The anterior dorsal cirri are longer than the branchiae. Branchiae begin on setiger 3, rapidly increasing to about 8 filaments, then gradually decreasing posteriorly. The maxillae follow a formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 5+5; Mx III = 7+0; Mx IV = 6+9. The antennae and tentacular cirri are long, weakly ringed, with the peristomial segment being elongate and carrying smooth, slender tentacular cirri. The aciculae and acicular setae are brown, with acicular setae being bidentate and having small guards. Geographically, this species is found in the Red Sea, tropical IndoWest Pacific, with records from Mozambique and Madagascar, and a doubtful record from South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Eunice filamentosa
Expected_answer: Eunice filamentosa Grube, 1856 features a body approximately 120 mm in length. The prostomium has a deeply notched anterior margin between the palps. The branchiae begin around setiger 26 with up to three filaments extending to the posterior end. The maxillae follow a formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (45)+(34); Mx III = (54)+(68); Mx IV = (37)+0. The short, slender tentacular cirri are smooth or wrinkled, with the peristome elongated, and the tentacular cirri are about half the length of the peristome. Acicula setae are brownish with fist-shaped terminal knobs; the acicular setae are brown, bidentate with recurved teeth and large guards; compound setae are also bidentate with well-developed teeth and rounded guards. The species is found in the Tropical Atlantic, ranging from North Carolina and Florida to Ghana and Angola, and has been recorded from Natal (South Africa).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Marphysa mossambica
Expected_answer: Marphysa mossambica Peters, 1854 is characterized by a large, elongated body reaching up to approximately 350 mm, with the posterior segments being flattened compared to the anterior. The prostomium features a deeply bilobed anterior margin. All setae are simple capillaries with very narrow, striated blades; comb-setae are absent. The antennae are smooth and approximately 1.5 times the length of the prostomium. Branchiae appear on setiger ~2533 (size-dependent), increasing to 68 filaments and persisting to the posterior end. The acicula are yellow to black, straight, with blunt tips. The acicular setae are pale, bidentate, about half the thickness of the acicula, and absent from some parapodia. This species is geographically distributed in the Red Sea, tropical Indo-West Pacific, and has been recorded from Mozambique Island.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Marphysa depressa
Expected_answer: Marphysa depressa Schmarda, 1861, features a slender, cylindrical body up to approximately 100 mm long. Its prostomium has a bilobed anterior margin. The superior setae include capillaries and asymmetrical comb-setae with many teeth, while the inferior setae are compound, comprising spinigers and long-bladed bidentate falcigers, which are more common at the front. The antennae are smooth and longer than the prostomium. Branchiae begin on setiger ~1025 (size-dependent), with 24 filaments at most, gradually decreasing posteriorly. Each parapodium initially has three acicula shafts that reduce to two posteriorly; these shafts are dark brown to black with pale tips. The acicular setae are pale distally, bluntly bidentate, with small guards. It is found in New Zealand and has also been recorded from South Africa (Cape, Natal).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Marphysa sanguinea
Expected_answer: Marphysa sanguinea Montagu, 1815 has a stout, oval body up to approximately 250 mm in length. The prostomium features a bilobed anterior margin. Superior setae consist of winged capillaries and numerous comb-setae with coarse teeth, while inferior setae are compound and spinigerous. Dorsal cirri are about as long as the setigerous lobes. The antennae are smooth and nearly twice as long as the prostomium. Branchiae start around setiger 1630, with up to 47 filaments that decrease posteriorly. Two to three black, blunt-tipped aciculae are present. Acicular setae are pale, bidentate with small guards in adults, and guards are larger in juveniles. This species is commonly found in muddy sandbanks and Zostera beds. Its distribution includes the North Atlantic (from Scotland to Senegal and from North Carolina to the Gulf of Mexico), the Mediterranean, New Zealand, southern California, and Japan.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Marphysa macintoshi
Expected_answer: Marphysa macintoshi Crossland, 1903 The body is described as Slender, rounded to slightly flattened; over ~200 mm long. The prostomium is described as Palps partially fused; anterior margin not distinctly bilobed; eyes indistinct. The setae is described as Superior setae winged capillaries and comb-setae; inferior setae compound with knife-shaped blades, often deeply retracted and appearing simple. The antennae is described as Smooth; about equal to prostomial length. The branchiae is described as Appear on setiger ~20Ã¢ÂÂ50 (size-dependent); up to 6 filaments; decreasing posteriorly. The jaws is described as Mandibles normal; maxillary formula: Mx I 1+1, Mx II 7+7, Mx III 7+0, Mx IV 3+8, Mx V reduced to chitinised areas without teeth. The acicula is described as Brown with pale tips; blunt; three anteriorly, reducing to one mid-body. The acicular setae is described as Single brown seta with a simple blunt tip. The geographical distribution is described as Red Sea and tropical Indian Ocean; recorded from South Africa (Cape to Natal), Mozambique, and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Marphysa bifurcata
Expected_answer: Marphysa bifurcata Kott, 1951, features a body approximately 80 mm long. The prostomium has completely fused palps with a rounded anterior margin. The setae consist of winged capillaries and comb-setae for the superior setae, and falcigerous, bidentate inferior setae with divergent teeth and rounded guards. Dorsal cirri are short, conical at the front, and bifurcate in the branchial regiona key diagnostic trait. The antennae are short, smooth, and about half the length of the prostomium. Branchiae extend from the setiger around 22 to the posterior end, with up to 45 filaments that arise directly from the dorsum without an axial stem. Three brown acicula with pale blunt tips are found anteriorly, decreasing to one posteriorly. The acicular setae are brown, yellowish at the tips, minimally bidentate, and lack guards. This species is distributed in Southwest Australia and has been recorded in Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Marphysa purcellana
Expected_answer: Marphysa purcellana Willey, 1904 features a body approximately 60 mm long with an oval cross-section. It has a prostomium with a brown bar and a front part with a reddish-brown pattern. The prostomium has a bilobed anterior margin. Its ventral setae are compound and falcigerous, equipped with two large teeth. The dorsal cirri are equal in length to the setigerous lobe before the branchial region, matching the branchial filaments there, but are much longer than the post-branchial setigerous lobe. The antennae are short, smooth, and about the same length as the prostomium. The branchiae begin on setiger 8 with four filaments, increasing to around 18 filaments by setiger 18, then decreasing and ending around setiger 28. Its jaws follow the maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 5+5; Mx III = 5+0; Mx IV = 3+8. The acicula are yellow and blunt, with acicular setae also yellow and strongly bidentate, accompanied by small guards. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa, including South-West Africa and Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Marphysa adenensis
Expected_answer: Marphysa adenensis Gravier, 1900 has a slender, rounded body cross-section, reaching up to approximately 70 mm in length with about 200 segments and no distinctive color markings. The prostomium features a smoothly rounded anterior margin. Superior setae are narrow-winged capillaries, while comb-setae have 510 teeth. Inferior setae are compound falcigers with long, narrow, bidentate blades. The antennae are tapered and not annulated, with the median antenna slightly longer than the prostomium. Branchiae appear suddenly around setigers 1519, become larger and pectinate around setigers 20, with 810 long filaments from a short dorsal cirrus. The jaws are weakly chitinized, with a maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 7+8; Mx III = 7+0; Mx IV = 7+11; Mx V consists of chitinous plates without teeth. The acicula are pale and blunt, with three anteriorly, reducing to one over most of the body. The acicular setae are single, pale, and emerge from setigers 3540 onwards; they are bidentate with small terminal teeth and guards. This species is found in the Red Sea and has also been recorded from Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Marphysa posterobranchia
Expected_answer: Marphysa posterobranchia, described in 1962, has a slender, rounded body about 30 mm long. The prostomium features a bilobed anterior margin. Its setae include winged capillaries and comb-setae with 815 teeth, while the inferior setae are compound falcigers with two strong teeth. Dorsal cirri are well developed at the front, becoming smaller towards the posterior, where they are less prominent than the branchiae. The antennae are smooth or mildly wrinkled, slightly longer than the prostomium. The branchiae are simple filaments found only on the posterior segments, appearing after around the 55th setiger in juveniles and most developed on the last segments in adults. The pale jaws follow a maxillary formula of Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 4+4; Mx III = 6+0; Mx IV = 5+10. The acicula are blunt, pale in juveniles and black in adults, appearing from approximately the 30th setiger. The acicular setae are bidentate with guards, also pale in juveniles and black in adults. Its distribution is limited to South Africa, from Cape to Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Marphysa capensis
Expected_answer: Marphysa capensis Schmarda, 1861, features a body up to approximately 150 mm in length and about 10 mm wide, with a roughly oval cross-section and a brown coloration accented by a slightly darker peristome. The prostomium is bilobed at the anterior margin. It has superior winged capillaries and comb-setae, while the inferior setae are falcigerous with rounded guards. The antennae are smooth and extend back to the first setiger. Branchiae start on setiger 1230 (size-dependent), reaching nearly the posterior end with up to four filaments. The jaws follow a maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 3+4; Mx III = 4+0; Mx IV = 3+6; Mx V = 1+1. The acicula are black and bluntly pointed, with acicular setae that are black, unidentate, and guardless. Its geographical distribution spans from South West Africa to the Western Cape, including New Zealand, the Chatham Islands, subantarctic regions, and Antarctica.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Marphysa corallina
Expected_answer: Marphysa corallina Kinberg, 1865 is characterized by a very long body, approximately 300 mm in length, with a rounded anterior region and a flattened posterior. The prostomium features a bilobed anterior margin. The setae include superior comb-setae with 2025 teeth and inferior compound, falcigerous setae. Antennae are smooth and about 1.5 times the length of the prostomium. Branchiae start on setiger 2050 (size-dependent) and can have up to six filaments; these continue to the posterior end, with filaments becoming reduced. The aciculae are dark with pale, blunt tips. Acicular setae are pale, bidentate, and have small guards. The species occurs in tropical Indo-West Pacific regions, with recorded sightings from Eastern Cape to Natal, Mozambique, and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lysidice natalensis
Expected_answer: Lysidice natalensis Kinberg, 1865, has a body up to approximately 100 mm long and about 5 mm wide, featuring a brown coloration with tiny white spots. Its prostomium has a white, bilobed anterior margin, with a pair of black, kidney-shaped eyes positioned just outside the lateral antennae. The setae consist of superior limbate capillaries and comb-setae, while the inferior setae are compound with short, blade-like falcigers. The parapodia have conical dorsal cirri, truncate setigerous lobes, and ventral cirri that are rounded at the front and merge with a glandular ventral pad towards the back. The antennae are white, slightly tapered, and approximately as long as the prostomium. The heavy, gouge-shaped mandibles are strongly calcified; the maxillary formula includes Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = 3+3 with very robust teeth, Mx III = (23)+0, Mx IV = 2+(48), Mx V = 1+1. The acicula are black with blunt tips, and the acicular setae appear from about setiger 20, brown, bidentate, with small guards. The species is distributed in southern Africa, with records from South West Africa, the Cape region, and Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lysidice collaris
Expected_answer: Lysidice collaris Grube, 1870 is described as having a body length of up to approximately 75 mm. Its prostomium features a bilobed anterior margin and reniform eyes. The setae include superior limbate capillaries, comb-setae, and inferior bidentate falcigers. The parapodia consist of a short, conical dorsal cirrus positioned high above the broad setigerous lobe, and a ventral cirrus that is papilliform, becoming indistinct from the glandular ventral pad after about setiger 30. The antennae are tapered and slightly longer than the prostomium. The jaws are mandibles that are gouge-shaped and partly calcified, with a maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = (45)+4, Mx III = (35)+0, Mx IV = 2+5, and Mx V reduced to chitinized areas. The acicula are brown shafts with blunt ends, and acicular setae appear around setiger 20, characterized by their brown color and blunt, minutely bilobed tips. The species is found in the Red Sea and tropical Indo-West Pacific, extending to Japan, with recorded occurrences from Cape, Natal, Mozambique, and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lysidice ninetta
Expected_answer: Lysidice ninetta Audouin & Milne Edwards, 1833 is characterized by a body length of up to approximately 150 mm, with a reddish coloration featuring white punctuations and white transverse bars on setigers 2 and 5. The prostomium has a bilobed anterior margin, with large, black, oval eyes. The setae include superior limbate capillaries and comb-setae, along with inferior compound falcigers having bidentate blades. The parapodia consist of dorsal cirri that are digitiform and as long as the truncated, compressed setigerous lobes, and ventral cirri that are papilliform with swollen bases. The antennae are subequal, shorter than the prostomium. Mandibles are heavy and gouge-shaped, with the maxillary formula being: Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = 4+4, Mx III = 4+0, Mx IV = 4+4, and Mx V reduced to chitinized patches. The acicula are dark in color. Acicular setae appear from around setiger 20, are bidentate, and have guards. Its geographical distribution includes the North Atlantic (English Channel, North Carolina), the Mediterranean, Angola, and possibly the Indian Ocean.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Epidiopatra gilchristi
Expected_answer: Epidiopatra gilchristi Day, 1960 is characterized by a slender body measuring up to approximately 60 mm, enclosed within an erect, tough, translucent tube that can be annulated or spirally twisted but remains attached. The prostomium features subulate frontal antennae and five smooth occipital antennae of normal length, borne on ceratophores with 57 rings; occasionally, the inner lateral ceratophores carry short stumpy projections. The setae include pseudocompound setae on setigers 14, which are strongly bidentate with well-developed hoods; comb setae with about 12 teeth appear from setiger 6, and later, two bidentate acicular setae emerge a few segments afterwards. Parapodia on setigers 13 possess subulate dorsal cirri, low presetal lips, postsetal lobes with an inferior papilla, and subulate ventral cirri. In posterior segments, ventral cirri become glandular pads, and postsetal lobes reduce to papillae. The branchiae are poorly developed, with 25 pairs present on setigers 49. The jaws are pale and weakly chitinized; the maxillary formula is: Mx I = 1 + 1; Mx II = 8 + 7; Mx III = 7 + 0; Mx IV = 6 + 10. This species is found in South Africa, specifically in the southern and eastern Cape as well as Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Epidiopatra hupferiana hupferiana
Expected_answer: Epidiopatra hupferiana hupferiana Augener, 1918, features a slender body up to approximately 30 mm long. The front part is brownish, marked by a dark spot behind each parapodium, with paired spots connected by a dorsal cross-bar. Its tube is encrusted with debris, coarse sand, or mud. The prostomium has distinct eyes, frontal antennae that are subulate, and occipital antennae that are fairly long, situated on ceratophores with 67 rings and sometimes featuring short lateral projections. The anterior setigers (13/4) sport capillaries and pseudocompound hooks that are bidentate and hooded, while the posterior setigers lack hooks, but display broader winged capillaries along with comb-setae and bidentate acicular setae. The first three setigers each have cirriform dorsal and ventral cirri and a tapered postsetal lobe, with simpler structures on later parapodia. Branchiae start from setiger 5 and extend to setiger 2030, with well-developed anterior branchiae that have spirally arranged filaments, gradually reducing to 12 filaments in the posterior ones. Its distribution is recorded in West Africa, including Senegal and South West Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Diopatra dubia
Expected_answer: Diopatra dubia Day, 1960, is characterized by a small body approximately 35 mm in length. It has a fragile tube made of mud with large shell fragments protruding. Its pigmentation varies, with the front segments often brown and ventral cirri that are white with a pale streak along the middle. The prostomium features reduced frontal antennae that are flattened extensions; occipital antennae on short, ringed ceratophores with lateral lobes on five rings. The anterior pseudocompound setae are hooded and strongly bidentate, with winged capillaries that have serrated blades; from setiger 10, bidentate acicular setae are present, and from setiger 15, comb-setae with 18-20 teeth. Branchiae begin on setiger 5, are weakly developed with 2-3 whorls of filaments, and disappear around setiger 30. The jaws are poorly developed, with mandibles that have straight, tapered shafts. Juveniles lack tentacular cirri until later in development. The species is found in South Africa, specifically in the Cape region.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Diopatra monroi
Expected_answer: Diopatra monroi Day, 1960, features a large body measuring 100150 mm in length. It has a sausage-like tube made of hardened mud, lacking shell fragments. The anterior region is brown, with a darker spot behind the median occipital antenna, and there are dark transverse bars on the anterior branchiferous segments. The prostomium includes subulate frontal antennae and a median occipital antenna on a ceratophore with 68 rings. The anterior pseudocompound setae are hooded and strongly bidentate, with comb-setae on setigers 68, bearing 1525 teeth, while bidentate acicular setae appear around setiger 16. This species is tubicolous, living in firm mud tubes. Branchiae start on setiger 5, with fairly long, well-developed filaments. The mandibles are dark and thickened, often sausage-shaped in adults. Its distribution includes South-west Africa and the western Cape of South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Diopatra musseraensis
Expected_answer: Diopatra musseraensis Augener, 1918, is characterized by a medium-sized body, approximately 50 mm long, with a brown anterior region lacking a distinct color pattern. Its tube contains projecting shell fragments. The prostomium features frontal antennae that are subulate, and a median occipital antenna positioned on a ceratophore with about 10 smooth rings. The anterior pseudocompound setae are hooded and strongly bidentate, while the comb-setae have 1525 teeth and broad blades that are rolled into a funnel shape, resembling a single broad central tooth. The branchiae are well developed, with relatively long filaments. The mandibles have straight, tapered shafts. This species is found in tropical western Africa, from Ghana to Angola, although it has not been recorded in other locations.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Paradiopatra quadricuspis
Expected_answer: Paradiopatra quadricuspis M. Sars in G.O. Sars, 1872 is a medium-sized species measuring approximately 4060 mm in length. Its body features rounded anterior segments and dorsally flattened posterior segments, with the anterior region displaying brown transverse bars and a tube reinforced with mud. The prostomium bears a pair of tiny anterior eyes and long occipital antennae situated on short ceratophores with about six rings. Its setae include hooded, tridentate anterior pseudocompound hooks; posterior feet possess winged capillaries, comb-setae, and bidentate acicular setae with guards. The species is tubicolous, inhabiting mud-reinforced tubes. Branchiae begin on setigers 69, increasing to a maximum of four filaments, then reducing to one after approximately setiger 40. The maxillary jaws follow a formula: Mx I = 1 + 1; Mx II = 7 + 8; Mx III = 8 + 0; Mx IV = (46) + (78). The acicula are yellow. Tentacular cirri, inserted behind the inner lateral antennae and shorter than the peristomial segment, along with ventral cirri on setigers 13, characterize the antennae and cirri structure. Geographically, it is distributed in the North Atlanticfrom Norway and Sweden to the English Channel and Senegaland in the western Atlantic from Canada to Massachusetts. The record in South Africa and the tropical zone is considered doubtful.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Nothria conchylega
Expected_answer: Nothria conchylega Sars, 1835 has an elongate body 40150 mm long, living in a freely moving, flattened tube covered with large shell fragments. The prostomium is cordate with a brown spot, with one pair of tiny eye spots and a large pair of eyes outside the inner lateral antennae. The anterior setigers (14) have stout pseudocompound or simple hooks, bidentate and usually guarded; from setiger 4, smooth-winged capillaries and fine comb-setae with 1012 teeth; long bidentate acicular setae appear around setigers 1015. It is a free-living, tubicolous species common in dredged sediments. The branchiae consist of a single filament from setiger 913, depending on size. Mandibles have a weak tooth on the calcareous edge and straight shafts; maxillary formula: Mx I=1+1, Mx II=67+67, Mx III=8+0, Mx IV=68+810, Mx V=0+0, with dark, toothless plates. Antennae ceratophores are short with 34 rings; ceratostyles are long, tapered, reaching about setiger 6. Parapodia cirri are tentacular, with short segment and long cirri reaching the prostomium's front. Setigers 13 are enlarged and project forward; presetal lamellae are dorsal and heart-shaped on front feet; postsetal lobes are elongated and cirriform on setigers 215, reduced posteriorly. Ventral cirri are tapered on the first 23 feet, then swollen; dorsal cirri are elongated anteriorly and reduced posteriorly. The species is cosmopolitan, found from the Arctic to subantarctic, including South Africa, Natal, and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Oenone fulgida
Expected_answer: Oenone fulgida Savigny, 1818, is characterized by its large, elongated body measuring approximately 100350 mm. The prostomium is rounded with two pairs of eyes, the outer pair being larger. Fine, tapered setae are present throughout, and the posterior feet feature two yellow, bidentate acicular setae. The parapodia are uniform, with a flattened, strap-like dorsal cirrus that is constricted at the base. The presetal lobe is short and rounded, while the postsetal lobe is longer. This species is a free-living, carnivorous polychaete. It has three stout antennae, shorter than the prostomium, often hidden by a biannulate peristomial fold. The mandibles are well chitinized; the maxillae have long, slender supports and a faint dagger-shaped median piece. The jaws are often asymmetrical, with the first tooth much larger than the others. The maxillary formula is: Mx I = 12 (or 7+5) + 7; Mx II = 9 + 15; Mx III = 6 + 5; Mx IV = 6 + 6; Mx V = 1 + 1. Distribution includes the Red Sea and Suez, tropical Indo-West Pacific, with records from Natal, Mozambique, and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Augneria tentaculata
Expected_answer: Augneria tentaculata Monro, 1930, features a slender, cylindrical body measuring up to approximately 135 mm in length and about 3 mm in width, consisting of around 110 segments, resembling a lumbrinerid. The prostomium is ovoid to rounded, with no eyes, and has three small antennae tucked in a peristomial pocket. Its setae include winged capillaries and compound hooks at the front, with capillaries that have very narrow blades and hooks that become simple further back; aciculae are absent. The parapodia are characterized by anterior feet with a low presetal lobe and large, ear-shaped postsetal lobe, while the posterior feet have lobes of similar size, with the postsetal lobe featuring a superior point. It is a deep-water benthic species. The jaws include well-developed mandibles with short, divergent shafts, and maxillae consisting of four symmetrical, toothed plates supported by small structures. The maxillary formula is: Mx I = 1 + 1; Mx II = 3 + 3; Mx III = 2 + 2; Mx IV = 1 + 1, with rectangular, toothless plates. The peristomium and the adjacent segment lack chaetae and are without pores, with paired buccal cushions located in front of the mouth. Its distribution is in the Subantarctic and Antarctic regions, and it has not been recorded from southern Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris magalhaensis
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris magalhaensis Kinberg, 1865, has a slender body that can reach approximately 100 mm in length. The prostomium is conical in shape. The setae feature long, winged capillaries and short-bladed compound hooks in anterior feet, from setigers 14 to around 1215; posterior feet only have simple hooks. The parapodia have a low, rounded presetal lobe throughout, while the postsetal lobe is conical, compressed at the front, becoming shorter posteriorly, and nearly equal in size to the presetal lobe. The jaws have a maxillary formula where Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = 4+4, Mx III is a curved cutting plate without a distinct tooth, and Mx IV = 1+1; with short, broad maxillary supports. The acicula are yellow. Geographically, this species is found in southern South America (Chile), subantarctic islands, Antarctica, and has been recorded occasionally in South African waters (Cape).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris meteorana
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris meteorana Augener, 1931 is characterized by a slender body approximately 20 mm long with around 120 segments and a pale yellow color. The prostomium is bluntly conical. The setae consist of anterior feet with about two long-bladed compound hooks and three to four winged capillaries, which disappear before the mid-body. The hooks become simple after roughly 10 to 15 segments and remain as two to three simple hooks toward the posterior end. The parapodia feature bilobed anterior feet, with the presetal lobe initially smaller but soon equal to the postsetal lobe, a condition that persists throughout most of the body. Mid-body feet are reduced, and posterior feet have both lobes long and filamentous, with the presetal lobe slightly longer. Its ecology indicates it is common in dredgings on muddy sand. The acicula are yellow. Maxillary jaws follow the formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 3+3 with stout, nearly bilobed teeth; Mx III consists of cutting plates without distinct teeth; Mx IV = 1+1, large and rounded. The mandibles are poorly calcified with united shafts, and the maxillary supports are broad and triangular. Geographically, it is found in southern Africa, recorded from South West Africa, Cape, and Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris albidentata
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris albidentata Ehlers, 1908, features an elongate body reaching up to about 100 mm, with juvenile anterior segments that are swollen to hold large jaws. The prostomium is conical and has a prominent nuchal slit at the junction with the peristomium. Setae include winged capillaries from setiger 150, long compound hooks from setiger 130, and simple hooks plus capillaries from setiger 3150; posteriorly, only simple hooks are present. The parapodia consist of anterior limbs with low presetal and rounded postsetal lobes, middle limbs with obliquely upward-facing subequal lobes, and posterior limbs that are elongate and bilabiate with stout lobes. The species is common in deep dredgings on muddy sand. The acicula are yellow, with four per parapodium. The maxillae jaws are heavily calcified mandibles with widely divergent shafts; maxillae are robust, featuring large white plates on Mx IV bordered in black; the maxillary formula is Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = (23)+(23), Mx III = 2+2, and Mx IV are indistinct paired plates. Maxillary supports are long and triangular. Its distribution includes South West Africa, South Africa (Cape, Natal), Mozambique, and it has also been recorded from North Carolina.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris brevicirra
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris brevicirra Schmarda, 1861, has a slender body approximately 5070 mm in length. Its prostomium is conical in shape. The setae consist of slender capillaries extending to the mid-body, with long-bladed simple hooks appearing within the first ~10 setigers and continuing posteriorly, where blades become shorter toward the rear. The parapodia feature small anterior feet with a rudimentary presetal lobe and a deep, compressed postsetal lobe; the presetal lobe enlarges posteriorly, while the postsetal lobe decreases in size. The posterior feet have elongated bases and lobes that are roughly equal. The acicula is pale in color overall, though some material from Chatham Island shows black. The maxillary jaws follow a formula of Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 5+5; Mx III comprises indistinct paired cutting plates; and Mx IV = 1+1. Its distribution includes South Africa (Cape, Natal), New South Wales, Chatham Island, Chile, and Japan.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris inflata
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris inflata Moore, 1911, has a small, approximately 20 mm long body that is short and orange. The prostomium is spherical and prominently white. Its setae are winged capillaries found in the first 30-40 feet, with hooded compound (or partially compound) hooks appearing in the first 3-4 feet, then becoming simple and continuing to the end. The anterior parapodia feature a low, rounded presetal lobe and a longer, similar postsetal lobe, with setae always longer than the postsetal lobe. This species is typically found on rocky shores and is considered uncommon. The acicula are yellow. Its maxillae follow a maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 4-5 + 4-5; Mx III = 3-4 + 3-4; and Mx IV = 2+2, with long maxillary supports. Geographically, it is circumtropical, present in the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific oceans, and has been recorded from Natal and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris coccinea
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris coccinea Renieri, 1804 is characterized by a small body, approximately 40 mm in length, appearing orange when alive and pale in alcohol. The prostomium is globular. The setae features winged capillaries on the first 3040 feet, with compound hooks from the first to around the 20th foot, becoming simple posteriorly with opaque white heads. The parapodia have anterior feet with a low, rounded presetal lobe and a longer, conical postsetal lobe; posterior feet are slightly longer but similar, with setae always surpassing the postsetal lobe. It is commonly found in algal tufts. The acicula are yellow. The maxillary jaws follow the formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 45 + 45; Mx III = 2+2; Mx IV = 1+1. Its distribution includes the North Atlantic (from the USA, English Channel to Morocco and Senegal), the Mediterranean, and recorded populations from South West Africa, Cape coast, and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris oculata
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris oculata Ehlers, 1908 is characterized by a small body approximately 20 mm in length, comprising around 87 segments. The prostomium appears ovoid with dark lateral pigmentation. Setae include winged capillaries from the first to about the 34th foot, alongside long-shafted compound hooks from the anterior to approximately the 16th foot, which are replaced posteriorly by simple, short-headed hooks. The parapodia of the anterior feet have low presetal lobes and long, ear-shaped postsetal lobes with an inferior expansion; the posterior feet are not described. The acicula are unreported. The maxillary jaws follow a formula of Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 3+4; Mx III = 1+1 (featuring a very small plate); and Mx IV = 2+2. The maxillary supports are long and kite-shaped. This species is known from South Africa and has only been documented from the type locality.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris latreilli
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris latreilli Audouin & Milne Edwards, 1834 is described as having an elongate body up to approximately 150 mm in length. The prostomium is conical. The setae includes winged capillaries from the first to around the 40th-50th foot, with long-bladed compound hooks from roughly the 3rd to 25th foot, which are replaced posteriorly by simple hooks that have progressively shorter heads. The parapodia feature anterior feet with a low, rounded presetal lobe and a larger, bluntly triangular postsetal lobe; posterior feet possess long, conical postsetal lobes that are always shorter than the setae. The acicula are yellow. The maxillae have a maxillary formula of Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (45)+(45); Mx III = 2+2; Mx IV = 1+1, with fairly long maxillary supports. This species is cosmopolitan in temperate and tropical seas and has been recorded from South Africa (Cape, Natal) and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris aberrans
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris aberrans Day, 1963 is characterized by a very small body, approximately 10 mm in length, with around 60 segments. The prostomium is conical, highly elongated, and as long as the combined length of the peristomium and the first four setigers. The setae are winged capillaries present from the first setiger, featuring very short, broad blades; simple hooks appear from setiger 4, which are bidentate with divergent teeth and a short, broad hood. The parapodia in the first six setigers have tiny lobes; subsequent parapodia become larger, conical, with a rudimentary presetal lobe and a shorter, conical postsetal lobe than the setae. The posterior parapodia are unknown. The acicula are pale. The maxillary jaws consist of mandible shafts that are completely fused, with very large maxillary supports. The maxillary formula is: Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = 3+3, Mx III = 1+1 (short plates with indistinct teeth), Mx IV = 0+0 (toothless oval plates). This species is known only from the Agulhas Bank in South Africa, based on a single specimen.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris tetraura
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris tetraura Schmarda, 1861 is characterized by a large body, reaching approximately 250 mm in length. The prostomium is conical in shape. The setae include winged capillaries from setiger 1 to about 60, and long-headed simple hooks from around setiger 4 to the posterior end, with hook heads becoming shorter and whitish after about setiger 30. The parapodia feature anterior feet with a low, rounded presetal lobe and a longer, bluntly conical postsetal lobe; posterior feet are longer but similarly shaped. The acicula are yellow. The maxillary jaws follow the formula Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = (45)+(45), Mx III = 2+2, and Mx IV = 1+1, with major plates bearing 45 teeth and long, kite-shaped maxillary supports. Its distribution is cosmopolitan, inhabiting temperate and tropical waters, with records from South-west Africa, South Africa (Cape, Natal), and Chile.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris hartmani
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris hartmani Day, 1953 is characterized by an elongate body reaching approximately 100 mm or more. The prostomium is conical in shape. The setae are winged capillaries extending from the anterior segments to around setiger 6070; around setiger 2545, long-bladed simple hooks appear and remain posteriorly, with blades shortening after the mid-body. The parapodia feature anterior feet with a low, rounded presetal lobe and a longer, conical postsetal lobe; posterior feet have an extending postsetal lobe that never exceeds the length of the setae. The acicula are yellow. The maxillae exhibit a maxillary formula of Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = (45)+(45), Mx III = 2+2, and Mx IV = 1+1, supported by long, triangular supports. This species is found in South Africa, specifically in False Bay, Cape, and is closely related to Lumbrineris fragilis.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris heteropoda difficilis
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris heteropoda Day, 1963 is characterized by an elongate body, typically over ~120 mm long. The prostomium is conical with dark pigmentation at its base. Its setae consist of anterior winged capillaries long, tapering superior ones, and short, blunt inferior ones, and around setiger ~40, long-bladed simple hooks emerge, becoming shorter towards the posterior. The posterior feet mainly feature short-bladed hooks with occasional capillaries. The parapodia have anterior feet with a low, rounded presetal lobe and a dorsally produced, compressed postsetal lobe; the posterior feet have a very long, digitiform postsetal lobe that significantly exceeds the length of the setae, which is a key diagnostic feature. The acicula are black. The maxillae follow a maxillary formula of Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (45)+(45); Mx III = 2+2; Mx IV = 1+1, and are supported by a heart-shaped structure. Geographically, the species is found in Southwestern Africa and South Africa's tropical regions, and has also been recorded from Tristan da Cunha and the Congo (Brazzaville).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Lumbrineris papillifera
Expected_answer: Lumbrineris papillifera Fauvel, 1919. The body is typically elongate, often exceeding approximately 100 mm. The prostomium is conical in shape. The setae consist of all anterior setae being winged capillaries; short-headed simple hooks appear around setiger ~40, replacing capillaries entirely before the mid-body. The parapodia feature anterior appendages with a low, rounded presetal lobe and a longer, conical postsetal lobe. The posterior feet have a short presetal lobe and a very long, possibly exceeding the setal length, postsetal lobe. Adults may develop a ventral papilla between parapodia from the mid-body onward, a new diagnostic character. The acicula are yellow. The maxillae support a maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (45)+(45); Mx III = 2+2; Mx IV = 1+1, with long, triangular supports. The species is found in Tropical East Africa, specifically recorded from Natal, Mozambique, and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Arabella mutans
Expected_answer: Arabella mutans Chamberlin, 1919 is characterized by an elongated body reaching up to approximately 190 mm with over 300 segments. The prostomium is conical, featuring four eyes. Its setae consist of winged capillaries with smooth or basally serrated blades, and it has one inferior asymmetrically hooded acicular seta, a distinctive feature. The parapodia have dorsal cirri reduced to a slight swelling at the base, a low, rounded presetal lobe, and a longer, blunt postsetal lobe. It has two to three yellow aciculae with pointed tips just piercing the body wall between parapodial lobes. The maxillary jaws include black, roughly M-shaped mandibles and well-developed maxillae with enlarged falcate hooks, with specific formulae for each maxillae: Mx I = (1+4)+(1+4); Mx II = (0+12)+(0+12); Mx III = (1+4)+(1+4); Mx IV = (1+3)+(1+3); Mx V = 1+1, with the presence of enlarged falcate hooks serving as a diagnostic character. The species is distributed geographically across Easter Island, Zanzibar, Cape Verde Islands, North Carolina, and has been recorded from Cape Coast and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Arabella iricolor iricolor
Expected_answer: Arabella iricolor iricolor Montagu, 1804 is characterized by a tough, wiry, and highly iridescent body, reaching up to approximately 100 mm, with short, crowded segments. The prostomium is bluntly conical, featuring four eyes arranged in a transverse row along the posterior margin. It bears four to five winged capillaries set often with serrated bases. The dorsal cirrus is well developed at the front as a curved papilla originating from the dorsal base of the parapodium. The parapodia have a low, rounded presetal lobe and a longer, conical postsetal lobe. About three yellow aciculae are present, pointed with tips that pierce the parapodial skin. The strong, black mandibles are roughly H-shaped, with maxillae containing an enlarged first tooth in series. The maxillary formula is Mx I = (1+9)+(1+8); Mx II = 8+14; Mx III = 7+5; Mx IV = (7+4)+(7+3); Mx V = 1+1. This species is cosmopolitan in temperate and tropical seas and has been recorded from Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Drilonereis falcata
Expected_answer: Drilonereis falcata Moore, 1911, features a slender, rounded body approximately 100 mm in length. The prostomium is depicted as depressed and bluntly conical, with possible presence of internal eyes. The setae are not distinctly differentiated in the original description, aside from their connection to the parapodia. The parapodia start on the first two segments, which are achaetous, and then develop well in subsequent segments with a very small presetal lobe and a conical postsetal lobe. The acicula are stout with projecting acicula seen from about setiger 1020, sometimes with two per foot. The maxillae are robust, black, and triangular, with basal teeth on Mx I and enlarged anterior teeth on all plates. The median unpaired support is dagger-shaped and fully black. The maxillary formula is Mx I = 8+6; Mx II = 8+8; Mx III = 4+3; Mx IV = 1+1; Mx V = 1+1. The posterior end remains unknown. Geographically, it is found in deep waters off California and has been sparsely recorded from South West Africa and the Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Drilonereis monroi
Expected_answer: Drilonereis monroi Day, 1960, is characterized by a long, tough, and wiry body exceeding 200 mm. The prostomium is blunt, depressed, and eyeless, almost fused to the first segment. It has four to five smooth-winged capillary setae between parapodial lobes. The small yet well-formed parapodia feature a low, rounded presetal lobe and a bluntly conical postsetal lobe, with posterior parapodia being elongate and the presetal lobe increasing to about half the length of the postsetal lobe. Each foot contains one stout, blunt aciculum projecting outward, along with three to four internal acicula with long, tapering tips that may resemble emerging capillaries. The maxillae lack mandibles but are otherwise well developed: Mx I without basal teeth, Mx V absent; the maxillary formula is Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = (68)+(68), Mx III = 4+4, and Mx IV = 4+4. Maxillary supports are very slender, and the unpaired median piece is pale with a black, heart-shaped basal area. The species is found in South West Africa, Cape coast, and Tristan da Cunha.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ophryotrocha puerilis
Expected_answer: Ophryotrocha puerilis Claparede & Metschnikov, 1869 is characterized by a small, colorless, vermiform body approximately 5 mm in length, with 2030 segments, each featuring rings of cilia. The prostomium is rounded and bears two ciliary rings, with papilliform antennae positioned dorsolaterally and similar palps located anteroventrally; it has one pair of eyes. Dorsal setae include one to three stout, simple setae, while median setae are two to four unidentate, falcigerous, and compound. A ventral simple pointed seta is also present. The parapodia are small, with setigerous lobes that support both dorsal and ventral cirri. Its ecology indicates an intertidal habitat, often observed in aquaria feeding on algal films. The jaws consist of brown, well-chitinized maxillae; mandibles with divergent shafts and bilobed, crenulate cutting edges; and maxillae made up of stout forceps (not dentate at the base) plus seven pairs of dentate elementsbasal three with about five teeth decreasing in size, and distal four with approximately twelve tiny, subequal teeth. The species has a cosmopolitan distribution across temperate and tropical seas.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Protodorvillea egena
Expected_answer: Protodorvillea egena Ehlers, 1913 features a small body (48 mm, ~60 segments). The prostomium is broadly conical; two pairs of eyes (anterior pair tiny); very small antennae with a single club-shaped joint; long, wrinkled palps with terminal palpostyles. Superior setae include one serrated capillary and one to two forked setae with smooth shafts and short, equal prongs flange internally; four inferior compound setae with short blades bearing minutely bidentate tips. Dorsal cirri are short, ovoid, without cirrophores or internal acicula, present on all feet except the first, arising distally; ventral cirri are ovoid. Setigerous lobes are elongate with a triangular presetal lobe. The maxillae have four rows of minute dentate elements. Found in South India, the Red Sea, and South Africa (False Bay).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Dorvillea gardineri
Expected_answer: Dorvillea gardineri Crossland, 1924, is characterized by a body size considered large for its genus, reaching up to approximately 50 mm in length with around 100 segments. The prostomium is small and rounded, featuring four large eyes and separated from the peristomium by a deep dorsal incision that contains a prominent nuchal papilla. The superior setae are capillaries with flattened blades and blunt, tapering tips; broken setae may appear forked. The inferior setae are compound, falcigerous, with short, tridentate blades. Dorsal cirri are well developed, while ventral cirri are not notably emphasized. Parapodia have tapering dorsal cirri, with each cirrus composed of a long cirrophore that is partially fused to a shorter cirrostyle, about a quarter of its length. The dorsal cirrus is present on setiger 1. Ecologically, this species is benthic and inhabits tropical marine environments. Its maxillae consist of four rows of toothed plates. The antennae feature approximately ten indistinct annulations, with palps slightly longer than the antennae and a weakly defined terminal palpostyle. The mandibles are well developed, with anterior margins that are denticulate. Geographically, Dorvillea gardineri is found in the tropical Indian Ocean, with recorded occurrences in Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Dorvillea neglecta
Expected_answer: Dorvillea neglecta Fauvel, 1923, has a small body about 15 mm long with around 80 segments. The prostomium is broadly conical and depressed, featuring two pairs of eyes. The superior setae consist of 34 fine, weakly serrated capillaries and 12 forked setae with subequal prongs and smooth shafts. The inferior setae are numerous, compound, with faintly serrated shafts and falciger blades of varying lengths, ending in tridentate tips. No dorsal cirrus is present on setiger 1; later dorsal cirri have long cirrophores with an internal aciculum and cirrostyles about half their length. The parapodia have an elongate setigerous lobe, a conical presetal lip, and a shorter postsetal lobe. The maxillae consist of four rows of small toothed plates. The palps are long with a well-developed terminal palpostyle; the antennae are slightly shorter, with 811 joints. The mandibles have dentate cutting edges with outer 34 teeth easily detached. Distribution includes the English Channel, with records from the Cape and Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Dorvillea rudolphi
Expected_answer: Dorvillea rudolphi Delle Chiaje, 1825, features a small body approximately 15 mm long with around 80 segments. The prostomium is broadly conical and depressed, with two pairs of eyes. Its setae include 34 fine, weakly serrated capillaries and 12 forked setae with unequal prongs and serrated shafts, while the numerous inferior setae are compound, faintly serrated, and have falcigerous blades of varying lengths that are bidentate and protected by tiny hoods. No dorsal cirrus is present on setiger 1; later, dorsal cirri have long cirrophores with an internal aciculum and cirrostyle about half their length. The parapodia feature elongated setigerous lobes with a conical presetal lip and shorter postsetal lobes. The species is benthic and marine. It has four rows of small toothed plates on the maxillae. The palps are long and end with a distinct palpostyle, while the antennae are slightly shorter with 611 joints. The mandibles have dentate cutting edges, with the outer 34 teeth easily detachable. Geographically, it is found in the English Channel, Mediterranean, Madeira, North Carolina, and from the Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Amphinome rostrata
Expected_answer: Amphinome rostrata Pallas, 1766: The body is large, measuring up to approximately 250 mm, dark grey, with a pentagonal cross-section. The prostomium is rounded dorsally, with a ventral groove, and features lateral palps, three dorsal antennae, and two pairs of eyes. The cirri includes a single dorsal cirrus located behind the notosetae and a short ventral cirrus. Its ecology indicates a planktonic lifestyle on driftwood, often found with floating objects supporting Lepas. Notosetae consist of simple capillaries and distinctive harpoon-setae with pointed tips and recurved serrations. Neuropodium is very short, stout, and positioned far from the notopodium, with a few stout, curved, needle-like neurosetae. Branchiae are tufted, branched filaments starting from setiger 23. The acicula has a knobbed tip, and the caruncle is small, smooth, and heart-shaped, extending to setiger 2. It is distributed throughout warm and tropical seas and has been recorded from the Agulhas Current (South Africa) on drifting substrates.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Chloeia flava
Expected_answer: Chloeia flava Pallas, 1766 has an oval body up to ~70 mm long with a median row of purple spots on the dorsum. The median antenna is slightly longer than lateral ones. It is a free-living amphinomid. Notosetae are serrated with a slight basal step, not distinctly forked; neurosetae are long, silky, spurred, not serrated. Branchiae are from setiger 4; the well-developed caruncle extends to setiger 4 with >30 lateral pleats. Found in tropical Indo-Pacific, recorded from Natal (South Africa).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Chloeia fusca
Expected_answer: Chloeia fusca McIntosh, 1885, is characterized by its small, brownish body measuring about 20 mm in length. Its dorsum features a pair of narrow purple longitudinal stripes. The prostomium has a median antenna that is longer than the lateral antennas. The anterior notosetae are smooth and distinctly forked, with the longer limb being roughly four times the shorter one; posterior notosetae include serrated types. All neurosetae are smooth and forked. This species is a free-living amphinomid. The branchiae begin from setiger 5. The caruncle extends to setiger 4 and has approximately 16 lateral lamellae. Its geographical distribution is in the Tropical Indian Ocean, recorded from Natal, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Pseudeurythoe microcephala
Expected_answer: Pseudeurythoe microcephala Fauvel, 1932 is characterized by a slim body roughly 30 mm in length and composed of about 120 segments. Its prostomium is small; the anterior part is ventrally grooved and features a pair of cirriform dorsal antennae and lateral palps. The posterior part, often hidden by a skin fold, is roughly square and bears two pairs of eyes along with a median antenna that resembles the lateral ones. The first setiger lacks hooks on its cirri. The notopodium notosetae includes few harpoon setae and numerous slender notosetae, which can be smooth or have very faint serrations. The neuropodium neurosetae consist of two types of spurred setae: mostly very long with a tiny basal spur and lightly serrated blades, and a few shorter with a strong spur and coarser serrations. Branchiae are tufted, extending from setiger 3 to mid-body. The caruncle is very small, oblong, and usually hidden. Geographically, this species is found in the Tropical Indian Ocean, recorded specifically from Natal and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Euphrosine myrtosa
Expected_answer: Euphrosine myrtosa Savigny, 1818, has an ovoid body approximately 15 mm long with 3643 setigers, displaying red to purple coloration. Its prostomium features four eyes, one stout, tapered median antenna, and smaller antero-ventral antennae. Notosetae are all forked, presenting two types: (a) straight, smooth prongs; (b) curved prongs serrated on inner margins, known as ringent setae. Neurosetae are forked with smooth, straight prongs. Dorsal cirri are longer than the branchiae, with the first dorsal cirrus positioned medial to the first branchial trunk, and the second medial to the third branchial trunk. The species typically occurs under stones and on old coral, though it is rare. It has six to eight long, evenly tapered branchial tufts per notopodium, with blunt tips. The caruncle extends posteriorly to setiger 5. Its distribution includes the Mediterranean, Red Sea, Indian Ocean, tropical West Africa (Cameroons), and it has been recorded from South Africa (Cape to Natal) and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Etiphrosine capensis
Expected_answer: Etiphrosine capensis Kinberg, 1857 features an ovoid body approximately 25 mm in length and red in color. The prostomium has very short antennae and palps that are almost papilliform. Notosetae consist of two types: smooth, forked setae with very unequal prongs, and forked ringent setae with serrated prongs on the inner margins. Neurosetae are forked, smooth, with unequal prongs. Dorsal cirri are shorter than the branchiae; the first dorsal cirrus is medial to the first branchial trunk, and the second is medial to the third branchial trunk. The species is commonly found under stones in the intertidal zone. Branchiae are present from the first setiger; even juveniles have 9-11 branchial trunks in the notopodia, with terminal filaments ending in ovoid, acorn-like tips. The caruncle extends to setiger 5 and overlaps setiger 6. Its distribution includes southern Africa, from South West Africa near the Cape to Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Eurythoe parvecarunculata
Expected_answer: Eurythoe parvecarunculata Horst, 1912 has an elongated body measuring up to approximately 220 mm with around 120 segments. The prostomium features a median antenna significantly longer than the lateral ones, along with a small oval caruncle at the posterior part that is often hidden beneath a fold of setiger 2. Notosetae include short harpoon-like and spurred setae, with the longer prongs tapering and having serrated edges. Neurosetae are mainly forked, and the anterior segments also carry finer setae with basal steps and faint serrations. This species is a free-living amphinomid polychaete. Branchiae begin from setiger 3, with long filaments at the front that gradually become shorter towards the back. Its distribution covers the tropical Indian Ocean and West Africa, with records from Natal, Mozambique, and possibly Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Eurythoe complanata
Expected_answer: Eurythoe complanata Pallas, 1766 is characterized by a large, elongated, and dorsoventrally flattened body, reaching up to approximately 140 mm in length, with a greyish-green coloration. Its notosetae consists of three types: smooth pointed capillaries, harpoon-setae with recurved serrations on one side, and fine setae featuring a small spur or step, along with long, slender blades that have very faint serrations. The neurosetae mainly include forked forms and finer spurred setae, with less diversity compared to the notosetae. This species is a common, free-living amphinomid, frequently found in association with coral rubble and hard substrates. Branchiae are present from setiger 2 onward. The prostomium's caruncle is elongated, with a flat keel, attached to setiger 3 and overlapping setiger 4. Its distribution spans all tropical seas, with recordings from the Eastern Cape, Natal, Mozambique, and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Eurythoe chilensis
Expected_answer: Eurythoe chilensis Kinberg, 1857, has a small body typically measuring 25 mm or less with around 50 segments. The notosetae consist of three main types: harpoon-shaped setae, spurred setae with 24 serrations on the longer prong, and a few long spurred setae with tiny serrations or steps on the blade. The neurosetae are mainly stout spurred setae with more developed spurs and serrations than notosetae, along with a few long, fine spurred setae featuring minute serrations. Dorsal cirri are long and tapered. Its ecology involves living on rocks and old shells. Branchiae start from setiger 2, each with 47 finger-like filaments. The prostomium caruncle is sinuous and elongated, attached to setiger 2 and overlapping setigers 34. Geographically, it is found in southern Chile and Tristan da Cunha, and has been recorded from the Cape region of South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Pisionidens indica
Expected_answer: Pisionidens indica Aiyar & Alikunhi, 1940 is characterized by an elongated, slender, and depressed body measuring about 25 mm with approximately 70 segments. These segments are weakly defined and feature dorsolateral muscular ridges and lateral grooves. The prostomium is a depressed conical shape with one pair of frontal antennae, lateral palps with basal sheaths, and four closely grouped subdermal eyes. The dorsal and ventral cirri are small and biarticulate. The first 56 parapodia lack setigerous lobes, while subsequent ones have elongated lobes supported by an aciculum; adults do not have setae. This species inhabits surf beaches and is locally common. The pygidium has a pair of long cirri. The peristome is fused to the prostomium, featuring two pairs of long tentacular cirri and a ventral slit at the level of the tentacular cirri. The pharynx contains marginal papillae and two pairs of small, lightly chitinized jaws. Reproductively, the sexes are separate: males have sperm-filled segments and a club-shaped vesicula seminalis opening on a large genital papilla (copulatory organ), while females possess a receptaculum seminis opening below the parapodium and a series of median ventral genital suckers. Geographically, the species is found in India and has also been recorded from Natal, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Mysta siphodonta
Expected_answer: Mysta siphodonta Delle Chiaje, 1830. The body is elongated and flattened, reaching up to approximately 200 mm with around 350 segments. The dorsum is uniformly mauve-brown, while the ventrum is pale. The prostomium is depressed and has a truncate-conical shape; antennae are equal and slender; eyes are distinct. Each parapodium bears 1520 setae, with fairly long blades; the shafts are asymmetrical, featuring one large blunt tooth and 35 smaller teeth. Dorsal cirri are ovate, 1.52 times as long as broad, on long cirrophores; ventral cirri are bluntly pointed. The setigerous lobe of the parapodia is blunt and shallowly notched. Tentacular cirri are subequal, roughly as long as the width of the tentacular segment. The species is free-living and occasionally found. The anterior segments follow the tentacular segment without a dorsal cirrus and bear setigerous lobes with setae and a ventral cirrus. The proboscis has a dorsal band of minute flattened denticulate papillae, paired ventrolateral rows of large triangular papillae, and a narrow ventral streak. South African specimens lack globular papillae. The distribution includes the Mediterranean, the Atlantic coast of Africa from Morocco to Senegal, and South Africa from False Bay to Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Mysta siphodonta
Expected_answer: Mysta siphodonta Delle Chiaje, 1830 is an elongate, dorsoventrally flattened worm up to ~200 mm long with about 350 segments. Its dorsum is uniformly mauve-brown, and the ventrum is pale. The prostomium is depressed and truncate-conical, with equal, slender antennae and distinct eyes. It has 1520 setae per parapodium, with fairly long blades; setae shafts are asymmetrical, featuring one large blunt tooth and 3-5 smaller teeth. Dorsal cirri are ovate, 1.52× as long as broad, on long cirrophores; ventral cirri are bluntly pointed. The parapodia have blunt, shallowly notched setigerous lobes. Tentacular cirri are subequal and about as long as the tentacular segment's width. The segment after the tentacular one lacks dorsal cirrus but has a setigerous lobe with several setae and a ventral cirrus. The proboscis features a wide dorsal band of minute, flattened, denticulate papillae, paired ventrolateral large triangular papillae, and a narrow ventral streak; globular papillae are absent in South African specimens. Its distribution includes the Mediterranean Sea, Atlantic coast of Africa from Morocco to Senegal, and South Africa from False Bay to Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Phyllodoce quadraticeps
Expected_answer: Phyllodoce quadraticeps Grube, 1878 is characterized by a slender, elongated body over 100 mm long, with a yellowish hue and a distinct dark transverse band on each segment. The prostomium is oval to subquadrate, featuring a posterior notch with an occipital papilla, and has oval antennae. An organ resembling a papilliform, possibly nuchal, is located in front of the first tentacular cirrus. The setae comprise five to six short bristles per parapodium, with swollen, striated shaft-heads and short, dagger-shaped blades. Dorsal cirri are reddish, oval, and broader than long, while ventral cirri are oval. The parapodia include elongate, faintly bilobed setigerous lobes. The tentacular cirri are unusual, with D2 being cylindrical and tapered, and the others having long cirrophores with short, swollen cirrostyles. The proboscis is very long and irregularly papillated. The first tentacular segment is not visible dorsally; the second and third are distinct and separate, both without setae (chaetal formula: 1 + 0 + 0). The species is found in tropical Indo-west Pacific regions, including Mozambique Island.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Phyllodoce fristedti
Expected_answer: Phyllodoce fristedti Bergström, 1914: A very long, slender body (~100 mm by ~2 mm), uniformly bluish green. The prostomium is cordate with large posterolateral lobes and a small occipital papilla. Setae are numerous with oval, distally striated shaft-heads and tapering blades. Dorsal cirri are hastate in front, rhomboidal posteriorly; ventral cirri are oval and longer than lobes. Parapodia have blunt setigerous lobes. All tentacular cirri are long and cylindrical. The proboscis has small papillae proximally and six ridges distally. First tentacular segment is not visible dorsally; second and third are distinct without setae (1+0+0). Found in the Western Indian Ocean, Madagascar, Mombasa, and Sri Lanka.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Phyllodoce malmgreni
Expected_answer: Phyllodoce malmgreni Gravier, 1900 is characterized by a slender body approximately 70 mm long, with a green coloration often featuring a dark median dorsal stripe. The prostomium is cordate, lacking occipital papilla. It has numerous oval, striated shaft-head setae with strongly tapered blades. The dorsal cirri are broadly rhomboidal or asymmetrically truncate, while the ventral cirri are pointed and longer than the setigerous lobes. Parapodia have bluntly rounded setigerous lobes, and the tentacular cirri are very long and cylindrical. The proboscis has an irregularly papillae-covered proximal region and six rugose longitudinal ridges distally. The first tentacular segment is not visible dorsally; the second and third segments are distinct and separate, with the third bearing a small setigerous lobe with setae (chaetal formula: 1 + 0 + S). Its distribution includes the Red Sea and Indian Ocean, recorded from Mozambique, with the type locality in the Red Sea.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Phyllodoce tubicola
Expected_answer: Phyllodoce tubicola Day, 1963 is characterized by a very slender body, approximately 30 mm long, sometimes enclosed in a delicate, transparent, closely annulated tube. The prostomium is longer than wide, featuring marked posterolateral lobes and a small notch at the posterior margin containing a tiny occipital papilla. Its setae have oval, distinctly striated shaft-heads, with long, tapering blades. Dorsal cirri in anterior segments are bluntly cordate, becoming longer and almost hastate in posterior segments; ventral cirri are tapered, pointed, and significantly longer than the setigerous lobes. The parapodia possess setigerous lobes with bluntly rounded tips. All cirri are extremely long and cylindrical, with the dorsal tentacular cirrus of segment 2 (D2) being the longest, reaching back to setiger 8. The species can be free-living or facultatively tubicolous, with a delicate, transparent tube. Its proboscis features an proximal region covered with irregular papillae and a distal half with rugose longitudinal ridges. The first tentacular segment is not visible dorsally, while the second and third are distinct and separate; the third tentacular segment bears a few setae (chaetal formula: 1 + 0 + S). Geographically, it is found in South Africa, specifically the Agulhas Bank and Cape region.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Phyllodoce schmardai
Expected_answer: Phyllodoce schmardai Day, 1963 is characterized by a moderately broad body, green in color, measuring up to approximately 30 mm in length. The prostomium is cordate with large, conspicuous eyes and a small occipital papilla. The setae feature oval shaft-heads with distal striations, and the blades are relatively short. Dorsal cirri are cordate, as broad as they are long anteriorly, becoming longer and nearly hastate posteriorly. Ventral cirri are broad at the base and pointed at the tip, but do not surpass the length of the setigerous lobes. The parapodia have bluntly rounded setigerous lobes. The tentacular cirri are cylindrical and fairly long. The proboscis has a proximal half that is lightly papillose, with the distal half bearing six rugose longitudinal ridges. The first tentacular segment is not visible dorsally; the second and third are distinct and separate, with setae present on segments 2 and 3 (chaetal formula: 1 + S + S). The species is found in South Africa, specifically the Cape region around False Bay, although its distribution remains uncertain due to confused synonymy.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris nationalis
Expected_answer: Tomopteris nationalis Apstein, 1900 is characterized by an elongated, pelagic body measuring up to approximately 20 mm in length. It has 17 segments and a long posterior tail with 34 rudimentary parapodia. The prostomium is shallowly notched between the antennae. The parapodia are biramous, with pinnules limited to the parapodial rami. The antennae are moderately long; the first cirrus is nearly as long as the antennae, while the second cirrus is notably long, matching the total length of the body plus tail. This species is a holopelagic planktonic organism. Its glands include large, swollen chromophil glands starting from the 2nd or 3rd parapodium, spur glands, and rosette glands located in the trunks of the first two parapodia and at the tips of both rami in subsequent parapodia. Pinnules are present only on the rami, not on the trunks. The gonads are found in both rami from the 2nd parapodium (possibly from the 1st). Geographically, it inhabits the Mediterranean Sea and has been recorded in warm currents off southern Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris apsteini
Expected_answer: Tomopteris apsteini Rosa, 1908 is characterized by a pelagic, elongated body approximately 20 mm in length, featuring 18-24 pairs of parapodia and a tapering tail formed by four additional segments. The prostomium is notched between the antennae. The parapodia are biramous with pinnules limited to the parapodial rami. The antennae are moderate in size, with the first cirrus small and the second elongate, measuring about three-quarters the length of the trunk. This species is a holopelagic planktonic organism.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris helgolandica
Expected_answer: Tomopteris helgolandica Greeff, 1879 is characterized by a pelagic, elongate body approximately 12 mm long, with a narrow trunk, a distinct neck, and 1416 pairs of parapodia followed by a long tail bearing three to four rudimentary parapodia. The prostomium features a notched shape between the antennae. The parapodia are biramous, with pinnules limited to the parapodial rami. The antennae are moderate; the first cirrus is present in juveniles but absent in adults, while the second cirrus is elongated, about two-thirds of the body length. This species is a holopelagic planktonic organism. Chromophil glands, small and faint, are present from the first parapodium, located in the middle of the lower half of the pinnule. Well-developed rosette glands appear from the first parapodium, situated on the inner side of the pinnules near the apex of each ramus. Spur glands are not reported. Pinnules are present only on the rami and are relatively narrow. Gonads are present in both rami starting from the first parapodium. The species is found in the North Atlantic.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris dunckeri
Expected_answer: Tomopteris dunckeri Rosa, 1908 has a pelagic, elongated body, reaching up to approximately 15 mm in length. It features 1617 pairs of parapodia, followed by a tail with an additional 910 parapodia; the tail seamlessly blends with the trunk. The prostomium is notched between the antennae, which are large and often have a frilled margin, with very large nuchal epaulettes. Its parapodia are biramous, with pinnules limited to the parapodial rami. The first cirrus is retained until the late juvenile stage, with remnants still visible in adults, while the second cirrus slightly exceeds the overall body length. This species is a holopelagic, planktonic organism. Its glands include large chromophil glands starting from the third parapodium, spur glands present from the second or third parapodium, and rosette glands located in the trunks of the first two parapodia and at the tips of both rami in later stages. Pinnules are confined to the rami, and those of middle parapodia appear reticulate when fresh. Gonads are present in the dorsal rami from the first or second parapodium. Geographically, it is distributed in the Indian Ocean, with confirmed sightings from Ceylon.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris duccii
Expected_answer: Tomopteris duccii Rosa, 1907 is characterized by a pelagic, elongated body measuring up to approximately 15 mm, with 19 pairs of parapodia, followed by a tail about 5 mm in length. The prostomium is not specified but aligns with the typical genus Tomopteris. The parapodia are biramous, with pinnules limited to the rami. The first cirrus is well developed, while the second cirrus is about two-thirds the body length. This species is a holopelagic planktonic organism. Large chromophil glands start from the 5th parapodium, located in the ventral pinnule's lower part; spur glands are well developed from the 3rd parapodium and less distinct on the 1st and 2nd; rosette glands are found in the trunks of the 1st and 2nd parapodia and near the tips of the rami in subsequent parapodia. The pinnules are confined to the rami, with the ventral pinnule bearing major glandular structures. Gonads are present in the dorsal rami starting from the 2nd parapodium. The species is distributed in the Eastern Pacific near Mexico, the type locality, and has not been recorded from southern Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris kempi
Expected_answer: Tomopteris kempi Monro, 1930 features a holopelagic and very large, flaccid body that extends approximately 55 mm in length. It has a trunk with 16 segments, followed by a tapering tail with over seven segments. The prostomium is notched between the long antennae, with well-marked nuchal grooves. Its swollen parapodia have short, conical rami and narrow, tough pinnules. The antennae are long, while the first cirrus is absent in adults. This species is a holopelagic planktonic organism. Glands include well-developed chromophil glands starting from the 3rd parapodium, faint on the 2nd, and doubtful on the 1st; spur and hyaline glands are absent; rosette glands are distinct near the apex of each ramus on the 3rd parapodium, but doubtful on the 1st and 2nd. The eversible proboscis has a projecting upper lip. Pinnules are limited to the parapodial rami, narrow, and resistant. Gonads are present in the dorsal rami from the 2nd parapodium. Geographically, it is found in the South Atlantic, specifically Tristan da Cunha, which is its type locality, but has not been recorded from southern Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris euchaeta
Expected_answer: Tomopteris euchaeta Chun, 1888, is characterized by a very large, holopelagic body that can reach approximately 150 mm in length. The trunk features up to 39 body segments, along with several distinct tail segments, while juveniles are notably shorter with about 15 segments. The prostomium is notched between long antennae, and the eyes are small. Its short pharynx does not extend to the first parapodium. The parapodia are biramous, with rami expanded by broad pinnules. The antennae are very long and laterally extensive, reaching the width of the parapodia. The first cirrus is lost after the larval stage and is absent in juveniles and adults. The second cirrus is extremely long in juveniles, up to four times the body length, but becomes shorter than the body in adults. This species inhabits deep-water habitats, generally found below 100 meters and often below 500 meters. Chromophil glands, starting from the 4th parapodium and positioned at the apico-inferior end, become swollen in adults. Spur glands are absent; hyaline glands, which are faint but consistent, are present from the 3rd parapodium onward on the distal ventral pinnule's inferior part. In juveniles, hyaline glands are absent from dorsal pinnules and vary in adults. Pinnules are broad, divided into two zones: an outer, frilly glandular zone and an inner, clear zone that resembles a flattened extension of the ramus; in juveniles, the glandular margin is not continuous between rami. Gonads are located in the dorsal rami from the 2nd parapodium. The species is distributed in the Mediterranean Sea, the temperate and tropical Atlantic, and the North Pacific, where it is often recorded as Tomopteris nisseni.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris krampi
Expected_answer: Tomopteris krampi Wesenberg-Lund, 1936 is a holopelagic, elongated body species measuring up to approximately 26 mm in length. Its trunk features 21 pairs of parapodia and a very short tail. The prostomium is not notched between the antennae, which are long and slender. The parapodia are biramous, with trunks extending distally and pinnules reaching the ends of the trunks. The first cirrus is retained in adults but remains slender, while the second cirrus is slightly longer than the total body length. This species is a holopelagic planktonic organism, usually collected from deep-water hauls. Chromophil glands become voluminous from the 4th parapodium onward, located in the inferior half of the ventral pinnule; spur glands are absent, and hyaline glands are faint but present at the apices of both pinnules from the 3rd or 4th parapodium. Pinnules extend onto the distal ends of the parapodial trunks; ventral pinnules are larger and gland-bearing. Gonads are found in the dorsal rami from the 3rd parapodium. Its distribution includes the Atlantic Ocean from south-west Iceland to the warm South Atlantic, as well as deep waters off California.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris carpenteri
Expected_answer: Tomopteris carpenteri Quatrefages, 1865: The body is characterized as holopelagic and very large, reaching up to approximately 90 mm in length. It has around 35 pairs of parapodia on the trunk, with no tail. The prostomium is not notched between the antennae, and the neck is short and broad. The parapodia are biramous with broad trunks and pinnules that extend to their distal ends. Antennae are long; the first cirrus is absent in adults, while the second cirrus measures about half the total body length. This species is a holopelagic planktonic type typical of cold southern waters. Glands include large, voluminous chromophil glands from the 4th parapodium onward, located in the inferior half of the ventral pinnule; spur glands are absent. Hyaline glands, pigmented, appear from the 3rd parapodium in the upper half of the ventral pinnule and are present on all subsequent parapodia. Pinnules are oval, frilly, and extend onto the distal ends of parapodial trunks, with the ventral pinnule being dominant and gland-bearing. Gonads are present in both dorsal and ventral rami starting from the 1st or 2nd parapodium. The species is found in the Subantarctic and Antarctic Oceans.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris elegans
