Expected_answer: Tomopteris elegans Chun, 1888, features a holopelagic, slender, and delicate body measuring less than 10 mm in length. It has around 14 body segments on the trunk and lacks a tail. The prostomium is notched between long, broad antennae, with a narrow neck. The parapodia are biramous, with long, slender parapodial trunks. The long and broad antennae and cirri include a first cirrus that remains in adults but is often small, and a second cirrus with a globular base, reaching about a quarter of the body length. Its ecology is described as holopelagic planktonic, typically characterized by small and fragile organisms. Glands are chromophil and well-developed from the 4th parapodium onward, located below the tip of the ventral ramus. Spur glands are absent, and hyaline glands are limited to the dorsal pinnules of the 3rd and 4th parapodia, at the pinnule's apex, usually visible only in sexually mature adults. The oval pinnules are confined to the parapodial rami. Gonads are found in the dorsal rami from the 3rd to around the 8th parapodium. Its geographical distribution spans the Atlantic Ocean, from the temperate North Atlantic to the subtropical convergence and the warm North Pacific.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris planktonis
Expected_answer: Tomopteris planktonis Apstein, 1900 is characterized as a small, delicate holopelagic organism approximately 7 mm long, with a trunk featuring 1318 pairs of parapodia and no tail. Its prostomium is notched between the antennae, and it has a broad, short neck. The parapodia are biramous, relatively short, with pinnules limited to the rami. Long antennae and cirri are present, with the first cirrus absent in adults and the second reaching up to about three-quarters of the body length. This species is commonly found in open ocean plankton. It has large, conspicuous chromophil glands starting from the 4th parapodium, located near the base of the ventral pinnule, causing a swelling, while spur glands are absent. Hyaline glands are faint but can be seen at the tips of ventral pinnules from the 1st parapodium onward. Pinnules are attached to the rami, with ventral pinnules swollen proximally due to gland development. Gonads are found in the dorsal rami from the 2nd or 3rd parapodium onwards. The species ranges from the North Atlantic to the Antarctic, including the subarctic North Pacific and around southern Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tomopteris cavallii
Expected_answer: Tomopteris cavallii Rosa, 1907 is described as a holopelagic, very small and delicate organism, approximately 5 mm in length. Its trunk has 17 pairs of parapodia, with no tail. The prostomium is shallowly notched between the antennae, and the neck is broad and short. It has biramous parapodia with short trunks and pinnules limited to the parapodial rami. The antennae are short, with the first cirrus absent in adults and the second cirrus reaching about a third of the total body length. This species is a holopelagic planktonic creature. Large chromophil glands start on the 4th parapodium, located centrally in the lower half of the ventral pinnule. Dorsal pinnules of the first 23 parapodia also contain tubular glands, while spur, hyaline, and rosette glands are absent. Pinnules are confined to the rami, with diffuse tubular glands in dorsal pinnules of the first 23 parapodia. Gonads are present in the dorsal rami from the 1st or 2nd parapodium. Its distribution includes the northwestern Atlantic, Indian Ocean, and western Pacific; records from southern Africa are doubtful and may refer to Tomopteris planktonis.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Travisiopsis lanceolata
Expected_answer: Travisiopsis lanceolata Southern, 1910 is characterized by a fusiform body reaching approximately 30 mm in length, with a head comprising three segments followed by around 19 trunk segments. Each head segment bears a single pair of lamellar cirri, while trunk segments feature both dorsal and ventral cirri. The prostomium is conical and equipped with a robust palpode. Cirri in the mid-body are reniform to quadrangular or cordate, becoming more elongated toward the posterior; the posterior cirri are lanceolate. Its ecology indicates a holopelagic habitat, recorded from deep plankton tows. The caruncle is broad and T-shaped, with a transversely oval base that extends posteriorly as a freely projecting tongue-shaped lobe. Nuchal organs are present as paired ridges embracing the caruncle and extending posteriorly as free digitiform lobes, roughly twice the length of the caruncle. The anal cirri are ovate-lanceolate, broader at the base and tapering distally, reinforced by a median rib. It is distributed across the North Atlantic, the temperate South Atlantic's deep waters, and the North Pacific.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Travisiopsis lobifera
Expected_answer: Travisiopsis lobifera Levinsen, 1885 has a fusiform body up to ~25 mm long, with three anterior head segments and ~18 trunk segments. Head segments bear lamellar cirri; trunk segments have dorsal and ventral cirri. The conical prostomium has a large anterior palpode. Cirri are dorsal and ventral, cordate mid-body, pointed posteriorly. Parapodia are setigerous lobes, with weak anterior setae and prominent posterior ones. Ecology is holopelagic, from plankton tows. The caruncle is a swollen, oval dorsal head structure, lacking a posterior lobe. Nuchal organs are paired semicircular ridges around the caruncle, continuing into digitiform lobes. Anal cirri are subtriangular, broad as long. Distribution is temperate and tropical North and South Atlantic, and temperate to subtropical Pacific.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Travisiopsis levinseni
Expected_answer: Travisiopsis levinseni Southern, 1910, has a fusiform body reaching approximately 24 mm in length, composed of three anterior head segments followed by around 22 trunk segments. Each head segment bears a single pair of lamellar cirri, while trunk segments feature both dorsal and ventral cirri. The conical prostomium, with a small, distinct palpode, is described as holopelagic, collected in deep-water plankton tows. Its flattened, almost rectangular caruncle lacks a freely projecting posterior lobe. Nuchal organs appear as short, semicircular lobes with bases extending anteriorly as narrow ridges alongside the caruncle, connecting to small wart-like lobes. Anal cirri are ovatetriangular, narrower proximally and broader distally. The head bears three pairs of lamellar cirri, and the trunk has dorsal and ventral cordate cirri with a broad attachment area in the mid-body; posterior cirri are elongated and tapered. Its distribution includes temperate North Atlantic, South Atlantic, subantarctic, and Antarctic waters, as well as the North Pacific off California.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ancistrosyllis rigida
Expected_answer: Ancistrosyllis rigida Fauvel, 1919 is characterized by a slender, stiff, and wiry body reaching up to approximately 35 mm in length. Its segments are uniform, muscular, and consistent throughout. The prostomium is small, occasionally partially retracted, with three short, nearly equal fusiform antennae and large palps ending in tiny terminal palpostyles. The setae consist of one or two short, forked types and several capillaries with finely spinulose edges; true notosetae are absent. The fusiform cirri are present on all segments, including setiger 2, with dorsal cirri slightly longer than ventral ones. Parapodia are small, lateral, weakly developed, and highly modified in the biramous condition. The notopodium is represented solely by a fusiform dorsal cirrus with an internal aciculum; from about setigers 1220 onward, a thick, projecting, blunt-tipped notopodial spine appears, slightly curved but never hooked. The neuropodium is a small, truncated lobe with neurosetae and a smaller fusiform ventral cirrus. The tentacular segment, comparable in size to other setigerous segments, has two pairs of short tentacular cirri resembling antennae. Its distribution is circumtropical, recorded from the Red Sea and Natal, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ancistrosyllis cf. constricta
Expected_answer: Ancistrosyllis cf. constricta was described by Southern in 1921. The observed body consists of juvenile specimens, measuring approximately 34 mm in length, with about 36 setigers. The body appears slender without a clearly defined constricted neck region. The prostomium features three cirriform antennae and two pairs of eyes. The palps are large, bent ventrally, each with a slender palpostyle. The setae in notosetae include fine capillaries and a stout, recurved hook, while neurosetae are composed solely of serrated capillaries. Dorsal cirri taper, and ventral cirri taper but are absent on setiger 2. Parapodia are present on all setigers, with blunt setigerous lobes; otherwise, they are simple and weakly developed. The notopodium is well-defined, bearing an internal aciculum, one to two fine capillary setae, and a stout, recurved hook, with the hook appearing first on setiger 8. The neuropodium is reduced, carrying only serrated capillary neurosetae; hooks are absent. The muscular pharynx lacks jaws. The peristomium is distinct from the prostomium and carries two pairs of tentacular cirri. This description is based on juvenile specimens; adult morphology is unknown, making the identification tentative. The species distribution includes India (the type locality of A. constricta) and South Africa (Natal).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ancistrosyllis robusta
Expected_answer: Ancistrosyllis robusta Ehlers, 1908, described as elongate, colorless, up to ~54 mm long with ~182 uniform segments. The prostomium is broader than long with three slender antennae, and palps with knob-shaped palpostyles. Setae are capillary neuropodial only, with shorter capillaries serrated and longer smooth; no true notosetae. Dorsal cirri are tapered, with the first setiger's conspicuously elongated dorsal cirrus twice as long as tentacular cirri; ventral cirri are short. Parapodia are present from setiger 1, well-developed with setae and cirri. The notopodium has a tapered dorsal cirrus with a fine aciculum in early segments, replaced by a stout hook after about setiger 70. Neuropodia form ovoid lobes with capillary neurosetae. The short, stout pharynx has a mouth surrounded by 16 ovoid papillae. The peristomium is distinct, with two pairs of shorter tentacular cirri. Development of a stout notopodial hook in posterior segments distinguishes this species from others. It is only known from Great Fish Bay, Angola.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ancistrosyllis robusta
Expected_answer: Ancistrosyllis robusta Ehlers, 1908 features an elongate, colorless body measuring up to approximately 54 mm with around 182 uniform, cylindrical segments. The prostomium is broader than long, rounded at the front, with three slender antennae; the median antenna extends to setiger 5; stout palps and knob-shaped palpostyles. Notosetae are absent; the notopodium has only an aciculum or posterior hook, while neurosetae are capillary with short, finely serrated or long, smooth setae. Dorsal cirri are tapered and cirriform, with the dorsal cirrus on setiger 1 being elongated, about twice the tentacular cirri; ventral cirri are short and cirriform, though the setiger 2 ventral cirrus is uncertain. From setiger 1, the parapodia are small but well developed, present on all setigers. The notopodium has a dorsal cirrus with a fine internal aciculum anteriorly and a stout projecting hook from about setiger 70 posteriorly. The neuropodium is an ovoid setigerous lobe with only capillary neurosetae. The short, stout pharynx features a mouth ringed by 16 ovoid papillae. The peristomium is a distinct tentacular segment with two pairs of shorter cirri than the antennae. The key diagnostic feature is the posterior development of a stout, projecting notopodial hook. This species is found in Angola, specifically in Great Fish Bay.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ophiodromus agilis
Expected_answer: Ophiodromus agilis Ehlers, 1864 features a small body measuring about 45 mm with 1622 setigers. It has a square prostomium with four eyes  the anterior pair slightly larger and more spaced apart. The median antenna is fusiform, approximately equal in length to the prostomium, while the lateral antennae are similar but longer. Elongated palps have short palpophores. The setae include single capillary notosetae and falcigerous neurosetae with long, finely bidentate blades. Dorsal cirri are fusiform and weakly ringed; ventral cirri are slender. Parapodia are weakly developed and biramous. The notopodium is reduced, containing an aciculum, a single capillary, and a vaguely ringed dorsal cirrus. The neuropodium has a triangular presetal lobe and a rounded postsetal lip. The proboscis lacks papillae or jaws. Its diagnostic features include a reduced notopodium with a single capillary and aciculum, and falcigerous neurosetae with long, bidentate blades. The peristomium consists of six pairs of tentacular cirri, which are fusiform and on ringed ceratophores. This species is distributed in the Mediterranean, with a doubtful record from Natal, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Syllidia armata
Expected_answer: Syllidia armata, described by Quatrefages in 1865, has a small, broad body measuring less than 10 mm with 26 to 35 setigers. It features a greenish-yellow coloration with transverse stripes that fade in alcohol. The prostomium is nearly square, with four eyes, two long antennae, and biarticulate palps. The setae are falcigerous, with blades of varying lengths and a terminal hook that has a very fine secondary tooth below. Dorsal cirri are long and faintly annulated. The parapodia are uniramous, with the notopodium reduced to a dorsal cirrus containing an aciculum in the cirrophore. The neuropodium is triangular with a low, rounded postsetal lamella and a triangular presetal lip. The proboscis is armed, featuring a median ventral stylet, paired lateral jaws with serrated edges, and 1015 papillae along the margin. The peristomium consists of six pairs of tentacular cirri, which are annulated. Its geographical distribution includes the Eastern Atlantic from Scotland to Angola, the Mediterranean, and recorded presence in South West Africa and Cape Province, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Syllidia capensis
Expected_answer: Syllidia capensis McIntosh, 1925, has a generally grayish body about 12 mm in length. Its prostomium's features include unknown antennae and four eyes, with palps that are slightly tapered and have an articulation at the distal third. The setae vary in length, with median setae being the longest and having hair-like tips, while the inferior setae possess minutely bidentate blades. The dorsal cirrus is long, accompanied by a ventral cirrus. The parapodia are uniramous, with the notopodium represented by a long dorsal cirrus and a cirrophore bearing at least four internal spines. The neuropodium has three-pointed lobes, with the median lobe noticeably larger than the lateral lobes. This species is found in South Africa, specifically in the Cape region, with a single doubtful deep-water record.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Hesione splendida
Expected_answer: Hesione splendida Savigny, 1818, features a cylindrical body that tapers slightly towards the rear, measuring 4070 mm in length and 46 mm in width. Its prostomium is deeply notched at the back; it has four eyes, with the front pair being larger and more widely spaced. Two tiny anterolateral antennae are present. The setae are falcigerous, with blades varying in length; their tips are bidentate, equipped with two strong teeth and a fine, straight accessory tooth. The dorsal cirri are long and articulated; ventral cirri are short and indistinctly jointed; there are two long anal cirri. The parapodia are well developed, with a stout setigerous lobe. The notopodium bears long, closely jointed dorsal cirri on long cirrophores containing fine internal acicula. The neuropodium has presetal and postsetal lips and a superior conical papilla. The jointed tentacular cirri are approximately equal in size and arranged in oblique rows of 3, 3,3,2, and 2. The wide, smooth pharynx has an ovoid dorsal tubercle anterior to the prostomium, with no jaws or marginal papillae. The species is distributed across the Eastern Atlantic (from France to Senegal), the Mediterranean, the Red Sea, and the tropical Indowest Pacific.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Leocrates claparedii
Expected_answer: Leocrates claparedii Costa, 1868 has a stout body measuring 4060 mm with 1617 rounded setigers. Its prostomium is bilobed, with slender antennae and stout palps. A large ovoid facial tubercle is located anterior to the prostomium. The setae include notosetae that are capillary and serrated at the ends, while neurosetae are falcigerous with blades that are bidentate and have a fine accessory tooth. The cirri are dorsal and tentacular, elongate, and annulated. The parapodia are well developed, with the notopodium carrying capillaries from setigers 45 that are finely serrated distally, and the neuropodium bearing falcigerous neurosetae. The long, closely annulated tentacular cirri are reinforced by black acicula, as are the tentaculophores. The pharynx features a proboscis with a stout dorsal styliform tooth and a finer ventral tooth. Its distribution includes Senegal, the Mediterranean, the Red Sea, tropical Indowest Pacific regions, and South Africa from Transkei to Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Pharyngeovalvata natalensis
Expected_answer: Pharyngeovalvata natalensis Day, 1951 is characterized by a soft, dorsally swollen body about 12 mm long. The prostomium is wider than long, with large eyes, possibly two pairs fused, and ventrally bent palps; an occipital flap is present. The compound setae have expanded shaft-heads and short, hooked blades that are unidentate or bear a small secondary tooth. The dorsal cirri are long and indistinctly jointed, while the parapodia are weakly developed. The notopodium lacks distinct notosetae, whereas the neuropodium bears compound setae. Long, indistinctly jointed tentacular cirri and antennae are also present. The pharynx is valvate, with a longitudinal dorsal ridge that meets transverse ventrolateral ridges around setiger 5, and it lacks chitinous teeth. The proventriculus extends from setiger 10 to 18 and contains roughly 70 rows of points. This species is found in South Africa, specifically in the Natal and Cape regions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Haplosyllis trifalcata
Expected_answer: Haplosyllis trifalcata Day, 1960, is approximately 9 mm long with around 88 pale segments in alcohol. The prostomium has four eyes, with short, nearly equal antennae and broad, unfused palps. Its setae are simple, with expanded shaft-heads and trifalcate tips featuring three similar claw-like teeth. The dorsal cirri are very short, tapered, and often coiled, with 912 segments; ventral cirri are small. The parapodia are small, each with 36 simple setae, and the notopodium is reduced without distinct notosetae. The neuropodium bears only simple setae. The elongated pharynx and proventricle with about 40 rows of points are noted. This species is found in South Africa, specifically False Bay, Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Syllis gracilis
Expected_answer: Syllis gracilis Grube, 1840 is characterized by a slender body approximately 35 mm in length, with two dark transverse cross-bars on the anterior segments. The prostomium features four eyes and stout antennae with 812 articulations. The setae comprise anterior parapodia with compound bidentate setae, while mid-body parapodia contain 23 stout, Y-shaped simple setae, which result from the loss of the blade of the compound setae; notably, compound setae reappear posteriorly. The dorsal cirri are robust; the anterior cirri are cylindrical with approximately 16 joints, and the median cirri are shorter, fusiform, with 812 joints. The parapodia exhibit the typical syllid form. The notopodium is reduced, whereas the neuropodium bears both compound and simple setae. The pharynx is elongated with a single anterior tooth. The proventriculus extends from setigers 10 to 14. The species has a cosmopolitan distribution, inhabiting temperate and tropical seas from South West Africa to Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Syllis amica
Expected_answer: Syllis amica Quatrefages, 1866, features a slender body measuring 2060 mm in length. Its prostomium has four eyes. The setae are numerous compound types with short, unidentate or minimally bidentate blades; some are simple and stout due to blade loss, with an obliquely truncated shaft-head; the aciculum has a small apical knob. Dorsal cirri are stout, tapered, and have 1525 joints, roughly the same length as the body width. The parapodia are typical of syllids, with a reduced notopodium and a neuropodium that bears both compound and simple setae. The long pharynx has a single anterior tooth. The proventriculus extends over five segments. This species is found in the Northeastern Atlantic and Mediterranean regions and has been recorded from Natal, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Syllis anops
Expected_answer: Syllis anops Ehlers, 1897 features a slender body measuring 1525 mm with around 120 segments. The prostomium is broader than it is long, with no eyes. It has anterior compound setae with blades of unequal length, tips that are minutely bidentate, and middle parapodia with superior Langerhansia-type setae featuring very long, slender blades, while the inferior setae are unidentate. The acicula is very stout with a blunt tip. Dorsal cirri are about as wide as the body and have around 30 joints, while ventral cirri are short, emerging near the distal end of setigerous lobes. The parapodia are typical of syllids, with a reduced notopodium and a neuropodium bearing both compound and modified setae. The antennae are short, almost equal in length, with 2530 joints. The pharynx includes an anterior tooth, and the proventriculus extends over approximately 11 segments. The fused palps are basally joined. This species is found in the Magellan region, Chatham Islands, and has been recorded from the Cape, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Paraehlersia ferrugina
Expected_answer: Paraehleria ferrugina Langerhans, 1881, has a body that is slender and thread-like, approximately 10 mm long. Its prostomium features four eyes and two ocular specks. The anterior compound setae have blades of varying lengths, with a stronger terminal tooth than secondary; middle parapodia possess 1-2 superior Langerhansia-type setae with significantly elongated blades, while other setae have shorter blades and a secondary tooth that is more robust than the terminal. The acicula in middle parapodia are stout and knob-tipped. Dorsal cirri are long, slender, with 15-25 joints that are distinct anteriorly and less so posteriorly. Ventral cirri are slightly longer than the setigerous lobes. The parapodia are typical of syllids, with a reduced notopodium and a neuropodium bearing both compound and modified setae. The long pharynx has an anterior tooth. The proventriculus features approximately 25 rows of points. The palps are large. Geographically, this species is found in the eastern and western Atlantic, from North Carolina and Ireland to Angola, and is common around the Cape of South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Syllis cornuta
Expected_answer: Syllis cornuta Rathke, 1843 features a body that is thread-like and measures 1015 mm. The prostomium has four eyes and two ocular specks. It has one to three superior compound setae with very long blades, about six compound setae with normal bidentate blades, and a slender secondary tooth. The dorsal cirri are short, with 1018 joints that are always clearly marked. The parapodia are typical of syllids, with a reduced notopodium and a neuropodium bearing compound setae. The long pharynx has an anterior tooth. The proventriculus contains approximately 3035 rows of points. The large palps complement the organism's features. Its distribution ranges across the Atlantic from Greenland to Georgia (USA), and from Scotland to Antarctica, including the tropical Indian Ocean. It is common along the South African coast.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Syllis prolifera
Expected_answer: Syllis prolifera Krohn, 1852, has a body length of 1020 mm, with anterior segments featuring two dark transverse lines. Its prostomium has four eyes and fairly long, separate palps. It possesses approximately 10 compound setae with blades that are strongly bidentate and of normal length. The dorsal cirri alternate between long and short, with about 22 and 27 joints respectively. The parapodia are typical of syllids, with a reduced notopodium and a neuropodium bearing compound setae. The median antenna has about 27 joints, while the lateral antennae have roughly 16 joints. The pharynx extends to setiger 9, and the proventriculus reaches setiger 15, featuring approximately 2530 rows of points. Its distribution covers the Eastern Atlantic from South West Africa to the Cape, including Mozambique, the British Channel, the Mediterranean, and the IndoWest Pacific.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Syllis variegata
Expected_answer: Syllis variegata Grube, 1860 features a body measuring up to approximately 40 mm, with a tough texture. The anterior segments display broken brown transverse bars. The prostomium has four eyes. All setae are compound, with blades strongly bidentate and of standard length. Dorsal cirri are longer than the body width and have about 20-40 distinct joints. The parapodia are typical of syllids, with a reduced notopodium and a neuropodium bearing compound setae. The long pharynx reaches to setiger 12 and has an anterior dorsal tooth. The long proventriculus extends over roughly 8-10 segments. This species is found in Southwest Africa, including the Cape coast, Natal, Mozambique, and is also cosmopolitan in temperate and tropical seas.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Opisthosyllis ankylochaeta
Expected_answer: Opithosyllis ankylochaeta Fauvel, 1921 has a smooth, colorless body approximately 15 mm long. The prostomium features four large eyes, with long palps originating at the base, and lacks an occipital flap. The setae include compound unidentate types on both the anterior and posterior feet, while the middle feet have two simple setae resulting from the fusion of a short hooked blade with the shaft. Dorsal cirri vary in length; the longer ones, around 30 joints, are roughly as wide as the body, whereas the shorter cirri have fewer joints. Ventral cirri are sausage-shaped. The parapodia resemble typical syllid structures. The notopodium is reduced, and the neuropodium bears both compound and simple setae, depending on the segment. The pharynx is positioned with a dorsal tooth located far back near setiger 10. The tentacular cirri on the peristomium have about 30 joints. The long proventriculus extends over approximately six segments. This species is found in Madagascar (Tamatave) and New Caledonia.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Opisthosyllis brunnea
Expected_answer: Opisthosyllis brunnea Langerhans, 1879, has a smooth, soft body that is relatively broad, reaching about 10 mm in length and comprising approximately 75 segments. The prostomium bears an occipital flap covering the posterior eye pair and part of the prostomium. The setae are compound, with short, unidentate blades. The dorsal cirri are slender, with roughly 20 joints. The parapodia are typical of syllids, with a notably reduced notopodium. The neuropodium bears compound setae, a feature that further distinguishes the species. The pharynx is elongated and broad, with a small dorsal tooth located around the eighth setiger. The proventriculus extends over approximately 8 segments and contains about 70 rows of points. The palps are tapered and approximately twice as long as the prostomium. Geographically, this species occurs in Madeira, along the tropical West African coast, in South Africa (from False Bay to Natal), and in Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Trypanosyllis prampramensis
Expected_answer: Trypanosyllis prampramensis Augener, 1918, has an elongate, ribbon-like body approximately 25 mm long and 2 mm wide, featuring two dark transverse lines on the anterior segments. Its prostomium is broader than long, faintly bilobed, with four anterior eyes, short palps, and short antennae with 1012 joints. It has around 10 compound setae per parapodium, with blades that are short, unidentate, and hooked. The dorsal cirri are short, stout, often spindle-shaped, with 812 joints, appearing purplish when fresh. The parapodia are typical for the genus, with a reduced notopodium and a neuropodium bearing compound setae. It possibly reproduces via a single sexual stolon. The short pharynx has a trepan with about 10 triangular teeth. Its peristomium tentacular segment features tentacular cirri with 1520 joints. The proventriculus has roughly 2530 rows of points. Geographically, it is found in tropical western Africa, including South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Trypanosyllis ankyloseta
Expected_answer: Trypanosyllis ankyloseta Day, 1960, has a very short, flattened, oval body approximately 8 mm long and 1.8 mm wide, with about 120 segments. The segments are extremely short, around 20 times wider than long. The prostomium is located between the front segments, featuring four eyes arranged rectangularly, and ovoid palps. It has three short antennae with 68 joints. The setae are simple, with a falcate blade fused to the shaft-head. Dorsal cirri are short with 68 joints, while ventral cirri are inconspicuous. The parapodia and notopodium are reduced, and the neuropodium bears simple setae. The long, S-shaped pharynx has a trepan with about ten teeth. The peristomium's tentacular segment is not clearly distinct. The proventriculus contains around 4050 rows of pores. This species is recorded from False Bay, South Africa, based on a single specimen.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Trypanosyllis zebra
Expected_answer: Trypanosyllis zebra Grube, 1860, is an elongate, flattened worm (~3060 mm) with two purple transverse bars per segment and often purple dorsal cirri. It has a broader-than-long prostomium with four eyes, compound bidentate setae with a close secondary tooth, and blade without a basal spur. Dorsal cirri alternate long and short (~2050 joints), ventral cirri are pointed. The biramous, well-developed parapodia have a dorsal cirrus on the notopodium and compound setae on the neuropodium. Reproduction involves a single stolon; clusters of buds are absent. The pharynx has a trepan of ~10 triangular teeth and a dorsal tooth. The long proventriculus has ~30 rows of points. It is found in North Atlantic, Mediterranean, tropical Indian Ocean, Japan, and southern Africa from False Bay to Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Amblyosyllis formosa
Expected_answer: Amblyosyllis formosa Claparede, 1863 has a short body measuring approximately 1015 mm with 13 setigers. Its segments are nearly as long as they are wide, featuring a broken purple dorsal pattern. The prostomium appears roughly square with four large eyes and palps bent ventrally, fused at the base, along with prominent nuchal epaulettes reaching setiger 2. The compound setae have finely bidentate blades with variable lengths. The dorsal cirri are very long, coiled, and pseudo-articulate, while the ventral cirri are pinniform, located postero-ventrally, and longer than the setigerous lobes. The parapodia are well developed, with the notopodium containing a long, coiled dorsal cirrus, and the neuropodium featuring a ventral cirrus and compound setae. The tentacular and antenna cirri are both very long, coiled, and pseudo-articulate. The pharynx is long, coiled, with a crown of 67 teeth. The proventriculus is ovoid. Geographically, this species is found in the North Atlantic (from Plymouth to Senegal), the Mediterranean, Japan, South Africa, the tropics, and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Syllides longocirrata
Expected_answer: Syllides longocirrata Oersted, 1845 has a small body, approximately 5 mm long, with 3746 segments. It features elongated parapodia and cirri. The prostomium is wider than it is long, with large, fused palps that bend ventrally. It bears compound setae with long, finely bidentate blades, along with one simple, sabre-shaped seta per parapodium that has a finely serrated blade. The anterior dorsal cirri are slightly swollen at the tips, while the posterior dorsal cirri are long, consisting of 1015 distinct joints. The ventral cirri are slender. Its parapodia are long, with the notopodium containing compound setae and a simple superior seta, and the neuropodium also bearing compound setae. The tentacular cirri are swollen and wrinkled distally, as are the antennae. The pharynx lacks armament. The proventriculus has 4045 rows of points. This species is found in the North-east Atlantic, Mediterranean, Chile, New Zealand, South Africa, and tropical regions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Odontosyllis polycera
Expected_answer: Odontosyllis polycera Schmarda, 1861 is characterized by a soft, fragile body up to approximately 50 mm long and 2 mm wide, with a dorsally swollen appearance. The prostomium features four large, rectangularly arranged eyes, a median antenna situated between and behind the lateral antennae, and a large occipital flap covering most of it. About 25 compound setae per parapodium are present, with short, triangular, bidentate blades and a median secondary tooth. The dorsal cirri are tapered and either smooth or slightly wrinkled; the anterior dorsal cirri are relatively long, while middle-body dorsal cirri are less than half the body width. Ventral cirri are swollen, cushion-like, located ventrolaterally to the setigerous lobe. The parapodia contain numerous compound setae, with the notopodium reduced to a dorsal cirrus only, and the neuropodium featuring a setigerous lobe with compound setae. The antennae are tapered and range from smooth to faintly wrinkled. The long, vertically S-shaped pharynx has an anterior half that is thin-walled with a soft dorsal ridge, and a posterior half that is thick-walled, with a tiny dorsal tooth at the junction and a ventral semicircular row of 69 triangular teeth with lateral cutting plates. The long proventriculus has 6080 rows of points. Its geographical range includes Southern Africa (South West Africa, Cape region, Mozambique), Madagascar, and the Chatham Islands (New Zealand).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Pionosyllis magnidens
Expected_answer: Pionosyllis magnidens Day, 1953 features a small body approximately 4 mm in length with around 45 segments. The prostomium is broader than it is long, and it has two pairs of eyes. The palps are united at the base and bent ventrally. The setae are exclusively compound, with short, unidentate, strongly hooked blades; simple setae are absent. The dorsal cirri resemble antennae, are as wide as the body, and are similar to the ventral cirri, which are conical. The parapodia have truncate setigerous lobes. The notopodium is reduced, presenting only a dorsal cirrus, while the neuropodium bears compound setae. The antennae are tapered, wrinkled, and not annulated. The pharynx features a very large dorsal tooth extending to setiger 4, and the proventriculus extends to setiger 11. This species is found in South Africa, specifically along the Cape coast, including Lamberts Bay in Cape Province.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Pionosyllis longocirrata
Expected_answer: Pionosyllis longocirrata Saint-Joseph, 1887 has a small, approximately 8 mm long, soft and very fragile body. The prostomium's details are not specified. It features only compound setae, which are very long, fine, with slender, bidentate blades. The terminal tooth is strong and hooked, while the secondary tooth is weak and directed toward the terminal tooth. Simple setae are absent. The anterior dorsal cirri are exceedingly long, with posterior dorsal cirri that are shorter but still more than twice the body width. The ventral cirri are large and triangular. The parapodia have long, setigerous lobes. The notopodium contains only very long dorsal cirri, whereas the neuropodium bears only compound setae. The antennae are smooth and extremely long. The short pharynx has an anterior tooth present. The proventriculus features about 30 rows of points. The species is found in the English Channel, Mediterranean, South Africa, and tropical regions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Spermosyllis capensis
Expected_answer: Spermosyllis capensis Day, 1953, has a body approximately 12 mm long with about 60 segments. The prostomium is broader than it is long, featuring a single median antenna near the front edge. The palps are large, tapered, transversely striated, and fused along their length. Starting from about setiger 12, the setae include a superior simple seta, one to three compound setae with long, knife-like blades, and five to eight compound falcigers with short blades. The secondary tooth of these falcigers is large, while the terminal tooth is tiny. The dorsal cirri are ovoid and found on all setigers, with ventral cirri present throughout. The parapodia have obliquely truncate lobes. The notopodium only bears the dorsal cirrus, while the neuropodium carries both simple and compound setae. The pharynx extends to setiger 6. The peristomium, a tentacular segment, is separate from the prostomium and partially fused to setiger 1. The proventriculus reaches setiger 9 and has about 25 rows of points. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa, specifically in Langebaan Lagoon and Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Anguillosyllis capensis
Expected_answer: Anguillosyllis capensis Day, 1963 is characterized by a minute, thread-like body measuring about 5 mm with approximately 30 segments. The body tapers at both ends, and each segment is roughly four times wider than it is long. The prostomium is broader than long, lacking eyes, with three tiny papilliform antennae. The large, tapered palps are fused halfway and extend forward as a rostrum. All setae are compound, long, and fine, with blades that are uniformly slender ending in a blunt apical tooth. The dorsal cirri are long and often coiled, while the ventral cirri are slender and distinct. The parapodia are large, featuring a setigerous lobe with a tapered, retractile dorsal projection. The notopodium is represented by a long, often coiled dorsal cirrus, and the neuropodium has a setigerous lobe with a ventral cirrus. The short, broad, straight pharynx extends to setiger 3, and is unarmed with no dorsal tooth. The peristomium, a distinct tentacular segment, bears one pair of papilliform tentacular cirri. The proventriculus is barrel-shaped, located from setigers 3 to 6, with about 30 rows of points. The species is found in South Africa, specifically around the Agulhas Bank and Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Exogone clavator
Expected_answer: Exogone clavator Ehlers, 1913 is characterized by a slender body about 4.5 mm long, with 40 to 50 segments. The prostomium is wider than it is long, featuring four eyes, short lateral antennae, and a long, club-shaped median antenna that arises between the eyes. Large, nearly fused palps are present. The setae include a superior simple seta with an obliquely truncated tip starting around setiger 10, which becomes more robust posteriorly. Inferior simple setae appear in the posterior segments. The anterior legs have two long, sword-shaped compound setae, which reduce to one and then are absent further back. There are roughly three compound setae with short, bidentate, chopper-shaped blades, each with a tiny terminal tooth and a larger secondary tooth. Dorsal cirri are ovoid and present on all segments, including setiger 2; ventral cirri are slightly smaller and also on all feet. Parapodia have truncate lobes, with a single aciculum that has a knobbed tip. The notopodium is reduced, lacking true notosetae. The neuropodium bears a lobe with both compound and simple setae. The pharynx spans about three segments and has an anterior dorsal tooth. The tentacular cirri on the peristomium are small and ovoid. The proventriculus extends over approximately 2.5 segments and contains around 25 rows of points. This species is found in Southern Africa, from South West Africa to Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Exogone normalis
Expected_answer: Exogone normalis Day, 1963 has a slender, smooth, pale body about 5 mm long with an undefined segment count. The prostomium is short, with 23 pairs of eyes, and the median antenna exceeds the prostomium, reaching the palpal base. Lateral antennae are short, roughly half the length of the median. Compound setae are uniform, with straight blades and pointed shaft-heads. The superior simple seta is blunt, needle-like from about setiger 10, and stouter posteriorly; the inferior simple seta appears on the last segments. Dorsal cirri are small, ovoid, absent on setiger 2; ventral cirri are longer than setiger lobes, projecting distally. Parapodia are small with low setigerous lobes; no distinct notopodium is present. The neuropodium bears both compound and simple setae. The pharynx extends to setiger 5 with a dorsal tooth. The peristomium is indistinct; tentacular cirri are tiny and papilliform, about half the size of dorsal cirri. The proventriculus reaches to setiger 10 with about 23 rows of points. Palps are large, fully fused, and longer than broad. This species is found off South Africas Agulhas Bank.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Exogone heterosetosa
Expected_answer: Exogone heterosetosa McIntosh, 1885 features a tiny, smooth body roughly 2 mm long with many segments. Its prostomium is wider than long, with two pairs of eyes; sometimes, anterior eye-specks are visible. The median antenna matches the prostomial length, while the lateral antennae are shorter. The setae include three types: the first is a superior simple seta with an obliquely truncated tip; the second is a superior compound seta with a swollen shaft-head and a short, triangular blade; and the third, around three compound setae, has short bidentate blades with a secondary tooth larger than the apex. Dorsal cirri are ovoid and absent from setiger 2, with ventral cirri present. The small parapodia have low setigerous lobes; the notopodium is not distinctly lobe-shaped, while the neuropodium bears both simple and compound setae. The peristomium is a distinct tentacular segment. The large palps are fused almost to their tips. Geographically, it is found in Subantarctic regions, Antarctica, Chile, and Tristan da Cunha, but not in southern Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Sphaerosyllis capensis
Expected_answer: Sphaerosyllis capensis Day, 1953, has a short body about 3 mm long with roughly 29 setigers and a lightly papillose surface. Its prostomium is wider than long, featuring two pairs of coalescent eyes and three long, piriform antennae on the anterior margin. The setae include superior simple setae with curved tips, compound setae with unidentate blades, and inferior simple setae in the posterior segments. Dorsal cirri are piriform and absent from setiger 2, while ventral cirri are digitiform. The parapodia have conical setigerous lobes with two apical papillae. The notopodium is reduced; the neuropodium bears simple and compound setae. The pharynx, with an anterior tooth, extends to setiger 2 and is surrounded by brownish glands. The peristomium is partially fused to the prostomium and has a single pair of tentacular cirri at eye level. The short proventriculus spans about two segments, with 1014 rows of points. The fused palps are bent ventrally. A notable feature is the spherical dorsal vesicle with fibrillar contents, present from approximately setiger 4 onward. This species is found in South Africa, specifically in the Cape Agulhas region.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Syllis anops
Expected_answer: Syllis anops Ehlers, 1897, has a slender body measuring 1525 mm with around 120 segments. Its prostomium is wider than it is long and lacks eyes. The setae consist of anterior compound setae with unequal blades and tiny bidentate tips; middle parapodia feature Langerhansia-type setae with long, slender blades; and inferior setae have typical unidentate blades. Acicula are robust with blunt tips. Dorsal cirri are roughly the same width as the body (~30 joints), while ventral cirri are short and located near distal setigerous lobes. The parapodia are characteristic of syllids, with a reduced notopodium and a neuropodium bearing both compound and modified setae. Antennae are short, similar in size, with 2530 joints. The pharynx contains an anterior tooth. The proventriculus extends over approximately 11 segments. Palps are fused at the base. Its distribution includes the Magellan region, Chatham Islands, and Cape of South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Sphaerosyllis erinaceus
Expected_answer: Sphaerosyllis erinaceus Claparede, 1863 has a short body measuring about 3 mm with approximately 30 segments. It is flattened and its surface is densely covered with adhesive papillae that extend onto the palps and parapodia. The prostomium is broader than long and features three pairs of eyes and three equal, flask-shaped antennaemedian antennae are positioned behind the lateral ones. Each foot has about five compound setae with unidentate blades; a superior simple seta with an oblique tip appears from setiger 68 onward. The tentacular and dorsal cirri are flask-shaped, slightly larger than the antennae, with dorsal cirri absent from setiger 2; ventral cirri are small and cylindrical. The small parapodia lack dorsal glands. The notopodium is reduced, while the neuropodium bears a setigerous lobe with both compound and simple setae. The pharynx has an anterior dorsal tooth and extends to setiger 3. The very short peristomium embraces the prostomium, with tentacular cirri emerging at eye level. The proventriculus extends to setiger 6 and has 1518 rows of points. The papillae on the palps are papillose. Geographically, this species is found in the Eastern Atlantic (from Ireland to France), South West Africa to the western Cape, as well as in the Arctic, NW Japan, and Kerguelen.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Sphaerosyllis suhlaevis
Expected_answer: Sphaerosyllis suhlaevis Ehlers, 1913 is characterized by a relatively large body, roughly 10 mm in length, with about 36 setigers. Its dorsal surface is smooth, and it lacks adhesive papillae. The prostomium is arched forward and features two pairs of eyes, with some eye-specks at the front. The antennae are flask-shaped, approximately as long as the prostomium. The compound setae have blades that are unidentate and vary in length, with a simple superior seta also present. Dorsal cirri are flask-shaped, becoming more elongated towards the back, but are absent from setiger 2. The ventral cirri are small and conical. Its parapodia are small, with setigerous lobes, and the notopodium is reduced. The neuropodium bears both compound and simple setae. The peristomium is short, wrapping around the prostomium, with lateral, smaller tentacular cirri. The palps are stout and mostly fused dorsally. This species is found in South Africa (False Bay) and Chile (42°S).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Exogonoides antennata
Expected_answer: Exogonoides antennata Day, 1963 features a very long, smooth, and slender body roughly 35 mm long and 0.5 mm wide, with over 200 segments. The front segments are short and crowded, while the rear segments are elongated. The prostomium is bluntly conical, with four eyes and three ovoid frontal antennae, with the median antenna positioned above the lateral ones. The anterior parapodia have compound setae with short, triangular, bidentate blades, whereas the posterior parapodia have simple setae with short shafts and bluntly triangular tips. Dorsal cirri are ovoid, compressed, and about the same size as the setigerous lobe, present on all setigers including setiger 2; ventral cirri are absent. The parapodia have conical setigerous lobes, with ventral cirri fused to the posterior margin of the lobes. The notopodium is reduced, and the neuropodium has a setigerous lobe bearing either compound or simple setae. The slender pharynx extends to setiger 6, is unarmed, and lacks a trepan. The short, distinct peristomium segment is equipped with one pair of small, ovoid tentacular cirri. The proventriculus is short, dark, weakly muscular, with about 15 rows of large, poorly defined points. The small ventral palps are partially fused. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa, on the Agulhas Bank, in tropical waters.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Autolytus pictus
Expected_answer: Autolytus pictus Ehlers, 1864 has a body length of 1025 mm, with paired dorsal red pigment rectangles that fade in alcohol. The small prostomium features three long antennae, with the median antenna being longer than the lateral ones, and the palps are not visible dorsally. The setae are compound with bidentate blades and shaft-heads that are denticulate. The tentacular cirri and the dorsal cirri of setiger 1 are very long, while the dorsal cirri on subsequent segments are shorter than the body width. The parapodia are of the normal autolytine type. The pharynx is S-shaped, with a trepan that has around 20 teeth, alternating between large and small. The tentacular segment of the peristomium has very long cirri. The proventriculus contains 5060 rows of points, and the nuchal epaulettes are indistinct, not reaching setiger 2. This species is found in the North Atlantic (from the English Channel to Madeira and Morocco), the Mediterranean, Angola, and southwestern Australia.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Autolytus maclearnus
Expected_answer: Autolytus maclearnus McIntosh, 1885 features a body length of 612 mm, dusky at the front and otherwise pale. Its prostomium is rounded, with four eyes, three long, wrinkled antennae, and palps that are slightly visible from above. It has four to five compound, bidentate setae, and posterior feet equipped with a single, pointed, simple seta located above. The dorsal cirri on setiger 1 are long, while those on subsequent segments are very short, about a quarter of the body width. The parapodia are of the typical autolytine type. The long, twisted pharynx has a weakly chitinised margin, is enclosed in a sheath with roughly 10 papillae, and bears many tiny, indistinct teeth. The tentacular segment near the mouth has long dorsal cirri resembling antennae, with much shorter ventral tentacular cirri. The proventriculus appears at setiger 4 and contains 2530 rows of points. Nuchal epaulettes are not clearly defined. This species is found in the Subantarctic region, including Chile, Kerguelen, and the Chatham Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Micronereides capensis
Expected_answer: Micronereides capensis Day, 1963 features a small, approximately 6 mm long body with 30 to 40 colorless segments. The prostomium is broad and nearly square, with eyes that are either indistinct or absent. It has paired, widely separated antennae and stout palpophores fully fused to the prostomium. The slender palpostyles are longer than the antennae. All setae are homogomph spinigers, with inferior neuropodial setae having shorter blades and shaft-heads tending toward hemigomph. Dorsal cirri are short, and ventral cirri are small. The first two setigers are uniramous, lacking notopodial lobes and notosetae, but retaining the dorsal cirrus. Later parapodia are biramous and uniform, with no notopodial lobes; the inferior lobes are elongated, exceeding the dorsal cirrus, and the notopodial lobes are absent. The neuropodium has a stout, conical, setigerous lobe with a very small inferior lobe and a small ventral cirrus. The proboscis has no paragnaths, and the jaws are paired, large, with seven teeth each. The peristomium contains two pairs of short tentacular cirri arranged 2+2 from two fused segments, with no anterior apodous segment. Its distribution includes the Agulhas Bank, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Unanereis macgregori
Expected_answer: Unanereis macgregori Day, 1962 is characterized by an elongate body approximately 60 mm in length with around 120 segments. The prostomium is oval, featuring a single slender median antenna, and the paired palps are long. The setae include anterior heterogomph and homogomph spinigers, alongside heterogomph falcigers with long blades. Posterior notosetae consist of homogomph spinigers and hemigomph falcigers with bidentate tips, while posterior neurosetae include both homogomph and heterogomph spinigers and falcigers. Dorsal cirri are very long anteriorly, with ventral cirri reduced posteriorly. The parapodia differ between anterior and posterior segments. Anterior notopodia have two lobes and a very long dorsal cirrus; posterior notopodia have a superior lobe forming the cirrophore of the dorsal cirrus. The neuropodia feature a setigerous lobe with a long presetal lip anteriorly; posterior neuropodia have an inferior lobe reduced to a ventral papilla on the setigerous lobe. The proboscis has a paragnath formula of I=0, II=12, III=5, IV=12, V=0, and a broad, fleshy lobe in segments VI-VII. The tentacular cirri on the peristomium are very long and slender. Its known distribution is in Madagascar, specifically Diego Suarez.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Dendronereis arborifera
Expected_answer: Dendronereis arborifera Peters, 1854 features a slender body, reaching up to approximately 85 mm, with pale coloration and red gills visible in life. The prostomium is deeply cleft between the antennae, with short palps fused to the divided prostomium. The setae consist solely of homogomph spinigers, with neuropodial blades shorter than notopodial ones. Dorsal cirri are tapered anteriorly, while ventral cirri are short. The parapodia include anterior branchiferous and differentiated posterior pairs. The notopodium features anterior feet with three lobes, branchiferous feet with a three-lobed notopodium, and posterior feet that are simplified and bilabiate. The neuropodium has anterior feet with four postsetal lobes, later developing one to two presetal lobes; branchiferous feet with setigerous lobes subdivided into six and later four lobes; and posterior neuropodia that are conical and bilabiate. The branchiae are bipinnate branchial filaments on dorsal cirri from approximately setiger 12 to 24. The proboscis lacks paragnaths and papillae. The tentacular segment of the peristomium has tentacular cirri that are indistinctly jointed distally. Geographically, this species is found in Mozambique, Madagascar, and eastern South Africa's mangrove habitats.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Laeonereis ankyloseta
Expected_answer: Laeonereis ankyloseta Day, 1957 features a body up to approximately 50 mm long, with anterior segments showing brown spots. The prostomium is as wide as it is long, featuring a median longitudinal groove. Notosetae homogomph spinigers are present throughout; neuropodial falcigers have long straight blades anteriorly and shorter ones posteriorly, with a terminal tendon. Posterior neuropodia have 13 enlarged, simple, hammer-shaped setae formed by fused blades. Dorsal cirri are elongated posteriorly, while ventral cirri are present. The parapodia are differentiated into anterior and posterior sections. The notopodium has three lobes throughout, with a well-developed intermediate lobe anteriorly and a reduced one posteriorly; the dorsal cirrus is slightly longer anteriorly and longer posteriorly. The neuropodium features a setigerous lobe with a long postsetal lip, and the posterior neuropodia carry modified simple setae. The proboscis has a smooth maxillary ring; area VI has a large, soft transverse lobe; areas VIIVIII contain a row of six soft papillae. The tentacular segments of the peristomium have short cirri. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa (from False Bay to Natal) and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Platynereis australis
Expected_answer: Platynereis australis Schmarda, 1861, reaches a body length of about 105 mm in subantarctic specimens and roughly 30 mm in South African ones. Its prostomium resembles that of P. dumerilii. The setae are similar to P. dumerilii, but without adult notopodial falcigers. The dorsal cirri are significantly longer on the posterior parapodia. Its parapodia are akin to those of P. dumerilii, showing regional differentiation towards the rear. Adult notopodia lack falcigers and have elongated posterior lobes. The neuropodium is comparable to P. dumerilii. Its range includes South West Africa, the Cape coast, and subantarctic areas.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Platynereis calodonta
Expected_answer: Platynereis calodonta Kinberg, 1866 has a body approximately 30 mm long and exhibits a greenish coloration. Its prostomium is elongated relative to its width, featuring swollen palps. The setae include few notopodial spinigers across all limbs; from about setiger 5 onwards, there are numerous notopodial falcigers with short, brown, strongly hooked blades attached by tendons. Neurosetae comprise spinigers and falcigers, with falcigers having a tendon at the tip of the blade. Dorsal cirri are long, especially on the posterior parapodia. The parapodia show regional differentiation: the notopodium in anterior limbs has two rounded lobes with a long dorsal cirrus, while posterior limbs have an enlarged superior lobe with a long dorsal cirrus and a smaller inferior lobe. The neuropodium is typical of the genus. The long tentacular cirri are notable. The proboscis has comb-like paragnaths that are strongly developed, with a distribution pattern typical of this genus. Its geographic range extends from False Bay to Natal, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Platynereis dumerilii
Expected_answer: Platynereis dumerilii Audouin & Milne-Edwards, 1833 is characterized by a body up to approximately 45 mm long, with a greenish hue and often a pale dorsal stripe. Its prostomium is longer than wide, featuring large, swollen palps. The setae include numerous notosetae spinigers and homogomph falcigers from mid-body onward, with blades that are elongated, sharply recurved, and ending in a terminal knob. Neurosetae consist of spinigers and falcigers, with the falciger blades recurved and supported by short tendons. Dorsal cirri are long and increase in length toward the posterior. The parapodia are regionally differentiated, with the notopodium bearing anterior feet that have two large, rounded lobes, a minute intermediate lobe, and a long dorsal cirrus; posterior feet have two conical lobes and a longer dorsal cirrus. The neuropodium is typical for the genus. Tentacular cirri are long, and the proboscis features comb-like paragnaths arranged in a typical generic pattern. Reproductive modifications in heteronereid form begin at setiger 15 in males and 18 in females. The species has a cosmopolitan distribution, ranging from South West Africa to Natal, and is very common along the South African coast.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Nereis granulata
Expected_answer: Nereis granulata Day, 1957 is characterized by a small body measuring approximately 26 mm with around 50 segments, featuring brown bands on setigers 23 and scattered brown spots on other segments. The prostomium is typical for its genus. Notopodial falcigers have straight, cone-shaped blades with light serration at the base, while neuropodial falcigers also have relatively straight blades. The dorsal cirri are elongated, longer towards the back. The parapodia are regionally differentiated, with the anterior notopodia having two lobes and a long dorsal cirrus, and the posterior notopodia are similar but with relatively longer dorsal cirri; posterior notopodia have 12 falcigers. The neuropodium is standard, with falcigers. The tentacular cirri are typical. The proboscis features minute, pale, granular paragnaths; Group I has a small patch (~6), Group II is wedge-shaped, Group III a small oval patch, Group IV wedge-shaped, Group V absent, Group VI a circle of about 6, and Groups VIIVIII a broad ventral band. The species is found in Mozambique, specifically on Inhaca Island (single record).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Nereis jacksoni
Expected_answer: Nereis jacksoni Kinberg, 1865, has a small, slender body measuring approximately 15-25 mm. The prostomium features a smooth anterior margin without a notch. Its setae include posterior notopodial falcigers with dark blades and 2-3 large teeth, and neuropodial falcigers with slightly curved blades. Dorsal cirri are elongated, longer towards the posterior. The parapodia are regionally differentiated. Notopodium of the anterior feet has two lobes and a longer dorsal cirrus; the superior lobe is small and reduced posteriorly. Anterior notosetae are homogomph spinigers, while posterior notopodia have 1-2 stout falcigers. The neuropodium contains heterogomph falcigers. Tentacular cirri are short. The proboscis features pale, minute paragnaths: Group I absent; Group II with a double row; Group III with an oval patch of 4-6 (sometimes absent); Group IV wedge-shaped; Group V absent; Group VI a small, compact group of 3-6; Groups VII-VIII with a single row of 7-8. Its distribution includes the Indo-West Pacific, Red Sea, South Africa (Cape, Natal), Mozambique, and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Neanthes trifasciata
Expected_answer: Neanthes trifasciata Grube, 1878 is characterized by a slender body measuring 1530 mm. The prostomium is notably long. The setae are homogomph falcigers with straight, elongated blades that are lightly serrated near the base. Dorsal cirri are elongated, slightly longer towards the posterior. The parapodia show regional differentiation, with the notopodium featuring anterior segments with two lobes and a slightly longer dorsal cirrus. The posterior segments are similar but with an expanded superior lobe; notosetae are spinigers throughout, with 12 homogomph falcigers appearing from mid-body onward. The neuropodium reflects a typical nereid condition. The tentacular cirri are long. The proboscis contains paragnaths arranged as follows: Group I 01; Group II in double rows; Group III as an oval patch of 612; Group IV as a long triangular group; Group V is absent; Group VI is a compact group of 39; and Groups VIIVIII form a single row of about eight, sometimes double in juveniles. This species is distributed across the Tropical Indo-west Pacific, including the Red Sea, Mozambique, Madagascar, and the Juan Fernandez Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Nereis persica
Expected_answer: Nereis persica Fauvel, 1911 is characterized by a body length of 1530 mm. The prostomium is broadly triangular. The setae include Notosetae spinigers in the front and falcigers at the back; neuropodial falcigers are curved. Dorsal cirri are long at the front and shorter at the back. The parapodia show differentiation between front and back. The notopodium's front legs have two lobes and a long dorsal cirrus, while the back legs have smaller, more slender lobes. Posterior notosetae consist of 12 dark homogomph falcigers with blades bearing 23 blunt teeth. Neuropodial falcigers have curved blades and a slight apical tendon. The proboscis features paragnaths in several groups: Group I 01; Group II double row; Group III with few scattered points; Group IV with 23 rows; Group V absent; Group VI a cluster of 610; and Groups VIIVIII as broad bands with large points at the front and finer points behind. The distribution includes the Red Sea, tropical Indo-West Pacific, South Africa (Cape, Natal), Mozambique, and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Nereis pelagica
Expected_answer: Nereis pelagica Linnaeus, 1758, has a body length of 60120 mm with 80120 segments. The prostomium is broad and inverted T-shaped, with large palps and short tentacular cirri. Its setae include notosetae spinigers and single posterior falcigers, along with neurosetae spinigers and falcigers. Dorsal cirri are longer than the notopodial lobes, while ventral cirri are present. The parapodia feature similar anterior and posterior feet. Notopodia have two nearly equal lobes, with a dorsal cirrus longer than the lobes. Posterior notosetae have homogomph spinigers and a single falciger with a short, smooth blade. Neuropodia resemble typical nereid structures, with neurosetae spinigers and falcigers. The proboscis contains paragnaths arranged in groups: I (23), II (oblique double row), III (oval patch), IV (wedge-shaped), V is absent, and VI (45 large points in cross-section). Groups VIIVIII have 12 irregular rows of large points, followed by rows of smaller points. Its geographic distribution includes the Arctic, the Atlantic coasts of Europe, the Mediterranean, Senegal, the Okhotsk Sea, the South Pacific, South Africa, as well as tropical regions like Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Neanthes unifasciata
Expected_answer: Neanthes unifasciata Willey, 1905 features a body length of 2030 mm and a distinctive brown transverse band on setiger 2. Its prostomium is relatively long and often has a brownish tint. The setae are neuropodial falcigers with short, hooked blades, attached at the tips by a clear tendon. The dorsal cirri are shorter than the notopodial lobes in the front but become relatively longer at the back, with ventral cirri present. The parapodia are distinguishable as anterior and posterior, with the notopodium being the anterior foot that has two lobes and a shorter dorsal cirrus, while the posterior foot has more pointed lobes and a longer superior lobe; notably, no notopodial falcigers are present. The neuropodium contains neuropodial falcigers. The long tentacular cirri are characteristic. The proboscis contains paragnaths arranged as follows: Group I with 16 in line; Group II with double rows; Group III with a small patch of 715; Group IV wedge-shaped; Group V with 01; Group VI rounded or rectangular groups of 38; and Groups VIIVIII with a single row of approximately 7. This species is distributed across the tropical IndoWest Pacific region, with rare records from Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Neanthes agulhana
Expected_answer: Neanthes agulhana Day, 1963 is characterized by a body length of approximately 20 mm, featuring a brown transverse band on setiger 2. The description of the prostomium is not provided. The setae are neuropodial falcigers with relatively straight blades, whose tips are attached by an indistinct tendon. Dorsally, the cirri slightly surpass the superior notopodial lobe, while ventral cirri are also present. The parapodia exhibit differentiation between anterior and posterior segments. The anterior notopodia have three lobes, with the smaller intermediate lobe; the posterior notopodia have two lobes. The dorsal cirrus is slightly longer than the superior lobe, and notopodial falcigers are absent. Neuropodial falcigers are present. The description of the tentacular cirri is not specified. The proboscis features paragnaths arranged as follows: Group I with 0; Group II with 8-9 in a double row; Group III with 5-6 in a crescent-shaped patch; Group IV with approximately 10 wedges; Group V with 0; Group VI with 2-4 in a line; Groups VIIVIII with 35 arranged in a single row. The species is distributed in the Agulhas Bank and Cape region, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Neanthes agnesiae
Expected_answer: Neanthes agnesiae Augener, 1918 has an ~80 mm body with 90 segments. The broad, inverted T-shaped prostomium has broad palps and short tentacular cirri. It has spinigerous setae only, no falcigers. Dorsal cirri are short anteriorly, reduced posteriorly; ventral cirri are present. Differentiated anterior, middle, and posterior parapodia with specific limb features. Notopodium has three lobes, short dorsal cirrus; middle and posterior feet have expanded lobes and small dorsal cirrus, respectively. Neuropodium is typical without falcigers. Proboscis paragnaths include several groups with specific arrangements, and it is found in South West Africa (Swakopmund), the type locality.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Alitta succinea
Expected_answer: Alitta succinea Leuckart, 1847, has a reddish-brown body measuring up to approximately 80 mm in length. Its prostomium is typical of the genus, with well-developed palps and visible tentacular cirri. The setae consist solely of spinigers in notosetae, while neurosetae are falcigers with long, straight blades that lack distinct terminal tendons. The dorsal cirri are short posteriorly, reduced, and positioned on enlarged, superior notopodial lobes; ventral cirri are present. Its parapodia have distinct anterior and posterior parts. The anterior notopodium features three lobes and a setal lip, whereas the posterior has a greatly enlarged, lamellate superior lobe, a short dorsal cirrus placed in a terminal notch, a reduced intermediate lobe, a pointed inferior lobe, and lacks notopodial falcigers. The neuropodium is well-developed and bears only falcigers. The proboscis includes Paragnaths arranged in groups: I with one, II in double rows, III with scattered points, IV wedge-shaped, V with three to five, VI with clusters of 812, and VIIVIII as a broad band of about four irregular rows. It is widely distributed and considered cosmopolitan in temperate and subtropical waters.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ceratonereis mirabilis
Expected_answer: Ceratonereis mirabilis Kinberg, 1866 is approximately 30 mm long, with anterior segments showing vague brown transverse bars. Its dorsum is finely papillose, especially towards the rear. The prostomium features a deep cleft between slender antennae, with elongated palps and very long tentacular cirri. Notosetae in the posterior segments include 1-2 homogomph falcigers with long, slightly curved, spinulose blades, while neurosetae have heterogomph falcigers with very long, spinulose blades and hooked tips. The dorsal cirri are extremely long, and ventral cirri are present. The parapodia are similar in both anterior and posterior parts. The notopodium in the anterior feet has two lobes a slender superior lobe, sometimes appearing as a ventral branch of the dorsal cirrus while the posterior feet feature a further reduced superior lobe. The dorsal cirri are very long. The neuropodium is well developed, bearing falcigers. The proboscis includes Group I with no paragnaths, Group II with wedge-shaped paragnaths, a few scattered points in Group III, and wedge-shaped paragnaths again in Group IV. Distribution includes Brazil, the Gulf of Mexico, the Red Sea, and the Indo-West Pacific to Japan.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ceratonereis costae
Expected_answer: Ceratonereis costae Grube, 1840, features a body up to approximately 80 mm in length. The prostomium is as broad as it is long, with tentacular cirri of moderate length. Notosetae are only spinigers, while neuropodial setae include a few heterogomph falcigers with long blades; towards the posterior, two falcigers are enlarged and often lose their blades. The dorsal cirri are slightly longer than the notopodial lobes in the anterior, elongating posteriorly, with ventral cirri present. The parapodia have two notopodial lobes and slightly elongated dorsal cirri at the front; middle parapodia (around setigers 717) feature a small but distinct intermediate notopodial lobe; posterior parapodia have all lobes elongated and more pointed. The notopodium has two lobes in the front, with a transient intermediate lobe in the mid-body; no notopodial falcigers are present. The neuropodium consists of a setigerous lobe with a long presetal lip and a stout postsetal lip, with posterior neuropodia elongated. The proboscis has paragnaths arranged in groups: Group I with 01, Group II in double rows, Group III with three in a triangular group, and Group IV wedge-shaped. Its distribution includes the North Atlantic, Mediterranean, Red Sea, Indo-West Pacific, and records from Mozambique and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ceratonereis pachychaeta
Expected_answer: Ceratonereis pachychaeta Fauvel, 1918: The body reaches up to approximately 45 mm in length. The prostomium has a hexagonal shape, with moderately long tentacular cirri. The setae consist solely of notosetae spinigers; neuropodial falcigers are straight or slightly convex at the front and more hooked at the back, with a distinct tendon. The posterior feet feature two to three large falcigers with blades partly fused to their shafts. Dorsal cirri are longer than the anterior notopodial lobes, and ventral cirri are present. The parapodia exhibit anterior segments with three roughly equal notopodial lobes and an elongated dorsal cirrus. Posterior parapodia show diverging notopodia and neuropodia, with the notopodial setigerous lobe reduced or vestigial, while the other lobes are long and pointed. The notopodium has three lobes anteriorly, but the setigerous lobe is reduced posteriorly with no falcigers present. The neuropodium is well developed, with modified falcigers in the posterior neuropodia. The proboscis contains paragnaths arranged as follows: Group I with 0-1; Group II with one to two rows of 410; Group III with 23 in line; and Group IV with 46 in a triangular group. The species is found in the Red Sea and Indo-West Pacific regions and has been recorded from Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ceratonereis erythraeensis
Expected_answer: Ceratonereis erythraeensis Fauvel, 1918 has a slender body up to approximately 160 mm in length. The prostomium is wider than it is long, with short antennae and fairly long tentacular cirri. It features only notosetae spinigers, while the neuropodial falcigers have short blades without tendons. The posterior feet carry one to two enlarged falcigers with blades fused to their shafts, forming simple hooks. Dorsal cirri are short and about the same size as the notopodial lobes; ventral cirri are also present. The anterior parapodia have two notopodial lobes and a short dorsal cirrus of similar length, with posterior parapodia resembling the anterior but with more pointed lobes. The notopodium consists of two lobes, and notopodial falcigers are absent. The neuropodium is well-developed; posterior neuropodia contain modified falcigers. The proboscis has elongate, conical paragnaths: Group I with 26; Group II with around 10 in double rows; Group III with approximately 18 in transverse patches; and Group IV wedge-shaped groups with 1215. This species is found in the Indian Ocean (Djibouti, Madagascar, western Australia) and Japan.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Leonnates decipiens
Expected_answer: Leonnates decipiens Fauvel, 1929 has a stout body up to ~300 mm long with ~90 segments. Its prostomium is broader than long, with stout palps as long as antennae. Notosetae are homogomph spinigers only; neurosetae include homogomph spinigers and falcigers, which have convex, spinous blades and truncated tips. Dorsal cirri are moderate, similar in size to notopodial lobes; ventral cirri are present. Anterior parapodia feature three notopodial lobes and dorsal cirrus, with neuropodia, setigerous lobes, and short presetal lips. Posterior parapodia have longer superior notopodial lobes, elongated postsetal lips, and slender inferior lobes. The notopodium has three anterior lobes, with an elongated superior lobe; notopodial falcigers are absent. The neuropodium has a well-developed setigerous lobe and elongated postsetal lips. The proboscis has a basal ring with soft papillae; Group V is absent; VI has a large square papilla; VIIVIII have a single row. Maxillary ring contains chitinous paragnaths: Group I absent, II oblique, III transverse, IV triangular. Found in Senegal, Congo, Suez region, Gulf of Manaar, and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Pseudonereis variegata
Expected_answer: Pseudonereis variegata Grube, 1857: The body is large and robust, reaching up to about 150 mm in length and 8 mm in width. It has a dark green coloration, with ovigerous females appearing bluish. The prostomium is described as a broad inverted T shape, complemented by large, bulbous palps. The setae consist solely of homogomph spinigers in the notosetae, while the neuropodial falcigers have short, faintly hooked blades. Dorsal cirri are longer than the notopodial lobes at the front, becoming reduced toward the back; ventral cirri are present. The anterior parapodia feature two rounded notopodial lobes and longer dorsal cirri, whereas the posterior parapodia have an enlarged, flattened, lamellate superior notopodial lobe with small, terminal dorsal cirri. The notopodium comprises two lobes anteriorly; the superior lobe is expanded and lamellate posteriorly, with no falcigers present. The neuropodium has a well-developed setigerous lobe and stout neuropodial falcigers. The proboscis contains several groups: Group I has 01, Group II has a double row of 1215, Group III has three comb-like rows of 1224, Group IV has a wedge of 1520, with a single paragnath in Group V, a single large transverse bar in Group VI, and 23 irregular rows in Groups VIIVIII; paragnaths in Groups IIIV are comb-like and not basally fused. Its distribution is circumtropical, ranging from South West Africa to Mozambique, and it is abundant on rocky shores under algae and barnacles.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Perinereis vancaurica
Expected_answer: Perinereis vancaurica Ehlers, 1868 is described as having a body length of up to approximately 80 mm. Its prostomium is broadly triangular with tapered antennae and short tentacular cirri. The setae include notosetae homogomph spinigers, while the neuropodial falcigers are heterogomph with straight blades. Dorsal cirri are short and roughly equal in length to the notopodial lobes, with ventral cirri present.
