The anterior parapodia feature two notopodial lobes and a short dorsal cirrus that matches the lobe length; posterior parapodia are similar but with slightly longer lobes. The notopodium consists of two lobes with homogomph spinigers possessing short blades; falcigers are absent. The neuropodium has an inferior lobe that is short anteriorly, with heterogomph falcigers that have very straight blades. The proboscis is organized into several groups: Group I with 12; Group II with two curved rows; Group III forming a square; Group IV a triangular field of numerous points; Group V three large points arranged in a triangle; Group VI two narrow transverse bars; and Groups VIIVIII with 23 irregular rows. Its distribution includes the Red Sea and Indo-west Pacific regions, with a single record from Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Perinereis capensis
Expected_answer: Perinereis capensis Kinberg, 1866, has a body that's brown at the front, reaching up to about 70 mm in length. The prostomium features a broad inverted T shape, with large, compressed palpophores, each ending in a small terminal button. Antennae are tapered, and tentacular cirri are fairly short. The setae include homogomph spinigers for notosetae, while neurosetae consist of homogomph and heterogomph spinigers, plus heterogomph falcigers with nearly straight tips. The dorsal cirri are long, originating from the upper notopodial lobe, and ventral cirri are present. The parapodia of the anterior segments have two to three notopodial lobes, with the intermediate lobe fused to the inferior lobe. Posterior parapodia have an enlarged base of the superior notopodial lobe. The superior notopodium bears a dorsal cirrus, approximately twice the length of the superior lobe at the front, with only homogomph spinigers. The neuropodium features a setigerous lobe with a short, pointed postsetal projection throughout, and neurosetae include spinigers and falcigers. The proboscis has several groups: Group I with 23 in a row; Group II with a wedge of 1215; Group III oval with about 10; Group IV triangular with about 15; Group V absent; Group VI as a large transverse bar; and Groups VIIVIII with two irregular rows of large and small points. Geographically, this species is found in the Tropical Indian Ocean, including Senegal and South Africa from False Bay to Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Perinereis cultrifera
Expected_answer: Perinereis cultrifera Grube, 1840, features a large body up to about 250 mm with approximately 125 segments. The prostomium is broadly triangular, with large palps and long, slender tentacular cirri. The setae include neuropodial falcigers with fairly straight blades, while notopodial falcigers are absent. Dorsal cirri are short and slightly increase in length towards the back, and ventral cirri are present. The anterior parapodia have two notopodial lobes, with posterior parapodia resembling the anterior but with more pointed lobes. Notopodia have two lobes throughout, with short dorsal cirri in the front and little change toward the back; they bear only notosetae spinigers. Neuropodia have a simple setigerous lobe with falcigers present. The proboscis features several groups: Group I with 13 large points aligned, Group II with points in a triangle, Group III as an oval patch, Group IV wedge-shaped, Group V with three large points in a triangle, Group VI as a transverse bar, and Groups VIIVIII with two to three rows of equal-sized points. The species is distributed in the NE Atlantic, Mediterranean, tropical Indo-west-Pacific, from South Africa (Cape to Natal), and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Aglaophamus dibranchis
Expected_answer: Aglaophamus dibranchis Grube, 1877, is about 25 mm long. The prostomium is pentagonal with a straight anterior margin, and it has well-developed, tapered antennae that are roughly equal in size. Eyes are visible through the body wall. The anterior notosetae consist of laddered capillaries, while the posterior notosetae are long, flattened capillaries, with forked setae present towards the rear. The dorsal cirrus on the first setiger is well developed, and branchial cirri appear from setiger 4 onwards. The parapodia are biramous with strongly divergent rami and pointed setigerous lobes. The notopodium has a small, anterior presetal lamella, with a larger postsetal lamella; middle feet have a postsetal lamella projecting dorsally, whereas posterior feet have a reduced postsetal lamella, barely exceeding the acicular lobe. The neuropodium shows anterior feet with three lamellaean anterior auricular, a superior tongue-like, and a postsetal auricularwhile middle feet feature an elongated, strap-like superior lamella. The posterior feet have reduced lamellae, with the superior lamella lost. Branchiae are cirriform, originating from setiger 4, and may be straight or involute, each with a slender notopodial cirrus at the base. The proboscis has fourteen rows of 45 papillae each, with a single elongated median dorsal papilla. The jaws are tetrahedral and chitinous. Geographically, this species is found in the tropical Indian Ocean, including Natal, South Africa, and possibly in New Zealand and the Campbell Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Aglaophamus lyrochaeta
Expected_answer: Aglaophamus lyrochaeta Fauvel, 1902, has a body about 30 mm long. Its prostomium is pentagonal with a straight front edge, and it lacks eyes. The setae include a front fan of ladder-like capillaries and a rear fan of long-bladed capillaries; both rami have forked setae. Notopodial cirri are located at the base of the branchiae, varying from short to very long. The parapodia are biramous, featuring prominent lamellae at the front that diminish toward the back. The anterior segment of the notopodium has rounded presetal lamellae and larger, circular postsetal lamellae, both exceeding the setigerous lobe, while the posterior segment has smaller lamellae shorter than the lobes. The neuropodiums front feet have oval presetal lamellae, blade-like upper lamellae, and large, circular postsetal lamellae; the rear feet have reduced lamellae, without the superior lamella. Branchiae start from setigers 4 or 5, are involute, and each bears a notopodial cirrus at the base; their length varies among sources. The proboscis features fourteen rows of 45 papillae each, with one enlarged median dorsal papilla. This species is distributed in Morocco, Congo (Brazzaville), and the Persian Gulf.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Aglaophamus macroura
Expected_answer: Aglaophamus macroura Schmarda, 1861: Large body (~150 mm); subquadrate prostomium; no eyes; unequal antennae, with second longer and ventro-lateral. Setae include anterior laddered capillaries and a posterior fan of long, flattened capillaries. Ventral cirri are blade-like; dorsal cirri near branchiae. Biramous parapodia with setigerous lobes and acicula. Notopodium has a bilobed presetal lamella; postsetal lamella large, bicornuate, with a foliaceous process; dorsal cirrus absent on first foot, blade-like on branchiferous feet. Neuropodium also has a bilobed presetal lamella; postsetal large, bicornuate, with a ligulate main lobe. Branchiae from setigers 2-4, involute, increasing in size to setiger 20, then decreasing, each with a dorsal cirrus. Proboscis has 22 rows of large papillae distally, 14 rows of smaller papillae proximally. Distribution includes Subantarctic, Chile, Antarctica, South Africa (Cape).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Nephtys capensis
Expected_answer: Nephtys capensis Day, 1953 is described as having a body about 60 mm long. The prostomium is pentagonal and slightly arched at the front, with no eyes. The posterior antennae are slightly shorter than the anterior pair. The setae feature an anterior fan of ladder-like capillaries and a posterior fan of many very long capillaries with spinulose edges, along with a few shorter, coarse-toothed geniculate setae. Ventral cirri on the first foot are elongated and as long as the antennae, while dorsal cirri are absent on the first foot. The parapodia are always biramous. The notopodium is conical, with a small, entire presetal lamella and a large, rounded postsetal lamella. The neuropodium is also conical, with a small presetal lamella that has a slightly raised upper edge, and a large, rounded postsetal lamella that extends well beyond the setigerous lobe. From setiger 4 onward, branchiae are present; the anterior branchiae are rectangular and compressed, and the posterior branchiae are cirriform and recurved, especially in larger specimens. The proboscis has 22 rows of six papillae each, with one larger median dorsal papilla. Distribution includes South Africa, along the Cape and Natal coasts.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Nephtys paradoxa
Expected_answer: Nephtys paradoxa Malmgren, 1874 is characterized by a large body, approximately 150 mm long. The prostomium ranges from straight to slightly concave at the front, with indistinct eyes or two eyes present. The posterior antennae are larger than the anterior pair. The setae include a fan of laddered capillaries at the front and a fan of long, flattened capillaries at the back, featuring transverse rows of fine teeth on one edge. The ventral cirrus on the first foot is stout and conical, while the dorsal cirrus is reduced to a low papilla. The parapodia are biramous, with divergent rami. The notopodium has a broadly rounded setigerous lobe at the front, which becomes more pointed behind, with rudimentary anterior lamellae and small, rounded posterior lamellae that barely extend beyond the setigerous lobe. The neuropodium's setigerous lobe is conical at the front, tapering to a point posteriorly, with rudimentary anterior lamellae and small, rounded posterior lamellae. The branchiae start from setigers 810, with anterior ones being cirriform and recurved, featuring small notopodial cirri at the base; middle branchiae are flattened or lamellar, decreasing and disappearing in posterior segments. The proboscis has 22 rows of papillae, each with 46 papillae, including an enlarged median dorsal papilla. Geographically, it is found in the North Atlantic, Arctic, Bering Sea, and north-west Japan, though records from southern Africa are doubtful.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Nephtys ambrizettana
Expected_answer: Nephtys ambrizettana Augener, 1918 is characterized by a small body measuring about 6.5 mm with around 42 segments. The prostomium is as broad as it is long, with slender antennae and uncertain eye-spots. The setae include an anterior fan of laddered capillaries and a posterior fan of long, finely serrated setae on the convex margin. The ventral cirrus on setiger 1 exceeds the length of the setigerous lobe, while the dorsal cirrus is similar; subsequent segments have small ventral cirri. Parapodia are poorly developed throughout the species. The notopodium lacks cirri, branchiae, and has rudimentary or absent presetal lamellae; postsetal lamellae are present but barely extend beyond the setigerous lobes. The neuropodium features conical setigerous lobes, with rudimentary or absent presetal lamellae, and small postsetal lamellae. The proboscis is not described. This species is found in Angola and has not been recorded in South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera rouxi
Expected_answer: Glycera rouxi Audouin & Milne-Edwards, 1833 features an elongate, cylindrical body measuring 100150 mm. Its prostomium is conical and tapered, with 1012 indistinct rings. The dorsal cirrus is ovoid and basally attached, while the ventral cirrus is long, pointed, and directed ventrally. The parapodia are biramous, with equal pointed presetal lobes and shorter postsetal lobes. The notopodium's postsetal lobe is roughly equal to the neuropodium's in the middle segments, with the superior postsetal lobe elongate and pointed posteriorly. The neuropodium has a rounded inferior postsetal lobe, shorter at the posterior. The retractile branchiae consist of a single digitiform lobe per parapodium, emerging from the anterior face starting around setiger 20. The jaws have supports with one well-developed prong, and a second prong reduced to a triangular basal projection without a notch. The eversible proboscis is covered with numerous papillae, mostly smooth and conical, with some globular forms. Its distribution includes the Eastern Atlantic (from Norway to Senegal), the Mediterranean, the tropical Indian Ocean, and Japan.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Goniada emerita
Expected_answer: Goniada emerita Audouin & Milne-Edwards, 1833 has a body that is elongated and tapered at both ends, measuring up to approximately 360 mm. In alcohol, its color is iridescent brown. The prostomium is long and conical, featuring 810 annulations, with four short antennae and no eyes. The setae include the absence of anterior notosetae, blunt posterior notopodial acicular setae, and spinigerous neurosetae. The cirri are dorsal, tapered, basally flattened anteriorly and triangular posteriorly, with long, triangular ventral cirri. The parapodia in the anterior region have 6070 uniramous segments, while the posterior region is biramous. The notopodium in the anterior lacks notosetae, whereas the posterior has a triangular dorsal cirrus, a similar inferior lobe, and 23 simple, blunt acicular setae between lobes. The neuropodium is large, with two presetal lobes united at the base and a single postsetal lobe with an expanded base and a pointed tip. The jaws are macrognaths with four teeth, and micrognaths with about 30 dorsal and 15 ventral teeth. The eversible proboscis has small, rounded papillae, each with a curved flange around a central pore and groove, and exhibits 1217 chevrons on each side at the base. Its distribution includes the North Atlantic (from Scotland to Morocco), the Mediterranean, the tropical Indian Ocean, and the Chatham Islands (New Zealand).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Goniada maculata
Expected_answer: Goniada maculata Oersted, 1843 is characterized by an elongate body measuring 50100 mm, with brown markings. The front part is uniramous, while the rear is biramous. The prostomium is conical, featuring 810 bands, and lacks eyes. The setae include absent anterior notosetae, capillary posterior notosetae, and spinigerous compound neurosetae. Dorsal cirri are blade-shaped at the front, with ventral cirri varying from blade-shaped to digitiform. The parapodia have 3540 uniramous segments in the front and biramous segments towards the rear. The notopodium in the front segments bears no notosetae, whereas the rear segments have dorsal cirri and a lobed setigerous lobe with capillary notosetae. The neuropodiums anterior feet have fused pre- and postsetal lips early on, later dividing into two presetal and one postsetal lobe; the posterior feet feature two finger-like presetal lobes and a blunt triangular postsetal lobe. The jaws comprise a dorsal arc of four micrognaths, a ventral arc of three micrognaths, and paired ventro-lateral macrognaths with 48 teeth. The proboscis has 711 chevrons, densely covered with low cordate papillae. Its distribution spans the Arctic, North Atlantic (from Norway to the English Channel and North Carolina), North Pacific (from Alaska to Japan), and possibly the Persian Gulf.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Goniadella gracilis
Expected_answer: Goniadella gracilis Verrill, 1873. The body is thread-like, up to ~20 mm, with an anterior uniramous region and a posterior biramous region. The prostomium has eight annulations; one pair of eyes in the basal ring, sometimes also in the terminal ring; and four slender, biarticulate antennae. The setae are described as anterior region with 35 spinigers and 24 falcigers; posterior region with similar neurosetae plus blunt acicular notosetae; spinigers with tapering blades, falcigers with short blades. The cirri are described as dorsal cirri pointed; ventral cirri triangular. The parapodia are described as anterior region with 2830 biannulate, uniramous segments; posterior region biramous. The notopodium is described as absent in the anterior region; posterior region with a notopodium corresponding to the dorsal cirrus, bearing 13 straight, blunt, acicular notosetae. The neuropodium is described as a setigerous lobe elongate; presetal projection long and fused anteriorly to a shorter postsetal lobe; similar structure posteriorly. The jaws are described as macrognaths with four teeth; micrognaths three ventrally and ~12 dorsally in a semicircle. The proboscis is described as with 2530 basal chevrons; papillae uniform, broadly conical, obliquely truncate. The geographical distribution is described as the Atlantic coast of the U.S.A.; recorded from the Cape region of South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Goniadopsis incerta
Expected_answer: Goniadopsis incerta Fauvel, 1932 features a body approximately 50 mm long, tapering at both ends, with distinct anterior, middle, and posterior regions. The prostomium has about 10 annulations. The setae include anterior neuropodia with falcigers, middle neuropodia with spinigers, and posterior notopodia with acicular notosetae, while the neuropodia have spinigers. Dorsal cirri are lamellar and flattened in the front, tapering towards the middle; ventral cirri are cirriform in the front, very long in the middle, and triangular at the back. The parapodia are uniramous in the front and middle parts, biramous in the rear. The notopodium is absent in the front and middle, but in the back has one presetal and two triangular postsetal lobes carrying acicular notosetae with faint spoon-shaped tips. The neuropodium has two presetal and one postsetal lobe with falcigerous setae in the front, two conical presetal and one postsetal lobes with spinigers in the middle, and two presetal with one triangular postsetal lobes bearing spinigers in the rear. The jaws consist of a dorsal arc with about 14 macrognaths, each with four teeth, and a ventral arc with roughly 20 micrognaths. The proboscis is covered with small spherical papillae. Geographically, it is found in Burmas deep waters and has been recorded off the Cape of South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Goniadopsis maskallensis
Expected_answer: Goniadopsis maskallensis Gravier, 1904. The body is slender, up to ~75 mm, tapered at both ends, and divided into anterior, middle, and posterior regions. The prostomium has ~10 annulations; the antennae are relatively long. The setae are anterior neuropodia with falcigers; middle neuropodia with spinigers; posterior notopodia with acicular, spoon-tipped setae; posterior neuropodia with spinigers. The cirri are dorsal, flattened in the anterior and middle regions; ventral, larger than the setigerous lobe anteriorly, smaller and rounded in the middle region, and short posteriorly. The parapodia are uniramous in the anterior and middle regions; biramous in the posterior region. The notopodium is absent in the anterior and middle regions; the posterior region has two blunt lobes bearing 13 stout, acicular notosetae with elongate, spoon-shaped tips. The neuropodium is anterior region with a single presetal and a single postsetal lobe bearing falcigers; middle region with presetal and postsetal lobes bearing spinigers; posterior region with longer presetal and shorter postsetal lobes bearing spinigerous compound setae. The jaws are macrognaths with four teeth; 13 dorsal micrognaths; 9 ventral micrognaths. The proboscis is covered with subspherical papillae. The geographical distribution is the Red Sea; recorded from Natal, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycinde kameruniana
Expected_answer: Glycinde kameruniana Augener, 1918, is characterized by a small, pale body measuring approximately 30 to 40 mm, with the body divided into anterior uniramous and posterior biramous regions. The prostomium features eight annulations and a pair of eyes embedded in a basal ring. The setae include anterior and posterior neurosetae, which are compound spinigers, and stout acicular notosetae in the posterior. Dorsal cirri are strap-like, anteriorly prominent and reduced posteriorly, while ventral cirri resemble anterior dorsal cirri but are shorter posteriorly. The anterior parapodium comprises 21 uniramous segments, with the posterior parapodium being biramous. The notopodium's anterior region lacks a dorsal cirrus, which is strap-like and laterally broadened (setigers 1520), and the posterior region has a small dorsal cirrus, a minutely bilabiate setigerous lobe, and 23 acicular notosetae with a blunt hooked apex and pointed guard. The neuropodium's anterior region has a single tapering presetal lobe and a subequal postsetal lobe, while the posterior region is similar but with a longer presetal lobe. The jaws consist of ventral macrognaths with four teeth and a dorsal arc of 45 micrognaths. The proboscis has five longitudinal bands of papillae. Geographically, this species is found in Tropical West Africa, recorded from South West Africa and the Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycinde capensis
Expected_answer: Glycinde capensis Day, 1960, is characterized by a yellowish-brown body up to 40 mm long with approximately 112 segments. The prostomium has 810 annulations and two pairs of eyes, one basal and one terminal. Its setae include acicular notosetae with blunt, hooked tips and pointed guards, along with compound spinigers throughout the neurosetae. The dorsal cirri are strap-like anteriorly and flattened posteriorly, and the ventral cirri resemble the dorsal cirri in the anterior region. The body is divided into an anterior uniramous region and a posterior biramous region; the anterior segment has 2830 segments, each with a parapodium bearing a strap-like dorsal cirrus, a single tapered setigerous lobe formed by fused pre- and postsetal lobes, and a ventral cirrus similar to the dorsal. From about setiger 20 onward, the dorsal cirrus expands inferiorly at its base. The posterior region features biramous parapodia, with notopodia bearing flattened dorsal cirri and a setigerous lobe with a distinct apical notch, and neuropodia resembling the anterior setigerous lobes. The proboscis has five longitudinal bands of papillae, two macrognaths each with five teeth, and a dorsal arc of 1525 micrognaths. Its distribution is limited to southern Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Boccardia ligerica
Expected_answer: Boccardia ligerica Ferronière, 1898 is described with a body approximately 25 mm long. The prostomium has a distinct notched anterior margin, a median keel extending to setiger 2, and four eyes. The setae on the fifth setiger feature enlarged, blunt hooks. Bidentate hooded hooks appear in the neuropodium starting from setiger 7. No specialized notosetae are present in the posterior segments. Notosetae are present on setiger 1. Branchiae begin on setiger 2, are absent on setiger 5, and reappear from setiger 6, continuing up to about setiger 30. The species is found in France (estuarine environments), with a doubtful record from South Africa in tropical conditions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Boccardia polybranchia
Expected_answer: Boccardia polybranchia Haswell, 1885 is characterized by a relatively large body for its genus, reaching up to 25 mm in length with about 80 segments. The prostomium features a distinctly notched anterior margin outlined in black, with a median keel extending posteriorly to setiger 2. Eye spots vary from none to about ten. The setae include setiger 5, which has two types of enlarged hooks: an anterior row of expanded, truncate hooks with dense fibrils, and a posterior row of simple hooks. Bidentate hooded hooks are found in the neuropodium from setiger 7 onward, and there are no specialized notosetae in the posterior segments. Notosetae are absent on setiger 1. The pygidium is small with a concave posterior margin. Branchiae are fused to the dorsal lamellae, present on setigers 24, absent on setiger 5, then reappearing and continuing to about the middle of the body. The antennae and tentacular cirri are not described as differentiated in the available material. The species is widely distributed, recorded from the English Channel, Bay of Biscay, Mediterranean, Brazil, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Subantarctic regions (Magellan area, Kerguelen, Macquarie Islands), and southern Africa (South West Africa and the Cape).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Boccardia pseudonatrix
Expected_answer: Boccardia pseudonatrix Day, 1961 is characterized by a small body approximately 10 mm in length with about 70 segments. The prostomium is bilobed, featuring a posterior keel extending to setiger 2 and two eye spots. The setae description notes that setiger 5 lacks notosetae and displays two types of enlarged hooks: a first row with three blunt conical hooks partially encircled by a raised margin, and a second row with four simple curved hooks. From setiger 7 onward, bidentate hooded hooks are present in the neuropodium, with no specialized posterior notosetae. The first setiger has a well-developed notopodium with several notosetae. The pygidium is very small. Branchiae are present on setigers 24 and 6, continuing on subsequent segments up to about setiger 40. The antennae and tentacular cirri are not differentiated in the available material. Geographically, this species is known only from the Knysna Estuary in South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Polydora capensis
Expected_answer: Polydora capensis Day, 1955 is characterized by a body length of up to 20 mm consisting of about 100 segments, typically boring into living gastropod shells. The prostomium features an unnotched anterior margin, a posterior keel extending to setiger 3, and paired lateral supporting lobes on the buccal segment. Setae include enlarged, blunt hooks on setiger 5, neuropodial hooks from setiger 7 that are hooded, bidentate, and range from three to five anteriorly, while posterior hooks are unhooded, unidentate, and reduced to two or three. Posterior notosetae comprise straight spines and capillaries. Notosetae are present on setiger 1. The pygidium is small. Branchiae are found from setiger 7 to setiger 37. The available material does not differentiate antennae and tentacular cirri. Geographically, this species is recorded from the Cape region of South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Polydora armata
Expected_answer: Polydora armata Langerhans, 1880, is characterized by a small body, approximately 5 mm in length, with 2445 segments. Its prostomium features a bilobed anterior margin and a dorsal posterior ridge extending to setiger 2, with no eyes. The setae on setiger 5 include two to three enlarged, bluntly hooked setae with stout hoods, and from setiger 7 onward, neuropodial bidentate hooded hooks, three to four in number, are present. Posterior notosetae consist of eight to twelve stout spines that form a cone shape when retracted and a funnel when everted. Notosetae are present on setiger 1, with two to three on each side. Branchiae are present from setiger 7 to setiger 14. The antennae and tentacular cirri are not differentiated. Its distribution includes the North Atlantic (from the English Channel to Morocco and Madeira), Gulf of Mexico, Mediterranean, Ceylon, and the North Pacific (Japan).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Polydora flava
Expected_answer: Polydora flava Claparede, 1870 is characterized by a large body, reaching up to 45 mm in length with around 150 segments. The prostomium has an anterior margin that is notched, and a posterior ridge extending to setiger 2; it lacks eyes. The setae on setiger 5 feature enlarged hooks with curved, blunt tips that are flattened on the concave side, accompanied by fine, straight, spear-shaped capillaries. From setiger 7 onward, neuropodial bidentate hooded hooks are present, with three to four per parapodium. Posterior notopodia contain packets of very fine, needle-like setae near the bases of capillaries. Few notosetae are found on setiger 1. Branchiae are present from setigers 7 to 9 and extend beyond the mid-body. The antennae and tentacular cirri are not differentiated. The species is distributed across the English Channel, the Mediterranean, Ceylon, Sumatra, Japan, the northern Pacific, southern Africa, and tropical regions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Polydora caeca
Expected_answer: Polydora caeca Oersted, 1843 features a body up to 40 mm long with approximately 130 segments. Its prostomium has a deeply notched anterior margin and a dorsal ridge extending posteriorly to setiger 2, with either four eyes or none. Setiger 5 includes two specialized series: a row of fine hastate setae and an oblique row of stout hooks excavated on the concave side. From setiger 7 onward, bidentate hooded neuropodial hooks are present. Posterior notopodia have three to four stout, straight spines and capillaries. The notosetae on setiger 1 are few. The pygidium is saucer-shaped with a dorsal notch. Branchiae start from setigers 79, extending beyond the mid-body. Antennae and tentacular cirri are not differentiated. Its distribution includes the Arctic, North Atlantic from Greenland to North Carolina, the English Channel to Morocco, the Mediterranean, the tropical Indian Ocean, and southern Africa (Natal, Mozambique).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Polydora ciliata
Expected_answer: Polydora ciliata Johnston, 1838 has a body up to 30 mm long with roughly 100 segments, often with blackened ends. The prostomium is slightly notched at the front, with a dorsal ridge reaching back to setiger 2. Juvenile specimens have four eyes, but adults often lack them. Setae on the fifth setiger are stout hooks with an accessory tooth; hooded, bidentate hooks are present in the neuropodium from setiger 7 onward. There are no specialized notosetae in the posterior segments. Notosetae are absent on setiger 1. The pygidium is saucer-shaped with a dorsal incision. Branchiae start from setiger 7 and extend nearly to the posterior end of the body. Antennae and tentacular cirri are not differentiated. The species burrows in calcareous rock and Lithothamnion. Its distribution includes the Baltic Sea, the North Atlantic from Scotland and the English Channel to Senegal, the Mediterranean, the Red Sea, India, Madagascar, the Falkland Islands, northwestern Japan, and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Polydora antennata
Expected_answer: Polydora antennata Claparede, 1870 Body length reaches up to 30 mm with approximately 100 segments. The prostomium features a deeply notched anterior margin, a dorsal ridge extending posteriorly, a single free occipital tentacle, and two to four eyes. Setiger 5 has enlarged, spoon-shaped hooks arranged in a horseshoe pattern, while from setiger 8 onward, neuropodia possess bidentate, hooded hooks. There are no specialized notosetae in the posterior segments. Notosetae are absent on setiger 1. The pygidium is saucer-shaped with dorsal and ventral notches. Branchiae begin at setiger 7, are weakly developed, and extend to around setiger 40. The antennae include an occipital tentacle, with other structures not distinctly differentiated. Geographically, this species is found in the Mediterranean, Arabian Sea, Ceylon, Gulf of Manaar, Japan, and southern Africa, mostly in tropical regions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Polydora maculata
Expected_answer: Polydora maculata Day, 1963 is characterized by a body up to 20 mm long with approximately 130 segments, often found in tubes within old gastropod shells inhabited by hermit crabs. It has palps with black bars, while the rest are unpigmented. The prostomium is bilobed at the front, with a median dorsal ridge extending back to setiger 2, and two small prostomial tentacles placed sequentially on the ridge between the palp bases. The setae on setiger 5 have enlarged hooks that are plain, curved, and slightly flattened at the ends, alternating with normal winged capillaries, and there is no separate tuft on setiger 5. The neuropodia from setiger 9 have bidentate hooded hooks, with eight to ten anteriorly and reduced to four posteriorly. There are no specialized posterior notosetae. Notosetae are absent on setiger 1. Branchiae extend from setiger 7 to the posterior end of the body. The prostomial tentacles are short, paired, and aligned antero-posteriorly. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa, with the type locality off East London.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Polydora kempi
Expected_answer: Polydora kempi Southern, 1921 is characterized by a body approximately 12 mm long. The prostomium features a faintly notched anterior margin, a single posterior occipital tentacle, and four eyes. Setiger 5 has typical notopodial capillaries and two specialized rows: an anterior row of recurved, fang-like setae with a basal swelling, and a posterior row of stout, simple, faintly curved hooks. Normal neuropodial setae are present on setiger 5, with bidentate hooded hooks in the neuropodia from setiger 8 onward. No specialized posterior notosetae are noted. Notosetae are absent on setiger 1. The pygidium is small and saucer-shaped. Branchiae are present from setiger 7 to setiger 14. The antennae and tentacular cirri include a single, median occipital tentacle. The species distribution includes India (type locality: Chilka Lake) and Mozambique (single record).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Spiophanes bombyx
Expected_answer: Spiophanes bombyx Claparède, 1870, is characterized by a body length of up to 60 mm and approximately 180 segments. The prostomium features a broad shape with a straight anterior margin, prominent pointed lateral peaks, a single posterior occipital tentacle, four eyes, and paired dorsal sensory grooves that extend to setiger 4. Notosetae on the first setiger are notably long, while the neuropodial setae of setiger 1 are enlarged with recurved blades. From setiger 15 onward, neuropodia have bidentate hooks with partial guards beneath the rostrum, complemented by an inferior sabre-like seta. The anal cirri are cylindrical. The notopodial lamella of the first setiger is slender, with subsequent lamellae widening at the base, and low dorsal ridges are present from setiger 3 onward. The neuropodial lamellae of setigers 14 are triangular, becoming low and rounded posteriorly, with fibrous glands located between setigers 515. The occipital tentacle is a single, posterior cirrus. This species has a broad distribution across the North Atlantic (from Sweden and Scotland to North Carolina), the Mediterranean, Gulf of Mexico, Cape Verde Islands, Liberia, Angola, Falkland Islands, and North Pacific (Japan to western Canada and southern California), and has also been recorded from South Africa (Cape, Natal).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Spiophanes soederstromi
Expected_answer: Spiophanes soederstromi Hartman, 1953 has a slender body up to 25 mm long with about 60 segments. The prostomium is transversely oval at the front, supported laterally by the buccal segment, and narrows towards the back. It features a single occipital tentacle, two pairs of subdermal eyes, and paired raised nuchal ridges that extend to setiger 4. The setae are winged capillaries throughout, with the first setiger having very long capillaries that are noticeably shorter from setiger 4 onward. The neuropodium of setiger 1 bears a stout, strongly curved seta. From setiger 15 onward, tridentate hooks lack or have partial guards, and sabre-like genital setae without fibrils are found from about setiger 15, occasionally anteriorly. The parapodia include notopodial postsetal lobes on setigers 14 that are pointed, with setigers 512 being blunt and broadening. Later, notopodia become slender and pointed again. Transverse dorsal ridges appear on setigers 1635, and neuropodial postsetal lamellae are pointed on the first four setigers but low and rounded thereafter. The antennae and cirri include a single, posterior occipital tentacle. Geographical distribution encompasses Sweden, Greenland, Uruguay, South Georgia, possibly Okhotsk and Bering Seas, and southern Africa (Cape and Natal).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Malacoceros indicus
Expected_answer: Malacoceros indicus Fauvel, 1928, has a body that can reach up to 60 mm in length and 1 to 1.5 mm in width. Its prostomium is broad and shield-shaped, featuring lateral projecting frontal peaks, while the posterior end of the cephalic keel is free, accompanied by numerous eye-specks. The setae are described as not dotted on the notopodial capillaries, with anterior neuropodia containing five to six large, sharply pointed capillaries, and long, bidentate, hooded hooks appearing from about setigers 4070. Additionally, sabre-like setae are found in the posterior neuropodia. The parapodia have rounded anterior neuropodial lamellae and posterior lamellae with nipple-like projections. The branchiae are long, cirriform, starting from setiger 1, and are fused at the bases of the dorsal lamellae. These dorsal lamellae are lanceolate, elongated anteriorly, and reduce to about one-third of the branchial length posteriorly. The antennae and tentacular cirri are not differentiated. Geographically, this species has been recorded in India (Gulf of Manaar), New Caledonia, and from certain locations in southern Africa (Natal, Mozambique), though records from the Cape are doubtful.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Laonice cirrata
Expected_answer: Laonice cirrata Sars, 1851 is characterized by a large body reaching up to 100 mm and comprising about 160 segments. Its prostomium is broadly rounded at the front with two large eyes and an occipital tentacle positioned posteriorly. From approximately setiger 45 onward, it develops bidentate hooded hooks as setae in the neuropodia. The parapodia feature large, auricular notopodial lamellae in the branchial area, with lateral membranous pockets appearing between parapodia from around setiger 25 in mature specimens. The branchiae are long and cirriform, extending from setiger 2 to setiger 40. Its dorsal features include a long, ciliated dorsal ridge spanning segments 28 to 40, along with membranous transverse ridges on the middle segments. The species has a cosmopolitan distribution, ranging from the Arctic to the Antarctic, inhabiting depths from shallow waters to the abyssal zone, and has been recorded from the Cape region.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Spio filicornis
Expected_answer: Spio filicornis Müller, 1776, is a small worm reaching up to 30 mm in length with about 90 segments, often smaller. The prostomium has a blunt front edge and a pointed rear end. Its setae include neuropodial bidentate hooded hooks from setiger 1011, with approximately 810 per neuropodium, and two inferior sabre setae in the posterior neuropodia. The parapodia feature auricular notopodial lamellae and broadly oval neuropodial lamellae that are wider at the front and narrower at the back. The branchiae are attached at the base of the notopodial lamellae at the front and are free at the rear. Geographically, this species is found in the Arctic, North Atlantic (from Greenland and the North Sea to the Bay of Biscay), and the Pacific (from the Bering Sea and Japan to California), including records from the Cape region.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Dispio magna
Expected_answer: Dispio magna, described in 1955, has a very large body up to 100 mm long with about 200 segments and a width of approximately 3 mm. The prostomium is smoothly conical, with a median ridge extending posteriorly to setiger 2, and it lacks eyes. The setae include notopodial and neuropodial capillaries, some with speckled axes. Neuropodial hooded hooks are found from setiger 30 to 44, bilobed in juveniles and bluntly unidentate in adults; additionally, one to two inferior sabre setae appear from setiger 14 onward. The parapodia feature a neuropodium with a small oval presetal lobe, and the postsetal lobe is dorsoventrally elongated with a free superior projection in the posterior segments. Branchiae extend from setiger 1 to the posterior end, with the anterior branchiae fully fused to the notopodial lamellae. The mid-body notopodium has a distal triangular lobe, and minute lamellae serving as accessory branchiae are located posterior to neuropodia from about setiger 35. The peristomium closely adheres to the lateral margins of the prostomium. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa, specifically in Cape and Simonstown.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Scolelepis lefebvrei
Expected_answer: Scolelepis lefebvrei Gravier, 1905 has a large body, reaching up to 80 mm in length with approximately 150 segments and about 3 mm in width. The prostomium is pointed at the front with a posterior keel extending to setiger 2, featuring four eyes arranged in a transverse row. It lacks an occipital tentacle and has lateral folds around the peristomium that enclose the prostomium. The setae include numerous anterior notosetae, which are winged capillaries with distal punctuations, and fewer, fine, elongated posterior notosetae. Notopodial hooks are absent; anterior neurosetae are winged capillaries, and unidentate hooded hooks appear from around setiger 40, with up to six posteriorly. The posterior neurocapillaries are reduced to small tufts. The parapodia have oval neuropodial lamellae that are anteriorly rounded and deeply notched posteriorly; notopodial lamellae are almost entirely fused with branchiae at the front and gradually separate towards the rear, joining only at the base around setiger 60, with a dorsal fold connecting lamellae from the mid-body onward. The pygidium features a ventral cushion beneath the anus. Branchiae extend from setiger 2 to near the posterior end. This species is found in the Red Sea and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Scolelepis squamata
Expected_answer: Scolelepis squamata Müller, 1806: The body can reach up to 80 mm and has about 200 segments. The prostomium is pointed at the front, with four to six eyes arranged in a transverse line, and a distinct occipital ridge extending to setiger 2. Setae include bidentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 3035 onward, with up to twelve per neuropodium, and similar hooks in notopodia starting around setiger 60. The parapodia feature notopodial lamellae fused to branchiae in the front segments, which are auricular and largely free at the back, with their lower edge projecting ventrally toward the neuropodium. The pygidium is a small cushion broader than long. The branchiae are fused to the notopodial lamellae in the front. Its distribution spans the North Atlantic from Scotland and the English Channel to Senegal and North Carolina, including the Mediterranean. It also occurs along the Pacific coast from western Canada to southern California and has been recorded in Southwest Africa, the Cape, Natal, and Mozambique, with doubtful records from India and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Nerinides gilchristi
Expected_answer: Nerinides gilchristi Day, 1961, has a body approximately 25 mm long with around 100 segments. Its prostomium is sharply pointed at the front and features an erect occipital tentacle at the back, along with two pairs of subdermal eyes and short nuchal bands extending to setiger 2. The setae consist of anterior notosetae and neurosetae, which are winged capillaries; punctate setae are absent. From setigers 1618 onward, neuropodial hooded hooks replace capillaries, with hooks bearing three long teeth above the main fang, and inferior sabre setae are absent. The posterior notosetae are unknown. The parapodia are consistently ear-shaped neuropodia; notopodial lamellae are triangular and laterally positioned in the posterior region. From setiger 2, branchiae are large, strap-like, fused to notopodial lamellae, but from about setiger 16 onward, branchiae and lamellae gradually separate. Posterior branchiae are narrow-stalked with flag-like ends. The peristomium and first setiger are small, with notosetae and neurosetae present. The posterior region is often missing, and its features are unknown. The species is found in South Africa (Saldanha Bay, Cape, Natal) and South-west Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Prionospio cirrifera
Expected_answer: Prionospio cirrifera Wirén, 1883, is characterized by a body approximately 30 mm long with around 90 segments. The prostomium is bluntly pointed at the front with a posterior keel extending to setiger 2, and it has four often indistinct subdermal eyes. Setae include neuropodial hooded hooks on setigers 1518 and notopodial hooded hooks after setiger 30, with hooks bearing paired teeth above the main fang in South African specimens. The parapodia feature pointed, small anterior notopodial lamellae on the first setiger that increase to setiger 6 before decreasing, with posterior notopodial lamellae being roughly equal. Dorsal ridges are absent, and neuropodial lamellae are small and triangular. Lateral pouches appear between neuropodia from around setiger 5 in mature specimens. The branchiae are long, smooth, and tapered, ranging from setiger 2 to 10, with the longest on setigers 24; they are about three times the length of the corresponding notopodial lamellae. The peristomium and anterior segments form a partly fused, reduced setiger 1. Geographically, this species is distributed across Arctic regions, the North Atlantic from Greenland to Portugal, North and South America, the North Sea, the English Channel, North Pacific from Bering Sea to southern California, with records also from South Africa and tropical areas.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Prionospio cirrobranchiata
Expected_answer: Prionospio cirrobranchiata Day, 1961 is characterized by a small, thread-like body approximately 15 mm in length with around 60 segments. The prostomium appears depressed with a square anterior margin and an inconspicuous posterior extension, lacking a keel. It has two pairs of small, often indistinct or absent in adults, eyes. The setae include neuropodial hooded hooks found from setigers 1819 onward, typically about five per neuropodium, each with a single dorsal tooth above the main fang. Four pairs of cirri are present, all subequal and cirriform. The parapodia feature triangular, pointed notopodial lamellaeexcept the first, which is smalland similarly shaped neuropodial lamellae, consistent across all segments. Branchiae consist of approximately 1112 pairs beginning from setiger 2, are smooth, cirriform, and uniform in length, being two to three times longer than the notopodial lamellae. The species is found in South Africa (Cape, including Saldanha Bay) and North Carolina.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Prionospio pinnata
Expected_answer: Prionospio pinnata Ehlers, 1901, is characterized by a large body, reaching up to 60 mm in length. The prostomium is bluntly pointed at the front, with a posterior ridge and large wing-like lateral expansions of the peristomium. In adults, eyes are rarely visible, and a membranous transverse ridge is located dorsally behind the palp bases. The setae include winged capillary setae on both rami in the front, with neuropodial hooded hooks starting from setiger 9, numbering 1215 per neuropodium. These hooks have four pairs of teeth above the main fang, and an inferior sabre seta is associated with them. The first setiger is well developed, with large, pointed notopodial postsetal lamellae on setigers 15, which become smaller and rounded posteriorly. From setiger 21 to mid-body, the parapodia are united across the dorsum as low ridges. Neuropodial lamellae are prominent and pointed at the front, low and rounded at the rear. There are three pairs of large pinnate branchiae on setigers 13, with some pairs often missing. The peristomium has broad, wing-like lateral expansions. Its distribution includes the Atlantic (North Carolina, Morocco, tropical West Africa, South Africa), the tropical Indian Ocean, the Pacific (western Canada, Japan to Chile), and New Zealand.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Prionospio sexoculata
Expected_answer: Prionospio sexoculata Augener, 1918 is characterized by a small body measuring 1020 mm in length. Its prostomium is rounded at the front and supported laterally by small peristomial ridges, with six eyes present. The setae include inferior sabre setae in neuropodia starting from setiger 12, tridentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 1416 onward, and in notopodia from setiger 30. The parapodia feature triangular notopodial lamellae on setigers 35, which become smaller and rounded towards the rear, with no membranous dorsal crests. The species has two pairs of pinnate branchiae on setigers 2 and 3. The reduced peristomium has a very small setiger 1 lacking branchiae or notosetae. Its geographical distribution includes southern Africa, recorded from South West Africa, the Cape, and Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Prionospio steenstrupi
Expected_answer: Prionospio steenstrupi Malmgren, 1867, is a species with a body length up to 45 mm and approximately 100 segments. The prostomium features a rounded front margin and a median keel that extends posteriorly to setiger 2, with eyes that are indistinct or absent. The setae include hooded hooks in the neuropodia from setigers 1819 and in the notopodia from setiger 50 onward, with hooks having four paired rows of teeth above the main fang, and an inferior sabre seta in neuropodia from setiger 18. Parapodia have triangular, anteriorly pointed notopodial lamellae that increase in size up to setiger 4 and then decrease to become low and rounded posteriorly; neuropodial lamellae are low and oval after the anterior segments. There are no membranous dorsal ridges or genital pouches. The branchiae consist of four pairs on setigers 25, with the first pair being pinnate and larger, the second and third pairs smooth, stout, and roughly equal to the notopodial lamellae, and the fourth short and pinnate. The peristomium features erect lamellae fused to the notopodia of setiger 1. Geographically, this species is found in the North Atlantic (Greenland, Iceland, Norway, North Sea, North Carolina) and southern Africa, including South West Africa, Cape, and Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Prionospio bocki
Expected_answer: Prionospio bocki Söderström, 1920, is described as having a body length of up to 20 mm. The prostomium is blunt at the front, with a posterior keel extending to setiger 2. It has two pairs of eyes: a small anterior pair and a larger, comma-shaped posterior pair. The setae are hooded hooks found in neuropodia from setigers 1618 onward, featuring four to five pairs of teeth above the main fang. Parapodia are notopodia, largest on setigers 34 and decreasing in size posteriorly; low dorsal ridges connect notopodia from setiger 6; neuropodial lamellae remain low and oval throughout. Membranous genital pockets appear between neuropodia from setiger 2, becoming conspicuous after about ten segments. There are four pairs of branchiae on setigers 25; the first pair is large and papillate, while the second and third pairs are short and smooth. The fourth pair is tapered with marginal papillae. The setiger 1 of the peristomium is small, with broad notopodial and neuropodial lamellae present. Geographically, this species is reported from Japan and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Prionospio ehlersi
Expected_answer: Prionospio ehlersi Fauvel, 1936, has a body length of up to 20 mm. The prostomium is expanded at the front and tapers into an elevated keel at the back between the peristomial folds, with two to four small eyes and scattered black pigment flecks. The setae include hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 1921 and in notopodia from setiger 37, featuring numerous teeth above the main fang, and a punctate sabre seta in the inferior neuropodium from setigers 1923 onward. Parapodia consist of triangular, pointed notopodial lamellae that are largest on setigers 35 and decrease posteriorly, with a low dorsal ridge linking notopodial lamellae from setigers 56 over 2030 segments. Neuropodial lamellae are rounded, initially longer than wide, later oval, with genital pockets positioned between neuropodia from setiger 2 for about 20 segments in adults. The branchiae are four pairs on setigers 25, the first pair being pinnate, the second and third short and smooth, and the fourth long, smooth, and tapered. The peristomium (setiger 1) is the first setiger, with small notopodial and neuropodial lamellae. Geographically, this species is found in Morocco and has also been recorded in Natal and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Prionospio saldanha
Expected_answer: Prionospio saldanha (Day, 1961) features a body that is thread-like, reaching up to 25 mm in length with about 80 segments. The prostomium is rounded at the front, with a posterior keel extending to setiger 2, and four eyes. The setae include hooded hooks in neuropodia from setiger 15, with up to six per neuropodium, and hooded hooks in notopodia from setigers 2535, which have a single tooth above the main fang. Additionally, the inferior sabre seta in the neuropodium appears from setiger 12. The parapodia consist of pointed, laterally directed notopodial lamellae on the anterior, largest on setigers 69, with smaller, rounded posterior lamellae, and dorsal ridges that connect lamellae from setiger 20 onward. The branchiae are four pairs on setigers 25: the first three pairs are smooth, and the fourth is larger and pinnate. The first setiger of the peristomium is small and fused to it. Distribution includes southern Africa, specifically recorded from South West Africa, the Cape, and Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Prionospio malmgreni
Expected_answer: Prionospio malmgreni Claparède, 1870 is characterized by a body that is thread-like, approximately 25 mm long, with around 60 segments. The prostomium is bluntly rounded at the front, with a posterior ridge extending to setiger 2 and four eyes, the second pair being large and elongated. The setae include pluridentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 1214, hooded hooks in notopodia after setiger 40, and an inferior sabre seta in the neuropodium from setiger 12. The parapodia feature anterior notopodial lamellae that are triangular, largest on setiger 4, and decrease in size posteriorly, becoming low and rounded from setiger 8 onwards. A membranous dorsal ridge is present across setiger 7, with smaller, incomplete ridges on subsequent segments. The neuropodial lamellae are low and rounded throughout, and there are no genital pockets. The branchiae consist of four pairs on setigers 25; the first and fourth pairs are long and pinnate, while the second and third are short and smooth. The first setiger of the peristomium has small lateral folds fused to it, with a reduced first setiger. Geographically, this species is found in the Atlantic (North Carolina, North Sea, Madeira), the Mediterranean, South California, Japan, and southern Africa (Cape, Natal).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Magelona papillicornis
Expected_answer: Magelona papillicornis Müller, 1858 features a body up to 170 mm long with approximately 150 segments, all uniformly white. The prostomium is bluntly spear-shaped, smoothly rounded at the front, with a median thickening. Setiger 18 have narrow-winged capillaries in both rami, while setiger 9 has fewer capillaries and many modified setae with a subterminal expansion before a fine tip. The abdominal segments display rows of hooks, each with two side-by-side teeth above the main fang. Notopodia in the anterior parapodia have low, rounded presetal lips and large, tongue-shaped postsetal lamellae, along with small, erect digitiform lobes above the notosetae on setigers 18. Neuropodia have smaller lamellae, with presetal lamellae produced ventrally below neurosetae, and small postsetal lips except on setigers 78. Setiger 9 is short, with presetal and postsetal lobes of similar size in both rami. In the abdominal region, from setiger 10 onward, rami have equal, tongue-shaped postsetal lamellae curving medially, and lateral pockets appear on several segments after setiger 25. The species is distributed across the Atlantic (Scotland, English Channel, North Carolina, Brazil, tropical West Africa), the Mediterranean, Madagascar, and southern Africa (South West Africa, Cape).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Magelona cincta
Expected_answer: Magelona cincta Ehlers, 1908. The body is described as up to 30 mm long; a distinct reddish to purple transverse band on setigers 58. The prostomium is described as truncate triangular; about as broad as long; paired muscular strands diverging anteriorly to antero-lateral projections. The setae are described as setigers 18 with simple capillary setae in both rami; abdominal segments with rows of hooks, each hook bearing two teeth side by side above the main fang. The parapodia anterior region is described as neuropodial lamellae slightly larger than notopodial lamellae; notopodial postsetal lamellae ligulate; erect superior lobe (dorsal cirrus) absent; neuropodial lamellae mainly infrasetal; lamella of setiger 8 markedly enlarged; presetal lamellae absent. The setiger 9 is described as short; parapodia reduced; setae similar to those of preceding segments. The parapodia abdominal region is described as from setiger 10 onward, rami with subequal, tongue-shaped postsetal lamellae, curved medially and pointed distally; lateral pocket-like folds present anterior to some posterior parapodia in adults. The geographical distribution is described as southern Africa (Cape, Natal, Mozambique); Morocco; tropical western Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Magelona capensis
Expected_answer: Magelona capensis Day, 1961 features a body approximately 35 mm long with about 40 segments. The body is uniformly pale, lacking a red band on setigers 58. The prostomium is elongate, 13 times as long as broad, with distinct antero-lateral corners. Setiger 9 has broad-winged capillaries similar to those of setigers 18, while abdominal segments bear hooded hooks with two side-by-side teeth above the main fang. In the anterior parapodia, notopodia of setigers 18 have a small superior lobe fused with a much larger inferior lobe, and neuropodia have a tapered inferior lobe. Setiger 9's notopodium lacks a superior lobe, and its neuropodium features a small ventral projection. In the abdominal parapodia, both notopodial and neuropodial postsetal lamellae are nearly equal, oval in shape, with constricted bases. The species is distributed in Southern Africa, including South West Africa, the Cape, and Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Dodecaceria laddi
Expected_answer: Dodecaceria laddi Hartman, 1954, has a small body approximately 7 mm long. It features capillary setae on both rami, except in the neuropodia of middle segments. Hooks are present in both rami from setigers 1115 onward, with anterior hooks having slightly flattened tips, middle hooks being spoon-shaped, and posterior neuropodial hooks possessing a boss below the excavation. The branchiae consist of two pairs, both shorter than the palps. The first pair is located dorso-laterally on the posterior margin of the buccal segment, while the second pair is more dorsal, on setiger 1. The palps are long and originate laterally. This species is distributed geographically in the Marshall Islands (Pacific) and has also been recorded from tropical South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Dodecaceria pulchra
Expected_answer: Dodecaceria pulchra Day, 1955, is characterized by a Black body that is gregarious and reaches up to 20 mm in length, boring into encrusting calcareous algae. The prostomium is stout and hood-like, overhanging the mouth. The setae are saw-edged capillaries located in the notopodia of setigers 112, often absent in middle segments but reappearing posteriorly; capillaries are absent from neuropodia after setiger 12; spoon-shaped hooks are present in neuropodia from setiger 10 and in notopodia from setiger 12, with posterior hooks featuring a boss below the excavation. The branchiae consist of four pairs, being longer and more slender than the palps. The first pair is dorsal on the buccal segment above the palps; the second pair is on setiger 1; the third and fourth pairs are on setigers 2 and 3. The branchial bases progressively diverge, forming an inverted V-shape. The palps originate laterally. The species is found in South Africa (False Bay, Cape), South West Africa, and nearby regions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Dodecaceria capensis
Expected_answer: Dodecaceria capensis Day, 1961, is characterized by a gregarious body that bores into calcareous algae, reaching up to 15 mm in length with about 60 segments. Its prostomium is stout, hood-like, and overhangs an elongated mouth. The setae on this species are specialized: setiger 1 has only neurosetae; notosetae are capillaries up to setiger 12, replaced by acicular hooks for approximately 10 segments, then both hooks and capillaries are present. Neurosetae capillaries are found on setigers 17, with a mixture of capillaries and hooks on setigers 811; hooks alone for several segments, then both types reappear posteriorly. The acicular hooks are spoon-shaped. It has four pairs of branchiae, longer than the palps: the first pair is immediately above the palps; the second pair is just below; the third is dorso-lateral on setiger 1; and the fourth is lateral on setiger 2. The palps are short, lateral, and arise just anterior to setiger 1. Geographically, it is found in South Africa (False Bay, Cape), South West Africa, and nearby regions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tharyx filibranchia
Expected_answer: Tharyx filibranchia Day, 1961 is characterized by an elongate body measuring up to 20 mm and composed of approximately 180 very short segments. Its branchiae are filamentous, and the prostomium is pointed with one pair of subdermal eyes. The setae consist of capillaries on both rami throughout, with posterior neuropodia featuring pointed setae that are intermediate between capillaries and acicular setae. The branchiae are very fine filaments extending from setiger 1 to near the posterior end, located anteriorly above the notosetae and posteriorly between the notosetae and neurosetae. It has one large, grooved pair of palps arising at the junction of the buccal segment and setiger 1. The species is found in South Africa, specifically in False Bay, Cape, and Natal, though there are very few records.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tharyx marioni
Expected_answer: Tharyx marioni Saint-Joseph, 1894, is a large body species up to 100 mm long and 1 mm wide. The anterior is swollen, tapering at both ends. Anterior segments are short and broad, posterior longer. The prostomium is broadly conical with no eyes. All setae are smooth capillaries; notosetae are longer than neurosetae. Posterior notosetae are very long, sometimes as long as body width. The long, filamentous branchiae extend from setiger 1 near the posterior end, arising above the notosetae. The stout, grooved palps originate at the junction of the buccal segment and setiger 1. The buccal segment is triannulate with a distinct third annulus. Found in the North Atlantic (Scotland to Morocco, including the English Channel and North Carolina), the Mediterranean, Persian Gulf, Madras, and southern Africa (South West Africa, Cape, Natal).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tharyx dorsobranchialis
Expected_answer: Tharyx dorsobranchialis Kirkegaard, 1959, features a body described as thread-like, approximately 35 mm in length, with short anterior segments and posterior segments roughly as broad as they are long. The prostomium is sharply conical, and there are no eyes. All setae are saw-edged capillaries, and acicular hooks are absent. The branchiae consist of very slender filaments, present from setiger 1 to the posterior end: anterior branchiae emerge dorsally within a fusiform interbranchial area extending to about setiger 20, while posterior branchiae originate from the mid-dorsal line. The palps are a pair, large, grooved, caducous, and arise at the junction of the third buccal annulus and setiger 1. The buccal segment is expanded and triannulate. Its geographical range includes Angola and parts of southern Africa, such as South West Africa, the Cape, and Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Tharyx annulosus
Expected_answer: Tharyx annulosus Hartman, 1965 has a body up to 18 mm long, with a cylindrical anterior section and a middle region showing strong segmental constrictions that create a beaded appearance. The posterior segments are short and slightly flattened. The prostomium is bluntly conical, and there are no eyes. The setae consist solely of serrated capillaries; those at the front are relatively long, while the rest are short, about a third of the segment width. The blades are thick and expanded, tapering sharply to thread-like tips with strongly saw-toothed edges. The branchiae are filamentous and located just above the notosetae; the anterior pairs are nearly as long as the palps, shortening toward the back, and they disappear before reaching mid-body. The palps are paired, grooved, dorsolateral, and originate at the junction of the buccal segment and setiger 1. The buccal segment is elongated and without annuli. Its distribution spans the Western Atlantic from Massachusetts to northeastern South America, and it has also been recorded from Natal, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Caulleriella capensis
Expected_answer: Caulleriella capensis Monro, 1930 features a yellow body that is somewhat swollen, measuring 2030 mm in length. It has relatively long segments and stout branchiae. The prostomium is short, conical, and depressed, with the posterior margin displaying paired dark ocular bars made up of three to four eyes. The setae are capillary with finely spinulose margins on both rami, and from setigers 1520 onward, unidentate acicular hooks are present. The parapodia have prominent anterior parapodial tori. The branchiae are filamentous, located only on the anterior part of the body, usually with fewer than 15 pairs, arising just above the notosetae. The palps are thick and stouter than the branchial filaments. The buccal segment is swollen, with the third annulus bearing a pair of stout palps. Its geographic range includes South Africa (Simonstown, Cape region), with a possible record from South West Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Caulleriella acicula
Expected_answer: Caulleriella acicula Day, 1961 features a body up to 20 mm long with about 200 segments. The segments are short and somewhat flattened, with prominent lateral parapodial ridges. The prostomium is sharply conical with a pair of small subdermal eyes. Notopodia have very few capillaries, whereas neuropodia lack capillaries. Acicular hooks are present throughout both rami, being bidentate with a small secondary tooth and a narrow hood on the convex side of the shaft. The parapodia have well-separated rami. The branchiae are slender filaments arising just above the notosetae, extending at least to the mid-body. The palps are slender, and the buccal segment is swollen, with palps originating at the junction with setiger 1. The species is distributed in South Africa, specifically in False Bay, Cape, and Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Caulleriella zetlandica
Expected_answer: Caulleriella zetlandica McIntosh, 1911, has a body described as thread-like, reaching up to 25 mm in length, pale when preserved in alcohol, with a rounded cross-section and short, crowded segments. The prostomium is long and conical, and eyes are absent. It features only capillary-type setae, some long with slender blades, others shorter with broader, curved blades. Neurosetae include short, broad-bladed capillaries and two to four stout sigmoid hooks; in juveniles, hooks are bidentate, while in adults, teeth are very blunt or nearly truncate. Hoods are absent. The parapodia have closely positioned notosetae and neurosetae. The branchiae are slender filaments that arise just above the notosetae and become progressively shorter toward the posterior. It has one pair of stout, grooved palps that originate at the junction of the peristome and setiger 1. The peristome is stout and triannulate. Its geographical distribution includes Ireland, with a doubtful record from South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Caulleriella bioculatus
Expected_answer: Caulleriella bioculatus Keferstein, 1862 is characterized by a body that can reach up to 40 mm in length, composed of approximately 140 segments. Its prostomium is pointed and bears two eye-spots. The setae are hook-shaped with two teeth and a small secondary tooth, with no hoods present. The parapodia include notopodia with capillaries throughout, and one to three acicular hooks starting around setigers 69. Neuropodia have capillaries only on setigers 12, with hooks appearing afterward. The branchiae are slender filaments extending from setiger 1 to about mid-body. It has one pair of long, grooved palps located at the junction of the buccal segment and setiger 1. Its known distribution includes the English Channel, with a questionable record from Angola and no records from southern Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Chaetozone setosa
Expected_answer: Chaetozone setosa Malmgren, 1867, has an elongate body measuring 20-25 mm in length and composed of 70-90 segments. The prostomium is conical and lacks eyes. The setae are capillary-like, extending from setiger 1 to the posterior end. Notosetae are up to four times the segment width, while simple sigmoid acicular hooks are present in notopodia from setiger 3 onward and in neuropodia from setiger 1. Notopodial and neuropodial bundles are separate at the front but form a continuous dorsoventral arc of spines in the posterior segments. The pygidium has a dorsal anus. Branchiae are filamentous, extending from setiger 1 to mid-body, arising just above the notosetae. The organism has two stout palps located at the anterior margin of setiger 1. Its distribution includes Arctic and subarctic regions, the North Atlantic from Greenland and Sweden to Morocco, tropical West Africa to Angola, the Mediterranean, Aden, Heard Island (subantarctic), the North Pacific from Bering Sea and Japan to California, and the Cape in South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirratulus filiformis
Expected_answer: Cirratulus filiformis Keferstein, 1862 is characterized by a very slender body that can reach up to 50 mm in length and appears greenish brown when alive. The prostomium is pointed with no eyes. The setae are slender, flattened capillaries throughout, with no hooks present. The parapodia have well-defined ridges. The branchiae are filamentous, extending from setiger 1 to near the posterior end, arising just above the notosetae throughout. The buccal segment is swollen. There are about four tentacular filaments, emerging at the junction of the buccal segment and setiger 1. Its distribution includes the Eastern Atlantic from Scotland to Morocco, as well as Senegal, possibly Sweden, tropical western Africa, South Georgia, and the Persian Gulf; it has also been recorded in South West Africa and the Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirratulus africanus
Expected_answer: Cirratulus africanus Gravier, 1906. The body is about 50 mm long and brown in color. The prostomium is long and pointed; eyes absent. The setae are capillary in both rami throughout; from about setiger 10, the setae abruptly taper and are intermediate between capillaries and hooks; they change to normal sigmoid acicular hooks about mid-body. The parapodia are similar throughout. The branchiae extend from setiger 3, over most of the body, and arise close above the notosetae. The tentacular filaments are three to four, arising above setigers 23. The geographical distribution is the Gulf of Aden; recorded from Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirratulus gilchristi
Expected_answer: Cirratulus gilchristi Day, 1961 is characterized by a thread-like body approximately 12 mm long that tapers strongly. The prostomium is bluntly rounded, with four pairs of eyes, though juveniles may have one or two pairs. The setae consist of unidentate acicular hooks in both rami from setigers 36 onward, with capillaries present in all notopodia but absent in neurocapillaries from setiger 6 onward. The branchiae extend from setiger 1 to the posterior end, originating high on the parapodium in mid-body and positioned as far above the notosetae as the distance between noto- and neurosetae. There are three to five pairs of stout tentacular filaments, arising transversely from the anterior margin of setiger 1. This species has been recorded in South Africa, specifically from Saldanha Bay and the Cape region, with three documented records.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirratulus cirratus
Expected_answer: Cirratulus cirratus Müller, 1776 has an elongate, cylindrical body up to 50 mm long and 12 mm in diameter, with segments that are two to three times broader than long. The prostomium is bluntly conical with two to four pairs of eyes arranged transversely. It features capillary setae in both rami throughout, one to two sigmoid acicular hooks on the notopodia from about setiger 20, and two to four on the neuropodia from about setiger 12. The stout branchiae extend from setiger 1 to the posterior end, rising higher above the notosetae in middle segments than the distance between noto- and neurosetae. The elongate peristome is as long as the first three to four segments. Numerous tentacular filaments form a transverse row above setiger 1. Its geographic distribution includes the Arctic and North Atlantic (from the North Sea to the English Channel), as well as subantarctic regions from the Magellan area and Falkland Islands to Kerguelen, with no confirmed records from southern Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirratulus concinnus
Expected_answer: Cirratulus concinnus Ehlers, 1908, features a small, thread-like body approximately 25 mm long with around 80 segments. The prostomium is elongated and conical, and it lacks eyes. It has long, capillary setae throughout both rami. Notopodia do not contain acicular hooks, but neuropodia do, starting from about setiger 32. Branchiae begin from setiger 1, arising close above the notosetae in the mid-body region. The buccal segment is elongated, with one or two pairs of grooved tentacular filaments located at the junction of the peristome and setiger 1. This species is known only from its type locality at the Agulhas Bank, South Africa, based on a single record.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirriformia tentaculata
Expected_answer: Cirriformia tentaculata Montagu, 1808 is characterized by a slender body, reaching up to 200 mm in European specimens and up to 80 mm in South African ones. It has a uniformly brown coloration, with red gills visible in live specimens. The prostomium is pointed. Both rami bear capillary setae throughout; each ramus has four to five unidentate, needle-like hooks originating from about the posterior third of the body (around segment 50 and onwards). The branchiae are slender filaments extending from setiger 1 to the posterior end, located just above the notosetae. The numerous tentacular filaments are arranged in two clusters, arising above setigers 57. Segments are narrow and closely packed. Its distribution covers the eastern Atlantic from the North Sea to Morocco and tropical western Africa, including the Persian Gulf, tropical Indian Ocean, and parts of the Pacific from Japan and New Caledonia to New Zealand and the Campbell Islands. It has also been recorded from South West Africa, the Cape coast, Natal, and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirriformia saxatilis
Expected_answer: Cirriformia saxatilis Gravier, 1906 is characterized by a body approximately 50 mm long, yellowish-brown in color, with darker anterior segments on the ventral side. The prostomium is rounded. The setae consist of saw-edged capillaries in both rami throughout the body, with sigmoid hooks in the neuropodia starting from setiger 8 and in the notopodia from setiger 42. The branchiae extend from setiger 1 to the posterior half of the body, emerging immediately above the notosetae. The tentacular filaments originate above setigers 24. Its distribution includes the Gulf of Aden and recorded occurrences in Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirriformia afer
Expected_answer: Cirriformia afer Ehlers, 1908 is characterized by a body that can reach up to 20 mm in length, is fairly stout, with parapodia forming lateral ridges. The prostomium is broad and rounded, and there are no eyes. The setae are capillaries present in both rami throughout; hooks are absent in the anterior region, while some posterior segments may have occasional single spines alongside capillaries. Branchiae extend from setiger 1 to the posterior half of the body, emerging close above the notosetae. Each side bears five to six tentacular filaments originating above setiger 2. This species has been found in Angola.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirriformia punctata
Expected_answer: Cirriformia punctata Grube, 1859, features a body approximately 40 mm long, fairly wide, and brown with black flecks. Its tentacles and branchiae are barred. The prostomium is rounded at the front, with no obvious eyes. The setae consist of capillary types in both rami throughout, with slender sigmoid hooks appearing from around setiger 12. The branchiae extend from setiger 1 to near the posterior end, emerging well above the notosetae in the mid-body and higher than the distance between noto- and neurosetae. Numerous tentacular filaments arise around setiger 4. This species is found in tropical regions worldwide, with records from Natal and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirriformia capensis
Expected_answer: Cirriformia capensis Schmarda, 1861, has a large body up to 150 mm long and 6 mm wide with numerous segments, all uniformly brown. The gills and tentacles are orange.
