The prostomium is broadly rounded at the front, and there are no eyes. The setae consist of capillary setae in both rami throughout, with sigmoid hooks starting to appear around setiger 12. The branchiae run from setiger 1 to the posterior end, consisting of stout filaments, and in the mid-body, they emerge higher above the notosetae than the distance between the noto- and neurosetae. The tentacular filaments are numerous, arising above setigers 34. This species is found in Southern Africa, including South West Africa, the Cape, and Angola.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirriformia filigera
Expected_answer: Cirriformia filigera Delle Chiaje, 1825 is described as a very large body, reaching up to 250 mm in length, with a uniformly brownish color and reddish gills. The prostomium is bluntly conical, and adults lack eyes. It has capillary setae on both rami throughout, with sigmoid hooks starting around setiger 12. The branchiae extend from setiger 1 to near the posterior end, arising higher above the notosetae than the distance between noto- and neurosetae in the mid-body. Numerous tentacular filaments arise above setigers 46. Its geographical distribution includes warm and tropical Atlantic regions (Morocco, São Tomé, North Carolina, Gulf of Mexico), the Mediterranean, Persian Gulf, tropical Indian Ocean, and possibly the Pacific (records are doubtful). It is also found in southern Africa, including Natal and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Poecilochaetus serpens
Expected_answer: Poecilochaetus serpens Allen, 1904, has a slender body up to 55 mm long with indistinct segments. The prostomium is rounded, featuring four eyes and a dorsal lip with a digitiform process, along with three long nuchal processes from the occipital region. The setae consist of long, forward-directed capillaries on setiger 1 that form a cephalic cage, two to four curved spines in neuropodia of setigers 23, with remaining anterior setae being smooth capillaries. A few feathered setae are present in middle segments, persisting posteriorly. The last 1617 setigers have notosetae replaced by simple or serrate spines. The parapodia have a vestigial notopodial postsetal lobe and a long cirriform postsetal neuropodial lobe on the first setiger. Setigers 26 feature tapered noto- and neuropodial lobes, while setigers 713 have club-shaped lobes with swollen bases and knobbed tips. From setiger 14 onward, lobes taper again. Two to four filamentous gills are located behind middle and posterior parapodia. The long, grooved palps are caducous. The species is distributed across the North Atlantic (Scotland, Ireland, from the English Channel to Morocco), the Mediterranean, and southern Africa (Cape, Natal).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Phyllochaetopterus herdmani
Expected_answer: Phyllochaetopterus herdmani Willey, 1905 is characterized by a large body, reaching up to 80 mm in length. Its prostomium has no eyes, and the tentacular cirri are long, tapered, and supported by fine internal setae. The posterior region features numerous segments with notopodia that are digitiform and have knobbed tips, while the neuropodia are inferior, square-shaped, and project pinnules. The buccal segment is large, truncate, and upcurved, with barred palps. The anterior region consists of nine to ten segments; segment 4 bears six to eight stout, obliquely truncate setae. The middle region contains two segments with elongate, bilobed notopodia, flattened branchiae, and large, wing-like neuropodia with uncini along the entire outer margin. The uncini have twelve to fourteen teeth. The tube is fragile, thickly encrusted with sand grains and shell fragments. Geographically, this species is found in Ceylon and has records from Natal and Mozambique in the Indian Ocean.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Phyllochaetopterus elioti
Expected_answer: Phyllochaetopterus elioti Crossland, 1903 exhibits a large body, measuring 50100 mm in length and 23 mm in width. Its prostomium features a single pair of eyes, while the well-developed, digitiform tentacular cirri emerge laterally from the prostomium. The palps are barred with brown coloration. The posterior region consists of slender, knobbed notopodia, each supported by a single spear-headed seta. The buccal segment appears truncated. The anterior part includes fifteen segments, with segment 4 possessing two to three enlarged, truncated setae. The middle region has over twenty short segments; notopodia are bilobed, each with six slender setae, and lateral triangular branchiae that are continuous with ventro-lateral neuropodia, which bear numerous tiny uncini with approximately 30 teeth. Its tube is horny, densely encrusted with sand, and lacks rings. Geographically, it is found in Zanzibar, Ceylon, the Gulf of Manaar, and has been recorded from Mozambique and the Cape of South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Phyllochaetopterus socialis
Expected_answer: Phyllochaetopterus socialis Claparede, 1870, has a small body typically measuring less than 30 mm in length, with the posterior region dark green. The prostomium is ovoid, featuring two lateral eyes often hidden by small tentacular cirri. It has two long, stout, grooved palps. The posterior body consists of numerous segments, with digitiform notopodia that bear one or two spear-headed setae. The buccal segment is truncated at the front and curves upward along the sides of the prostomium. The anterior region contains ten to eighteen segments; setiger 4 has a single, thick brown seta with an irregularly truncate tip. The middle region includes seven to twenty-four segments, with bilobed dorsal notopodia, lateral triangular branchiae, and neuropodia ventro-lateral and uncigerous. The uncini have about 24 teeth. Its horny tube is ringed distally and often forms branching colonies. Geographically, this species is found across the Atlanticfrom the U.S.A. and the English Channel to the Falkland Islands and South Africaalso in the Mediterranean, tropical Indian Ocean, Australia, and recorded from South West Africa, Cape, Natal, and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Spiochaetopterus vitrarius
Expected_answer: Spiochaetopterus vitrarius Ehlers, 1908 features a slender body longer than 35 mm, divided into three regions: an anterior section with nine uniramous segments, a middle section with about 20 segments decreasing in size, and a posterior with many short segments. The prostomium is oval, bearing a pair of lateral eye spots. Tentacular cirri are absent, while the long palps are distally barred. The posterior region has short, blunt notopodia supported by 1-2 long hastate setae, no branchiae, and neuropodia with serpuliform uncini. The buccal segment is broad and truncate with lateral upward curvature. The anterior regions segment 4 has a fan of hastate setae and one enlarged, conical-tipped seta, while segment 7 shows a sharp ventral black arc, and segments 89 have a white glandular patch. The middle regions notopodia are large, flattened, bilobed, with lateral branchiae, and neuropodia have undivided rows of serpuliform uncini. The tube is clear, horny, and closely ringed. Geographically, it is found in tropical western Africa from Senegal to Angola.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Spiochaetopterus costarum
Expected_answer: Spiochaetopterus costarum Claparède, 1870 is characterized by a slender, fragile body measuring 5060 mm in length, with clearly distinct anterior, middle, and posterior regions. The prostomium has not been described. Its palps are long and brown-speckled. The posterior region is short, with crowded segments, digitiform notopodia, and reduced neuropodia. The anterior region features nine to ten setigers, a large white glandular patch on the ventrum of setiger 7, and setiger 4 with one enlarged, swollen, and truncate seta with a serrated cutting edge. The middle region contains numerous segments, bilobed notopodia, lateral triangular branchiae, and neuropodia with many uncini bearing 2530 small teeth; a cupule is present on the second middle segment. The tube is horny, transparent, and distinctly ringed. It is found along the Atlantic coast of France, the Mediterranean, Madagascar, Japan, from western Canada to southern California, and has been recorded at the Cape, South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Chaetopterus variopedatus
Expected_answer: Chaetopterus variopedatus Renier, 1804, is described as having a large, robust body measuring approximately 100150 mm in length and about 10 mm in width, with around 70 segments. The body is divided into anterior, middle, and posterior regions. The prostomium is very small, with a truncated head and a large buccal segment forming a glandular lower lip, and it has one pair of small eyes. The palps consist of one pair, which are short and tapered. The posterior region contains more than 20 segments, featuring digitiform notopodia with knobbed ends and bilobed neuropodia. The anterior region includes eight to twelve segments, with triangular notopodia, notosetae with flattened, knife-like blades, and setiger 4 that bears several stout, obliquely truncate setae along with a few capillaries. The middle region comprises five biramous segments: the first is short with small notopodia; the second is elongated with large, wing-like notopodia anteriorly and a posterior cupule; the third to fifth segments have large notopodia fused across the dorsum to form paddles. The neuropodial uncini have six to eight teeth. Geographically, this species is cosmopolitan except in Arctic and Antarctic regions, with records from Cape and Natal (South Africa) and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Mesochaetopterus capensis
Expected_answer: Mesochaetopterus capensis McIntosh, 1885 is a small, solitary worm approximately 15 mm long with over 20 segments. The prostomium is oval-shaped with a pair of eyes at the bases of the palps. The long palps are faintly barred at the tips. The posterior region features short segments with simple, conical notopodia supported by two setae with flattened, tapering blades. The front part consists of nine uniramous segments; the fourth setiger has eight modified, obliquely truncate, serrated setae. The middle section includes two elongated segments: the first has short notopodia near the posterior anterior segment, and the second has longer, strap-like notopodia and a posterior cupule. The neuropodia form bilobed ridges with divided uncini series. Uncini have six to nine teeth each. The tube is fragile, encrusted with sand or foraminiferal shells. This species is found in the Cape and Natal regions of South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Scoloplella capensis
Expected_answer: Scoloplella capensis Day, 1963 features a small, thread-like body approximately 6 mm long in incomplete specimens, comprising 25 segments. The prostomium is bluntly conical, with no eyes. The thoracic and abdominal neurosetae are short, broad, crenulate capillaries, with no specialised setae. Branchiae are absent from the thorax and first appear starting at setiger 24. The peristome lacks setae, and the following segment is also achaetous. The thorax includes seven short, nearly rounded setigerous segments, sharply separated from the abdomen. Parapodia in the thorax have rami close together, each reduced to a small papilla with crenulate capillary setae. The abdomen segments are longer than broad, with the notopodium featuring a short, blunt postsetal lobe, and the neuropodium is stout and bilobed. Intermediate and ventral cirri are absent. This species is known only from its type locality west of Cape Town at a depth of 183 meters.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Proscoloplos cygnochaetus
Expected_answer: Proscoloplos cygnochaetus Day, 1954 is characterized by a very small body, measuring 3 to 5 mm in length. The prostomium is rounded in shape. The parapodia are generally uniform throughout the organism. The branchiae are stout and fusiform, starting from setiger 8. The first two segments are achaetous, meaning they lack chaetae. The notopodia feature a digitiform postsetal lobe with a few crenulate capillary setae originating from the base. The neuropodia resemble the notopodia but are smaller, positioned more laterally, with neurosetae consisting of a few crenulate capillary fibers. In the posterior segments, there are one or two swan-shaped hooks with four to five denticles above the rostrum. The species has been recorded in Tristan da Cunha and from a single specimen collected at the Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Schroederella pauliani
Expected_answer: Schroederella pauliani Laubier, 1962 is characterized by a minute body, measuring 34 mm in length and consisting of about 40 segments. The prostomium is long, pointed, conical, and divided into two annuli, with one pair of eyes. The setae are crenulate capillaries throughout, with a sharp-pointed aciculum in the abdomen. Thoracic neurosetae include a few crenulate capillaries and several serrated acicular uncini, while abdominal neurosetae comprise one to two crenulate capillaries and a single blunt acicular seta or projecting aciculum. The thorax contains approximately 820 segments, lacks branchiae, and features slight lateral swellings called thoracic neuropodia, with no foot papillae. The postsetal notopodial lobes are small and appear on setigers 79. The abdomen has 1620 segments, with digitiform dorsal branchiae, small postsetal notopodial lobes, better-developed neuropodia than thoracic segments, and no ventral cirri. The intermediate region is short, with 45 segments between the thorax and abdomen. Geographically, this species is recorded from Sandwich Bay, South West Africa, with no other records.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Orbinia angrapequensis
Expected_answer: Orbinia angrapequensis Augener, 1918 is described as having a body length of up to 30 mm with about 90 segments. The thorax features 1824 setigers, with thoracic neurosetae arranged in three to four rows of flanged, bent, serrated hooks, along with a row of crenulate capillaries. The abdominal notosetae are mainly capillaries, with a few forked setae. The thorax includes branchiae from setiger 6, a distinct postsetal notopodial lobe separate from the first setiger, and approximately 12 foot papillae per neuropodium. There are continuous rows of stomach papillae near the junction of the thorax and abdomen. The abdomens notopodia contain few forked setae among capillaries, while the neuropodia are bilobed with the inner ramus longer than the outer. Ventral cirri are present on all abdominal neuropodia, along with a ciliated cushion; interramal cirrus is absent. The species is distributed in South West Africa (Lüderitz) and the Cape region of South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Orbinia cuvieri
Expected_answer: Orbinia cuvieri Audouin & Milne-Edwards, 1834 is characterized by a very large body, reaching up to 300 mm in length, with approximately 400 segments and a thorax featuring 22-26 setigers. The setae include thoracic neurosetae arranged in three to five rows of flanged, bent, serrated hooks, alongside a few crenulate capillaries. It lacks enlarged superior spines, and the abdominal notosetae are primarily crenulate capillaries, with some forked setae bearing uneven prongs. The abdominal neurosetae consist of a few short crenulate capillaries. The thorax has branchiae starting from setiger 5; a distinct postsetal notopodial lobe separate from the first setiger; neuropodia with 10-15 foot papillae; and continuous rows of stomach papillae at the thorax-abdomen junction. The abdomen features notopodia with chopper-shaped postsetal lobes and larger tapered branchiae, a well-developed interramal cirrus, and bilobed neuropodia with a small conical ventral cirrus. Its distribution includes the North Atlantic (Greenland, Sweden, North Sea, English Channel), the Mediterranean, and southern Africa, specifically from Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Orbinia bioreti
Expected_answer: Orbinia bioreti Fauvel, 1919, features a large body up to 130 mm long with over 120 segments. The thorax has 3139 setigers. Thoracic neurosetae are arranged in four to five rows of flanged, bent, smooth hooks, with only a few crenulate capillaries; abdominal neurosetae include two blunt, bent aciculae and two to three crenulate capillaries, some of which taper sharply. The thorax has branchiae starting from setiger 56, a distinct postsetal notopodial lobe separate from the first setiger, neuropodia with about 12 foot papillae, and continuous rows of stomach papillae at the thoraxabdomen junction. The abdomens notopodia lack forked setae; the interramal cirrus is rudimentary in the front and well developed posteriorly; neuropodia contain small, uneven lobes. Its range spans the Bay of Biscay, Madagascar, and southern Africa, including records from Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Orbinia monroi
Expected_answer: Orbinia monroi Day, 1955, is characterized by a large body, reaching up to 100 mm in length, with approximately 200 segments and about 50 setigers on the thorax. The thoracic neurosetae are arranged in four to five rows of flanged, bent, smooth hooks, with some crenulate capillaries. The abdominal setae are forked, featuring shafts that are weakly serrated. The branchiae begin from setiger 5, and the posterior thoracic neuropodia have around 11 foot papillae. Numerous stomach papillae, roughly 30, are found on setigers 4045. The abdomen has a well-developed interramal cirrus and a notopodial postsetal lobe that is chopper-shaped. Geographically, this species is distributed in southern Africa, recorded from the Cape and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Haploscoloplos fragilis
Expected_answer: Haploscoloplos fragilis Verrill, 1873, has a small body up to 20 mm long with 1516 setigers on the thorax. Both rami feature crenulate capillary setae, and there are no hooks. Branchiae start from setigers 1415 and are larger than the notopodia. The thorax includes notopodia with a well-defined postsetal lobe from the first setiger, anterior neuropodia with a single postsetal lobe, and the last two thoracic neuropodia have two to three postsetal lobes. The slender abdomen has bilobed neuropodia with two ventral cirri initially, reducing to one later, and an interramal cirrus at the thoraxabdomen junction that diminishes posteriorly. The species is found in Cape (South Africa), but its identity is uncertain and may differ from Atlantic H. fragilis populations.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Haploscoloplos kerguelensis
Expected_answer: Haploscoloplos kerguelensis McIntosh, 1885 is characterized by a small body, reaching up to 20 mm in length. The setae are described as crenulate capillaries present only in both thoracic and abdominal rami. The branchiae are small near the front, but become significantly larger than the notopodia in the posterior abdomen. The thorax consists of 1014 slightly flattened segments, with branchiae starting from setigers 915 onward. Notopodial postsetal lobes are distinct from the first setiger. Neuropodia feature a single long median foot papilla, and stomach papillae are absent. The abdomen has small, tapered notopodia and neuropodia with unequal lobes. Neither interramal nor ventral cirri are present. This species is found in the Southern Ocean, including Kerguelen Island, the Magellan area, South Georgia, and Antarctica, with recorded occurrences in South Africa, tropical regions, Western Australia, and a doubtful record from India.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Scolaricia dubia
Expected_answer: Scolaricia dubia, described by Day in 1955, has a body length of up to 35 mm with around 100 segments. The prostomium is conical and pointed, with no eyes. The thorax consists of nineteen setigers, with branchiae starting from setiger 13. The notopodia features a postsetal lobe; notosetae are crenulate capillaries, and forked setae are absent. The thoracic parapodia have neuropodia with a single median foot papilla, increasing to three towards the end of the thorax. At the thorax-abdomen junction, there are six to twelve stomach papillae. The large, well-developed interramal cirrus is notable. Abdominal parapodia have neuropodia with equal lobes; ventral cirrus is absent, and a blunt glandular lamella is located below the neuropodium, later becoming notched or divided into two lamellae. The thoracic neuropodia setae include three rows of flanged, bent, serrated hooks, with the posterior row of crenulate capillaries. The abdominal neuropodia have few crenulate capillaries and long, tapered flail-like setae with serrated shafts. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa, specifically recorded from the Cape region.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Scoloplos capensis
Expected_answer: Scoloplos capensis Day, 1961 features a body up to 45 mm long with approximately 112 segments. The prostomium is conical and pointed, with no eyes. The thorax comprises seventeen setigers and has branchiae starting from setiger 15. The notopodia have a postsetal lobe, and the abdominal notosetae lack forked setae. The thoracic parapodia display neuropodia that are faintly bilobed with a single median foot papilla. The stomach lacks papillae, and the interramal cirrus is absent. The abdominal parapodia have bilobed neuropodia with a single inferior lamellar expansion, and ventral cirri are absent. The thoracic neuropodial setae are blunt hooks with a few coarse serrations, along with a posterior row of crenulate capillaries. The abdominal neuropodia have one to two crenulate capillaries and one to two flail setae. This species is distributed in South Africa, recorded specifically from the Agulhas Bank and Cape region.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Scoloplos marsupialis
Expected_answer: Scoloplos marsupialis, described by Southern in 1921, has a body length of up to 50 mm and consists of approximately 210 segments. Its prostomium is conical and pointed, with no eyes. The thorax includes about 18 setigers, with branchiae starting from setiger 9 to 13 and beyond. Thoracic parapodia feature neuropodia with a single foot papilla from setiger 4 to 12. No stomach papillae or interramal cirrus are present. The abdominal parapodia have segments with membranous pockets between neighboring neuropodia. Thoracic neuropodial setae are mainly crenulate capillaries, with few or no hooks, which are serrated, flanged, and faintly recurved when present. The abdominal setae are mostly forked and very few in number. Its distribution includes India (Chilka Lake, Gulf of Mannar) and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Leodamas johnstonei
Expected_answer: Leodamas johnstonei Day, 1934, is characterized by a body length of up to 35 mm with approximately 180 segments. The prostomium is conical and pointed, with no eyes present. The acicula has a blunt tip. The thorax comprises 2124 setigers, with branchiae starting from setiger 6. Thoracic parapodia feature neuropodia without foot papillae or with one to two papillae on the last two to three segments. The interramal cirrus is absent. Abdominal parapodia have bilobed neuropodia, with the outer ramus larger than the inner, and lack an inferior lamella. Thoracic neuropodia setae include three to five rows of hooks, which are slightly bent near the tips, lightly serrated, and flanged, along with a few capillaries. Abdominal neuropodia setae are crenulate capillaries with tapered tips. The abdominal notopodia have crenulate capillaries and some forked setae with equal prongs. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa (Cape, Natal) and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Scoloplos madagascariensis
Expected_answer: Scoloplos madagascariensis Fauvel, 1919 features a large body, reaching up to 120 mm in length with over 250 segments. Its thorax has 2430 setigers, with branchiae beginning around setiger 22. The thoracic parapodia are characterized by a small, anterior notopodial postsetal lobe, distinct from about setiger 10, and neuropodia that lack foot papillae, sometimes with one to three on the last thoracic segments. The abdominal parapodia have neuropodia without ventral cirri. Thoracic neuropodia setae consist of two rows of hooks, mostly smooth and nearly straight, with very few capillaries; these hooks are featureless, without serrations or flanges. Abdominal notopodia possess capillaries and forked setae with unequal rami. The species is found in Madagascar, tropical West Africa (Mauritania, Gulf of Guinea, Angola), and southern Africa (Cape, Natal, Mozambique).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Scoloplos armiger
Expected_answer: Scoloplos armiger Müller, 1776 is characterized by a large body, reaching up to 120 mm in length, with approximately 200 segments. The prostomium is pointed and has subdermal eyes. The thorax features 1618 setigers, with branchiae on setigers 1215. Thoracic parapodia include neuropodia with at least one foot papilla, and the last three to four thoracic segments have two foot papillae each. The stomach papillae are one or two in number at the junction between the thorax and abdomen. Interramal cirri are absent. Abdominal parapodia have bilobed neuropodia, with the inner lobe being longer, and lack ventral cirri. The thoracic neuropodia contain five rows of setae, consisting of a mixture of crenulate capillaries and short, blunt, hook-like setae. Notopodia have crenulate capillaries throughout, with one or two forked setae present in the abdomen. The species is found in the Arctic, North and South Atlantic, North Pacific (from Japan to California), possibly in the Indian Ocean, and has doubtful records from the Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Aricidea curviseta
Expected_answer: Aricidea curviseta Day, 1963 is characterized by a body length of up to 20 mm, comprising approximately 100 segments. The anterior segments are very short, about six times wider than long, while the posterior segments are roughly as broad as they are long. The prostomium is bluntly conical and slightly longer than it is wide. The short antenna does not extend to the prostomium's tip. There are 3444 pairs of branchiae starting from setiger 4, with anterior branchiae about half a segment wide and posterior branchiae decreasing in size along the body. The notopodia postsetal lobes are tapered, with anterior lobes about one-third the length of the branchiae and posterior lobes very slender. The neuropodia lack visible postsetal lobes. The setae on the anterior notopodia (121) are curved capillaries with stout shafts and tapering blades, identified as notosetae and neurosetae. On the posterior notopodia, only a few slender capillaries are present. The posterior neuropodia have only capillaries, with the superior setae tapering normally and the inferior setae being numerous, short, stout, abruptly tapered with a kink, and lacking articulation. This species is distributed in South Africa, possibly along the Agulhas Bank, Cape, and Natal regions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Aricidea (Acmira) simplex
Expected_answer: Aricidea (Acmira) simplex Day, 1963 features a slender body approximately 12 mm in length with around 80 segments. The anterior segments are about six times wider than long, while the posterior segments are slightly longer. The prostomium is slightly longer than wide. The short, club-shaped antenna does not reach the tip of the prostomium. Branchiae extend from setiger 4 to about setiger 15, with anterior branchiae overlapping medially and smaller posterior branchiae. The notopodia of parapodia have a slender postsetal lobe, with anterior lobes about two-thirds the length of the branchiae, and posterior lobes of similar length. The neuropodia do not have distinct postsetal lobes. Setae in the anterior, numbered 121, include curved capillaries with tapered blades for both notosetae and neurosetae, while posterior setae, numbered 124, are straight and much finer capillaries. From setiger 24, the neuropodia bear 610 stout, blunt, sigmoid acicular setae, without terminal filaments. This species is distributed in South Africa, specifically west of Cape Town in abyssal zones.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Aricidea fauveli
Expected_answer: Aricidea fauveli Hartman, 1957, has a body approximately 20 mm long and about 0.4 mm wide, with around 100 segments. The anterior part is strongly flattened, with segments about eight times wider than long, while the posterior is rounded with slightly longer segments. The prostomium is bluntly triangular, roughly as broad as it is long, with indistinct eyes and a small median antenna. Branchiae start from setiger 4 and extend over 2024 segments, with anterior branchiae about two-thirds the width of a segment. Posterior branchiae are stouter at the base and as long as the segments width. Notopodia in parapodia have well-developed anterior postsetal lobes about half the length of the branchiae, and slender posterior lobes. Neuropodia have less prominent postsetal lobes. Setae in the anterior (setae 121) include curved, tapered capillaries for both notosetae and neurosetae. Posterior (setae 124) exhibit fewer, finer capillaries slightly longer than the notopodial lobes, along with about four curved, unidentate hooks topped with a delicate pointed hood (arista) over the convex side of the apex. The species is distributed in the Eastern AtlanticMorocco, tropical western Africa, Angola, and recorded from tropical South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Aricidea longobranchiata
Expected_answer: Aricidea longobranchiata Day, 1961 features a vermiform, tapering body up to 20 mm in length and approximately 0.8 mm wide, with about 120 segments. The anterior segments are flattened and six to eight times wider than long, while the posterior segments are only slightly wider than long. The prostomium is bluntly triangular, as broad as it is long; it lacks eyes, and the median antenna is very long, reaching setiger 5. Branchiae start from setiger 4, extending over 1822 segments. They are uniformly tapered anteriorly and slightly overlap mid-dorsally, with the last three pairs having swollen bases and very long, slender tips that exceed the segment width. The notopodia have well-developed anterior postsetal lobes, while the posterior lobes are very slender. The neuropodia have inconspicuous postsetal lobes. Notosetae and neurosetae are curved capillaries with relatively broad blades, whereas posterior setae are fine, straight capillaries. The neuropodia contain four to five hooks, each unidentate and curved with a fine, tapered guard (arista) on the concave side of the shaft. Geographically, this species is distributed in Southern Africa, recorded from South West Africa and the Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Aricidea capensis
Expected_answer: Aricidea capensis Day, 1961 features a body that is thread-like, approximately 10 mm long and around 0.2 mm wide, with over 75 segments. The anterior segments are about three times wider than long, while the posterior segments are barely wider than long. The prostomium is conical, roughly 1.5 times longer than it is broad, with no eyes present. The antenna, slightly longer than the prostomium, is faintly annulated near the tip. Branchiae start from setiger 4 and extend over about 14 segments, with most branchiae about two-thirds the segment's width; the last two to three pairs are smaller. The notopodia have anterior postsetal lobes about one-third the length of the branchiae, with reduced posterior lobes. The neuropodia have inconspicuous postsetal lobes. Setae in the anterior (seta 121) are curved, broad-bladed capillaries, both notosetae and neurosetae. Posterior setae (124) are fine, straight capillaries; neuropodia contain about four curved hooks, each bidentate with a small secondary tooth above the main fang and a long, tapering arista emerging from the concave side below the apex.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cirrophorus branchiatus
Expected_answer: Cirrophorus branchiatus Ehlers, 1908 is characterized by a slender body approximately 25 mm long and about 0.4 mm wide, with around 120 segments. The anterior segments are flattened and three to four times wider than long, while the posterior segments are slightly broader than long, featuring prominent intersegmental constrictions. The prostomium is bluntly conical, slightly longer than wide, with no eyes. The median antenna is short, sturdy, and less than half the length of the prostomium. The peristomium is reduced, visible dorsally as a narrow band, and fused ventrally with the prostomium. Branchiae begin from setiger 5, extending over 2025 segments, with cylindro-conical lobes about two-thirds the segmental width; the last two to three pairs are reduced. The posterior end shows four pairs of cirriform projections, likely rudimentary segmental lobes. Notopodia have well-developed postsetal lobes anteriorly, becoming reduced in the mid-body and elongating again towards the posterior. Neuropodia feature inconspicuous postsetal lobes, with posterior neuropodial capillaries significantly longer than the notopodial ones. Setae in the anterior region are fine capillaries in both rami up to about setiger 12. From setiger 13 onward, there are one to two heavy notopodial spines per segment, straight, blunt, with a fine curved filament arising subapically. Notopodial capillaries are reduced, whereas neuropodial capillaries are long; specialized hooks are absent. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa (Agulhas Bank, Cape, Natal), with recordings also from North Carolina and possibly California.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Aedicira belgicae
Expected_answer: Fauvel (1936) described Aedicira belgicae as a body approximately 20 mm long and about 1 mm wide, with around 100 segments. The anterior region is flattened, with segments roughly six times wider than long, while the posterior region is rounded, with segments about twice as broad as long. The prostomium is broadly rounded anteriorly, as wide as it is long, featuring pale, indistinct eyes and prominent nuchal slits. The median antenna is short and sturdy, not reaching the prostomial margin; the peristome is reduced, fused ventrally, and not visible dorsally. The setae include numerous curved, tapered capillaries on the anterior rami; posterior setae are fewer, with no specialized types. Notopodial capillaries are very fine, whereas neuropodial capillaries are much longer, many matching the segments width. Branchiae start from setiger 4, extending over 1324 segments; the stout, cylindrical gills are approximately two-thirds segment width, with shorter posterior gills that have swollen bases and short, filamentous tips. The notopodia feature well-developed, tapered anterior postsetal lobes about half the length of the gills, while posterior lobes are slender, filamentous, and retain their length. The neuropodia lack distinct postsetal lobes, blending into the general ramus. These organisms are distributed in the Subantarctic regions, North Carolina, South Africa, and tropical areas.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Paradoneis lyra
Expected_answer: Paradoneis lyra, described by Southern in 1914, has a thread-like body measuring up to 20 mm in length and about 0.2 mm in width, with roughly 100 segments. The anterior segments are approximately twice as broad as they are long, while the posterior segments are about as long as they are broad. The prostomium is broadly triangular, about as broad as long, and lacks eyes. The setae consist of fine capillary setae on both rami throughout, with notopodia from the last branchiferous segments bearing one to two short, forked setae and longer limb spinulose on the inner margin. Neuropodia do not have specialized setae, and the capillaries typically exceed the segmental width. Branchiae start from setiger 4, numbering 8-14 pairs, are digitiform, and overlap along the mid-dorsal line. The anterior postsetal lobe of the notopodia is well developed, about one-quarter the length of the branchia, while the posterior lobes are inconspicuous. Neuropodia lack specialized lobes. Its geographical distribution includes Sweden, western Ireland, South Africa, and tropical regions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Paradoneis lyra capensis
Expected_answer: Paradoneis lyra capensis Day, 1955 is a body about 10 mm long with 80 segments, the front segments are broader, and the back segments are as long as broad. It has a conical prostomium without eyes, thread-like fine capillary setae throughout, and short forked setae on the last branches. Notopodia of some segments have short, spinulose setae, while neuropodia lack specialized setae. Branchiae start at setiger 4, are digitiform, and span 10-13 segments. It was found in the Knysna Estuary, South Africa, and is distributed in South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Prionospio krusadensis
Expected_answer: Prionospio krusadensis Fauvel, 1929 is characterized by a slender, filiform body that is slightly enlarged towards the front. It measures approximately 20 mm in length and 0.70.8 mm in width, with a yellowish coloration in alcohol. The prostomium is long and conical, tapering into a blunt median ridge extending to setiger 2, with low lateral folds that do not form distinct wings. It has two clusters of 45 small eyes. The anterior notosetae and neurosetae are long capillaries, with a notable large curved golden punctate seta in the neuropodia from about setiger 10, present in about 34 segments (a new feature). Neuropodial hooded hooks appear from setigers 1718, each with three teeth above the main fang, while notopodial hooded hooks develop from setigers 4042. Inferior sabre setae are absent. The pygidium features one median anal cirrus and two very small lateral cirri (both new characters). Three pairs of pinnate branchiae are situated on setigers 24, with the third pair often smaller than the first two. The first setiger of the peristomium is reduced, with poorly developed or obsolete parapodia, dorsal setae present, and ventral rami absent or vestigial. The notopodia have large, oval to subtriangular anterior postsetal lamellae; the first 56 are about equal in size, with the setiger 4 lamella often being the largest. Posterior lamellae decrease gradually in size, becoming rounded or heart-shaped but remaining conspicuous through the posterior end, with no dorsal membranous ridges. Neuropodia have smaller lamellae than notopodia throughout; they are oval anteriorly and become rounded and very small posteriorly. Genital pouches are absent. Distribution includes the Gulf of Mannar, India (Krusadai Island).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Disoma orissae
Expected_answer: Disoma orissae Fauvel, 1932. The body is short and expands anteriorly, measuring about 6 mm in length and approximately 1 mm in width, with around 25 segments. The posterior end is incomplete. The body is enlarged and flattened between setigers 4 and 10 and appears discolored in spirit. The prostomium is elongated with a slightly notched anterior margin, a bulging median region, and a crest extending to setiger 2. It has four tiny eyes (two dorsal and two lateral), a small, erect, tapering median tentacle, and a small projecting nuchal organ on each side at the prostomial base. Setiger 1 is large and lanceolate, with a subulate dorsal cirrus, a ventral cirrus directed forward, a small dorsal group of capillary setae anterior to the dorsal cirrus, and a fan- shaped ventral bundle of long capillaries extending beyond the prostomium. Setiger 2 has smaller triangular dorsal and ventral cirri, no dorsal setae, and ventral setae arranged in two rows: an anterior row of fine capillaries and a posterior transverse row of short, stout bristles with blunt, curved tips (a new character). Setiger 3 features a large, lanceolate, chopper- like dorsal cirrus with a crescent- shaped tip, a smaller triangular ventral cirrus, a ventral ligule, dorsal capillary setae forming a diverging fascicle anterior to the cirrus, and ventral setae, including yellow acicular setae with blunt, curved tips and an anterior row of slender capillaries. The anterior midbody transition shows a deep, triangular notch between setigers 3 and 4 on each side, dividing the anterior region from the enlarged flattened part (a new character). Setigers 4 to 10 have dorsal and ventral cirri as thick, rounded lamellae, with dorsal and ventral setae present. The ventral setae are brush- like, Aricia- type, comprising two types: stout, doubly curved sickle- shaped setae with broad wings tending to split into fine spines, and capillary setae similar to dorsal ones (a new character). Midbody modifications include dorsal setae disappearing around setiger 11; dorsal cirri becoming filiform from about setiger 9; and ventral cirri being modified from setigers 12 and 13. The ventral papillae are long, filiform structures appearing posterior to setiger 11, initially single but increasing to 2- 5 per segment posteriorly (a new character). Posterior setae consist of two types: stout, straight, bodkin- shaped setae and very slender capillaries. The species is found off Puri, Orissa, India, at depths of approximately 4 to 4. 4.5 fathoms.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ophelia anomala
Expected_answer: Ophelia anomala Day, 1961, is characterized by an elongated body up to 40 mm long, with 26 setigers. Its preanal segment is uncertain and possibly lacks chaetae, with a constriction behind setiger 2. The pygidium features two stout ventral cirri and a dorsal arc of 1618 small cirri. The branchiae are absent throughout. The notopodia have short notosetae that are not longer than the neurosetae, which are similar in length to the notosetae. The ventral groove becomes well defined from setiger 7, and nephridiopores are located between setigers 11 and 14. The lateral body wall has no pits. Dorsal structures include crimped dorso-lateral ridges extending from setiger 24 to the pygidium (a diagnostic feature). This species is found in South Africa, specifically in False Bay, Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ophelia roscoffensis
Expected_answer: Ophelia roscoffensis Augener, 1910 has a cigar-shaped body reaching up to 51 mm in length, with 32 setigers. The first 8 and the last setiger are abranchiate, while the next 23 are branchiate. It may have one questionable achaetous preanal segment. The pygidium features an arc of 12 small anal cirri and two stout ventral cirri. Its slender branchiae extend from setiger 9 to 31, with no branchial fenestrations. Notopodia carry long notosetae, at least twice as long as the neurosetae on posterior setigers. Neuropodia bear neurosetae shorter than the notosetae, with nephridiopores between setigers 12 and 20. The lateral body wall lacks branchial fenestrations. Dorsal structures include crimped dorso-lateral ridges on setigers 2932, which are diagnostic. Remarks suggest the South African specimens are questionable; it is reported to have 2021 branchial pairs and 34 posterior abranchiate setigers. Its known distribution includes the English Channel, with a doubtful tropical record from South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Ophelia capensis
Expected_answer: Ophelia capensis Kirkegaard, 1959, is characterized by a body length of up to 50 mm, with 36 to 57 setigers. It has 9 (sometimes 10) anterior abranchiate setigers and 17 to 19 branchiferous setigers. The specimen features three to four posterior abranchiate setigers and one to two achaetous preanal segments. The pygidium includes a dorsal arc of 12 small papillae and two long, stout ventral cirri. Branchiae are present on middle setigers, each with a distinctive flattened sac-like basal projection. The notopodia contain notosetae in the mid-body that are three times longer than neurosetae. The neuropodia have shorter notosetae, which are otherwise not differentiated. Nephridiopores are located on setigers 12 to 17. Lateral swellings are found from setiger 26 to the anus. This species is geographically distributed in South Africa, in tropical regions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Cossura coasta
Expected_answer: Cossura coasta Kitamori, 1960, has a body that is thread-like, rounded in cross-section, reaching up to 15 mm in length with about 107 segments, where segments are broader than they are long, and intersegmental constrictions are weak. The prostomium is blunt, depressed, and conical, with no eyes or appendages, but it has a pair of nuchal slits. The setae are simple capillaries, with blades of two lengths, somewhat flattened, and finely spinulose on one margin. Parapodia lack lobes, with setae arising directly from the body wall. The pygidium features three long, filiform anal cirri that are unforked in South African specimens. There is a single dorsal cylindrical branchia on setiger 3, very long, about three-quarters of the body length. The pharynx is eversible and lobed. The peristome is partly fused with segment 2, lacks appendages, and is achaetous. The first setiger is setiger 3, with a single setal bundle, while subsequent segments have two closely spaced bundles. The last few posterior segments are asetigerous. The species is found in Japan and South Africa, including South-west Africa, the Cape, and Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Capitella capitata
Expected_answer: Capitella capitata Fabricius, 1780 features a body that is thread-like, measuring 3040 mm in length and about 1.0 mm wide, with a dark red coloration in life. The prostomium is conical and bears a pair of ventro-lateral eyes. The thorax comprises biannulate segments with capillary setae present in both rami from the peristomial segment to setiger 6. The abdomen has smooth segments in cross-section and long-shafted hooks in both rami. Setiger 7 varies, containing only capillaries, only hooks, or both. Sexual dimorphism is evident: females have hooks in both rami on setigers 89, while males have enlarged dorsal genital hooks slanting inward toward the genital opening, with normal hooks ventrally. Each hook features an arc of three to four teeth above the main fang. The species is distributed across the Arctic, North Atlantic (from Greenland and Scotland to North Carolina and Senegal), Mediterranean, Black Sea, North Pacific (from Bering Sea to northwest Japan), southern California, and the subantarctic.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Notomastus fauveli
Expected_answer: Notomastus fauveli Day, 1955. The body reaches up to 90 mm in length and approximately 3 mm in width, consisting of around 80 segments. The prostomium is small and conical. The setae are hooded hooks with two transverse rows of denticles above the main fang810 denticles in the first row and 34 in the second. Capillary setae have relatively narrow blades. The branchiae are posteriorly branching, with up to 20 filaments. The peristome is featureless, lacking setae. The first thoracic segment bears capillary setae on both notopodia and neuropodia. In the abdomen, the anterior segments have notopodia forming a continuous dorsal ridge with short hooks on each side of the mid-dorsal line. From around the 15th abdominal segment onward, notopodia separate into well-defined papillae before the branchiae branch. The neuropodia in the abdomen have small superior projections in anterior segments, while the posterior segments are shorter without projections. The nephridia have inconspicuous pores and are present on the first six abdominal segments. Distribution includes South Africa, tropical regions of Sri Lanka (Ceylon), and India.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Notomastus aberans
Expected_answer: Notomastus aberans Day, 1957 is characterized by a body approximately 60 mm long with around 120 segments, where the posterior abdominal segments tend to become campanulate when contracted. The prostomium is elongate and conical, with indistinct eyes. It features hooded hooks with hoods twice as long as they are broad, along with at least two transverse rows of denticles above the main fang the first row has 45 equal teeth, and the second has 57 tiny teeth. Minute papillae are present on the outer edges of the abdominal notopodia and the superior edges of the neuropodia. The peristome lacks chaetae. The first thoracic setiger only has notopodial capillaries and no neurosetae. The abdomen's notopodia consist of short rows of hooks on segments with fragile, possibly indistinct, minute papilla-like branchiae on the outer edges. The abdomen's neuropodia have short, well-separated rows of hooks. Distribution includes South Africa (Cape, Natal), Mozambique, and Madagascar.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Notomastus latericeus
Expected_answer: Notomastus latericeus Sars, 1851 has a body length of up to 300 mm and more than 150 segments. The prostomium is blunt, conical, biannulate, with ocular specks present. It features hooded hooks with short hoods less than twice as long as broad, and about five denticles above the main fang. The branchiae are rudimentary, consisting of notopodial swellings and triangular projections on the upper edge of the neuropodia. Its habitat includes sand and mud. The peristome is achaetous. The thorax has eleven setigers; early segments are triannulate, while later ones are quinqueannulate, with capillary setae in both notopodia and neuropodia from the first thoracic setiger. The abdomen's notopodia contain rudimentary branchiae as small swellings, and the neuropodia have long rows of hooks that nearly meet at the mid-ventral line, with small triangular branchial projections along the superior edge. Lateral organs are located between notopodia and neuropodia. In mature specimens, genital pores are present, situated posterior to the lateral organs, on segments 720, starting from the second abdominal segment. This species has a cosmopolitan distribution, ranging from the Arctic to Antarctic, from intertidal zones to abyssal depths, typically below 50 meters in tropical seas.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Leiochrides africanus
Expected_answer: Leiochrides africanus Augener, 1918, has a body approximately 60 mm long with around 200 segments. The prostomium is conical and biannulate. It features abdominal hooks with long hoods, two arcs of denticles above the rostrum the first with one to two large denticles, the second with three to four smaller denticles. The retractile branchiae arise between the notopodia and neuropodia of the posterior abdominal segments and may have two to four lobes. The thorax is not externally differentiated. Posterior abdominal segments have rows of notosetae that are broadly separated dorsally, and hooks are present on the neuropodia. Its distribution spans tropical western Africa from Ghana to Angola, including South Africa, with a presence in Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Mediomastus capensis
Expected_answer: Mediomastus capensis Day, 1961 is characterized by a body that is thread-like, approximately 14 mm in length, with around 60 segments. The ventral side of the abdominal segments is flattened, and the dorsal side is thin-walled, with visible fecal pellets giving a beaded appearance. The prostomium is biannulate, conical, and lacks eyes. The setae are hooded hooks with two arcs of equal teeth above the main fang; the first arc has eight teeth, and the second arc has three to four teeth. Absent branchiae and an achaetous buccal segment are noted. The thorax comprises segments 25 that are biannulate with capillary setae on both rami; segments 611 are narrowed, biannulate to multiannulate, with long hooded hooks in both rami. The first abdominal segment is stouter than the last thoracic segment, with ventrally flattened segments and poorly defined parapodia. The notopodia and neuropodia of the abdomen feature short rows of hooded hooks, evenly spaced around each segment. The species is distributed in South Africa (Cape, Natal) and South West Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Heteromastus filiformis
Expected_answer: Heteromastus filiformis Claparède, 1864 has a filiform body, reaching up to 100 mm in length and about 1 mm in diameter. Its thorax and abdomen are not sharply distinct; the anterior abdominal segments are long and cylindrical, while the posterior segments become shortened and campanulate or strobiliform, with projecting uncigerous lobes. The prostomium is conical. The branchiae are indistinct, appearing as small superior projections of neuropodia starting from around segment 80. The thorax is biannulate and tessellated, with genital pores located on segments 9 to 12. The anterior abdominal segments are cylindrical, middle segments are shorter, and the posterior ones are campanulate or strobiliform, featuring short rows of hooks on projecting lobes. Thacheal setae in the thorax are hooded hooks with long hoods and about six denticles above the main fang. Abdominal setae are hooded hooks with shorter hoods and 34 denticles above the main fang. The species is distributed across the North Atlantic (Greenland to the Gulf of Mexico), Mediterranean, Morocco, Persian Gulf, North Pacific (from Bering Sea to Japan and southern California), as well as South Africa (Cape, Natal) and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Dasybranchus caducus
Expected_answer: Dasybranchus caducus Grube, 1846 is characterized by a large body, reaching up to 300 mm in length and about 10 mm in diameter. The prostomium is short and conical. Its setae are hooded hooks with hoods no more than twice as long as they are wide, featuring three to four transverse rows of denticles above the main fang, with each row containing approximately eight denticles of equal size. The retractile branchiae originate above the neuropodia from roughly abdominal segment 20 onwards, branching into up to 20 branches. The thorax has biannulate, tessellated segments. Genital pores are located in intersegmental constrictions between setigers 12 and 13 in sexually mature specimens, just before the last thoracic segment. The abdomen's parapodia are low ridges with rows of hooks, with anterior abdominal notopodial hooks separated by a narrow mid-dorsal gap. Its distribution includes the Mediterranean, Red Sea, tropical Indian Ocean south to Madagascar, and southern Africa (Natal; Mozambique).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Dasybranchus bipartitus
Expected_answer: Dasybranchus bipartitus Schmarda, 1861 is characterized by a large body, reaching up to 300 mm in length and approximately 6 mm in width, with over 200 segments. The prostomium is short and conical. Its setae consists of hooded hooks with hoods three to five times as long as broad, featuring three transverse arcs of teeth above the main fang. The first row has 14 teeth, and the second row has 48 teeth, with teeth decreasing in size distally. The branchiae are retractile, beginning around abdominal segment 40, with up to 13 branches per gill in larger specimens. The thorax has segments that are biannulate and tessellated. Nephridial pores are present from setigers 910 continuing to abdominal setigers 1415. The abdomen's parapodia are low ridges with rows of hooks; anterior abdominal notopodia display a broad dorsal gap between right and left hook rows, while anterior abdominal neuropodia have long hook rows separated by a small mid-ventral gap. Posterior segments have short hook rows in both rami with wide gaps. This species is distributed in South Africa, tropical regions, the English Channel, and probably Sweden.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Scyphoproctus djiboutiensis
Expected_answer: Scyphoproctus djiboutiensis Gravier, 1906 features a slender, cylindrical body 2330 mm long with over 70 abdominal segments. The prostomium is bluntly conical, with no eyes. The peristome and following segment lack chaetae. The thorax has twelve biannulate setigers with capillary setae; last thoracic neuropodial capillaries are partly or fully replaced by hooks. The anterior abdominal hooks are hooded and denticulate; posterior hooks are enlarged, without hoods or denticles, forming stout spines. Hooks have a short hood nearly as broad as long, with a main fang at a right angle, and a crest of four denticle rows. The abdomen has no parapodial projections or branchiae, with thin walls. Setal rows have evenly spaced hooks of equal length; notopodial rows converge dorsally and nearly fuse before the anal plate. Capillary setae are simple and narrow-winged. The anal plate, formed by fusion of several segments and pygidium, is slanting, dorsally flattened, with the anus dorsal to large terminal cirri. The margin has 1012 groups of spines; the anterior margin has about 20 fused spines. Posterior groups decrease from 45 to 12 spines near the cirri. A single row of dorsal neuropodial hooks matches the dorsal palisade. Distribution includes the Tropical Indian Ocean, Gulf of Aden, Sri Lanka, and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Parheteromastus tenuis
Expected_answer: Parheteromastus tenuis Monro, 1937 is characterized by a slender body measuring up to 50 mm in length and approximately 0.5 mm in width, comprising around 140 segments. The prostomium is conical, with no eyes. Thoracic setae are simple capillaries, with thoracic hooks featuring relatively long hoods and abdominal hooks with shorter hoods. Parapodial ridges are poorly developed. The pygidium has a single short anal cirrus. Branchiae are absent, and the peristome is achaetous. The thorax is slightly swollen, followed by 11 setigerous segments; the first four thoracic setigers have capillary setae in both notopodia and neuropodia, while the last seven have hooded hooks in both rami. Hooks are present in both rami of the abdomen, with hoods shorter than those of thoracic hooks. The thorax-abdomen transition is poorly marked, mainly distinguished by hook morphology. Distribution includes Myanmar (Burma) and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Branchiomaldane vincenti
Expected_answer: Branchiomaldane vincenti Langerhans, 1881 is characterized by a small, thread-like body approximately 10 mm in length, composed of 30 to 50 biannulate segments. The prostomium is ovoid-conical with two groups of ocelli and lacks otocysts. Its branchiae are notopodial, consisting of three to five simple filamentous branches located posterior to the notosetae. It is a hermaphrodite. The proboscis is globular. The posterior region contains 15 to 30 biannulate segments with parapodia throughout, most featuring notopodial branchiae. The peristome is achaetous, with the following segment also lacking chaetae. The anterior region has 14 to 20 abranchiate segments, with the anterior annulus of each segment more prominent than the posterior. Notopodia have capillary setae across all segments, while neuropodia only have hooks. There are two pairs of nephridia, opening on setigers 5 and 6. The digestive system includes one pair of oesophageal caeca. Notosetae are capillaries with flattened blades and minutely spinulose tips; neurosetae are hooks with three to four teeth above the rostrum and no hoods. The species is found in the North Atlantic, from the English Channel to the Canary Islands, the northeastern Pacific to southern California, and tropical South Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Arenicola loveni loveni
Expected_answer: Arenicola loveni loveni Kinberg, 1867 is characterized by a very large body, with a long, achaetous posterior section and a tail that can reach approximately 800 mm. The prostomium is trilobed, featuring a broad, median triangular lobe and V-shaped lateral lobes. It has thirteen pairs of branchiae beginning from setiger 7. Its habitat includes muddy sand in protected bays and estuaries, from low-water neap to low-water spring tides. The notopodia possess specialized notosetae, while the ventral neuropodia display long ridges in the branchial region that nearly meet at the mid-ventral line. It has five pairs of nephridia, opening on segments 5 to 9. The digestive system includes an oesophagus with one pair of glandular caeca. Notosetae feature lateral toothed crests with narrow, finely spinulose laminae, while neurosetae are hooks with faint or absent denticles. Sense organs comprise one pair of closed statocysts, each with a single statolith. The septal pouches are extremely large, extending into the third diaphragm or beyond. Circulatory features include a dorsal septal vessel that shifts from the subintestinal to the dorsal vessel at setiger 12, with no preventricular dilations. The nominate subspecies lacks preventricular dilations in the dorsal vessel. Geographically, this subspecies is found in South Africa, including Cape and Natal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Rhodine gracilior
Expected_answer: Rhodine gracilior Tauber, 1879 is characterized by a body length of up to 50 mm, approximately 1.0 mm in width, with a minimum of 23 setigers, including 510 achaetous preanal segments. Its color is pale with a red or purple hue on the fourth setiger. The prostomium features an oval hood over the mouth, a smoothly arched cephalic ridge, n-shaped nuchal grooves, and no eyes. Notosetae are narrow-winged capillaries and flattened, sword-like setae. The pygidium is a short, blunt cone with a terminal anus and a well-developed ventral valve. Glands are fully present in setigers 34, with the anterior half glandular from setigers 59, and restricted to the area around the parapodia in posterior segments. The tube is fragile. Neuropodia have hooks from setiger 5 onward, arranged in paired face-to-face rows. Setiger 1 is about five times longer than broad. Posterior segments gradually decrease in length and are achaetous preanals, much broader than long. The head is roughly three times longer than broad, with the junction to setiger 1 marked only by a dorsal crest. Setigers 25 become progressively shorter, while setigers 58 are nearly equal in size and about twice as long as broad. Setigers 910 are fused, and setigers 1116 are three to five times longer than broad. The collars are smooth, with anterior collars on setigers 23 and posterior collars from setiger 17 onward, including preanals. Neuropodial hooks have an expanded head bent backward relative to the shaft, a cap of 1520 denticles above the rostrum, rudimentary tendons, and a subterminal boss. The species is distributed in Sweden, Nigeria, Angola, and South Africa, primarily in tropical regions.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Nicomache lumbricalis
Expected_answer: Nicomache lumbricalis Fabricius, 1780 is characterized by a body length of up to 160 mm, cylindrical shape, and 2223 setigers, including a very short, achaetous preanal segment. The prostomium is short, broad, and poorly defined, blending into an arched cephalic keel, with juveniles exhibiting ocelli. Its setae include notosetae that are capillaries and feathered, with neurosetae composed of acicula anteriorly and hooks posteriorly. The pygidium is ring-shaped with a short funnel, featuring 1525 equal-sized anal cirri, a sunken anus, and no ventral valve. Notopodia consist of winged, capillary setae and fine feathered capillaries. The short, S-shaped nuchal grooves are present. Anterior neuropodia have one smooth acicular spine on the first three; posterior neuropodia have numerous hooks, each with a series of 45 teeth above the main fang and tendons below. This species is distributed across Arctic and North Atlantic regions from Greenland to the English Channel, North Pacific from Bering Sea to Japan and western Canada, as well as Bouvet Island, South Africa, and tropical areas.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Nicomache mossambica
Expected_answer: Nicomache mossambica Day, 1951 is characterized by a body length of up to 240 mm and about 5 mm in width, featuring 37 setigers. The first three segments are short, with subsequent segments becoming longer. The prostomium is described as a head bent forward with a short, arched cephalic keel dorsally. Notosetae are capillary and spinulose, while neurosetae include acicula anteriorly and hooks posteriorly. The pygidium is long and cylindrical, rimmed with many short anal cirri, and followed by a small achaetous preanal segment. Notopodia have narrow wings with capillary setae and some fine spinulose capillaries. The nuchal grooves are nearly parallel. The anterior neuropodia (segments 13) have two to four straight acicular spines, while the posterior neuropodia have rows of hooks, each with a vertical series of five teeth above the main fang. The first three segments of the thorax are ventrally glandular. Geographically, this species is recorded only in Mozambique (Delagoa Bay).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Maldanella fibrillata
Expected_answer: Maldanella fibrillata Chamberlin, 1919, is characterized by a body length of up to 70 mm, comprising 19 setigers, three achaetous preanals, and segments with distinct features. The anterior segments are short with glandular rims, while the middle segments are longer; the posterior segments gradually decrease in size, with the last few being sausage-shaped. The prostomium is small with no eyes. The pygidium is funnel-shaped, with the last preanal segment fused to it; it bears about 50 subequal cirri, has a sunken anus, and lacks a ventral valve. Notopodia consist of narrow-winged capillary setae of two lengths, whereas setae are absent on setiger 1. The nuchal grooves are straight, extending approximately half the length of the cephalic plate, with anterior ends continuous and sharply bent inward rim. The cephalic plate is oval, slanting, with a high, unnotched rim. Setae on setiger 2 include 1220 hooks per segment, each with two to three teeth above the main fan. From setiger 3 onward, there are about 30 hooks per segment, featuring vertical series of three to four teeth above the main fang. Geographically, this species is found in the Pacific Ocean off Panama at abyssal depths and off South Africa (Cape, abyssal).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Maldanella capensis
Expected_answer: Maldanella capensis Day, 1961 has a body length of up to 45 mm and a width of about 2 mm. It features 19 short setigers and four very short achaetous preanals. The anterior segments are only slightly longer than wide, while the posterior segments are roughly twice as long as they are wide. The four preanals together are shorter than the last two setigers. The prostomium is broad with a curved anterior margin and numerous eye-spots. The pygidium includes a ring and funnel, with about 30 short anal cirri, a sunken anus, and no ventral valve. The notopodia contain narrow-winged capillary setae and fairly broad feathered setae. The neuropodia are absent on setiger 1. The nuchal grooves are short and straight. The cephalic plate is broadly oval with a very low rim and deep lateral notches. Setiger 2 has two hooks with three to four teeth above the main fang, while setiger 3 has three to five hooks. The posterior setae in subsequent segments include numerous hooks with an acutely curved main fang, topped by about five teeth in a vertical series. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa, specifically at the Agulhas Bank and Cape.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Axiothella quadrimaculata
Expected_answer: Axiothella quadrimaculata Augener, 1914 features a tiny, cylindrical body approximately 5 mm long, with 1920 setigers, no preanals, and a pygidial ring with a scalloped funnel. The prostomium is broadly curved at the front and smoothly connects to the cephalic ridge behind. Its pygidium is shaped like a scalloped funnel. Notopodia carry capillary setae that are hastate-bladed, along with some feathered setae. Neuropodia have avicular hooks with S-shaped shafts and a swelling. These hooks have five teeth arranged vertically above the main fang. The nuchal grooves are slightly curved. The cephalic rim is low and poorly defined. The pigmentation includes barred anterior segments and brown markings on the head. Geographically, this species is found in southwest Australia, New Zealand, subantarctic islands, with doubtful reports from South Africa, as well as tropical and Mozambique Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Gravierella multiannulata
Expected_answer: Gravierella multiannulata Fauvel, 1919. The body is slender and elongated, reaching up to 80 mm in length and 12 mm in width, with about 6070 segments. The first seven segments are slightly longer than broad, while segments 8 to 12 are longer. From setiger 14 onward, segments are very short, campanulate, and have backwardly directed collars. No achaetous preanals are present, and the posterior region is often regenerative. The prostomium is well developed, conical, and equipped with numerous ocelli. The pygidium features approximately 20 anal cirri, with cirri increasing in length ventrally. The sandy tube is very fragile. Notopodia carry winged capillaries and fine feathered setae. Neuropodia have hooks starting from setigers 1 to 3, with the first three having 35 dentate hooks. Subsequent segments have more hooks, featuring a vertical series of 57 teeth above the main fang. The nuchal grooves are very long and parallel. The cephalic rim is high, with lateral and posterior indentations. This species is found in Madagascar (Tulear) and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Johnstonia clymenoides
Expected_answer: Johnstonia clymenoides Quatrefages, 1865: The body is elongate, reaching up to 200 mm in length, with 22 setigers and one short, poorly marked achaetous preanal segment. The prostomium is broad with ocelli present. The notosetae are described as broadly winged capillaries and feathered capillaries. The neurosetae in setigers 13 have hooks with one or two vestigial denticles above the apex; later hooks feature numerous denticles arranged in a vertical series. The pygidium is funnel-shaped, rimmed with 2030 anal cirri; the largest ventral cirrus is present, but ventral valve is absent. The nuchal grooves are straight, about two-thirds the length of the cephalic plate, which is bordered by a lightly scalloped rim. Glandular structures include glandular rings on setigers 17 and four longitudinal glandular belts on setigers 915 (dorsal, ventral, and lateral). The posterior vascular cirri are found in the last 56 setigers, with four rows of usually unbranched vascular cirri. Its geographical distribution covers the Atlantic from the English Channel and Morocco to tropical West Africa, the Mediterranean, and South West Africa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Macroclymene saldanha
Expected_answer: Macroclymene saldanha Day, 1955 is described as having a body approximately 55 mm in length and about 1.3 mm in width. It has a creamy yellow coloration in alcohol, with 35 to 40 setigers, and the presence of an achaetous preanal segment is doubtful or absent. The prostomium is triangular, pointed, with no eyes. Notosetae include stout, broad-winged capillaries, slender spinulose capillaries, and slender smooth capillaries. Neurosetae in setigers 13 have straight hooks with three obsolete teeth above a blunt rostrum; subsequent hooks are well developed, featuring a vertical series of 57 teeth above the main fang and distinct tendons. The pygidium is small, shorter than the last setiger, lacks a funnel, and has a sunken anus surrounded by 1020 short cirri in a ring. The nuchal grooves are straight, extending over about four-fifths of the cephalic plate. The cephalic plate has a well-developed rim that is high anteriorly, with lateral and posterior notches. Segmentation shows setigers 13 are short; setigers 48 are longer; subsequent setigers gradually decrease in length, with the last setiger approximately twice as long as wide. Glandular bands are faint on setigers 23, well marked on setigers 47, and faint again on setiger 8, with a narrow ventral glandular streak running from the first setiger to the pygidium. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa, specifically in Cape and Langebaan Lagoon.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Euclymene oerstedi
Expected_answer: Euclymene oerstedi Claparède, 1863: The body is slender, reaching up to 100 mm in length, with 19 setigers. It has two distinct achaetous preanal segments, followed by a circular ridge and pygidial ring with a funnel. The prostomium is small with visible ocelli. Notosetae are simple capillary setae, while neurosetae, in segments 13, feature one or two acicular setae with two to three vestigial teeth on a blunt apex. Later segments have numerous hooks with a vertical series of five teeth above the main fang and well-developed tendons. The pygidium has a funnel, a sunken anus, a small ventral valve, and several short anal cirri, with 710 longer alternating cirri. The nuchal grooves are about two-thirds the length of the cephalic plate, which is low-rimmed with one lateral notch per side. Segmentation includes short setigers 17, while subsequent setigers are longer. The first preanal segment is about two-thirds the length of the last setiger, the second preanal shorter, and the last preanal small and poorly marked. Glandular patterns show broad white glandular bands on setigers 17, contrasting with red posterior segments, and a broad mid-ventral glandular streak on setigers 714. Distribution includes the North Sea, English Channel, Mediterranean, with doubtful records from South Africa and the tropics.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Euclymene lombricoides
Expected_answer: Euclymene lombricoides Quatrefages, 1865 features an elongated body, reaching up to 150 mm in length and about 9 mm in width. It has 19 setigers, with three achaetous preanals decreasing in size, and the preanal region is slightly longer than the last setiger. The prostomium is broadly rounded at the front with indistinct ocelli. Notosetae comprise winged and feathered capillary setae, while neurosetae in the first three setigers include one to two smooth acicular setae. Following segments have numerous hooks with vertical rows of five to six teeth above the main fang and well-developed tendons. The pygidium features a ring and funnel, with the funnel sunken, no ventral valve, and numerous anal cirri that vary in length. The nuchal grooves are straight and about half the length of the cephalic plate, which is rimmed and divided into roughly 10 lobes posteriorly. Segmentation varies, with anterior segments slightly longer than broad, while posterior segments are two to four times longer than broad. The glandular pattern includes anterior rings on setigers 28 and sometimes a dorsal streak on setigers 812. Its distribution spans the North Atlantic from Scotland and the English Channel to Morocco, as well as the Mediterranean, southern Africa (South West Africa, Cape), and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Euclymene natalensis
Expected_answer: Euclymene natalensis Day, 1957 is characterized by an elongated body reaching up to 120 mm in length and approximately 3.5 mm in width. It has 19 setigers, with two achaetous preanals; the first preanal is nearly as long as the last setiger, while the second preanal is about half that length. The prostomium is rounded with a few ocelli. Notosetae consist of numerous winged capillary setae and a few fine feathered capillaries. The neurosetae in the first three setigers feature a single smooth acicular spine with a bent tip, whereas subsequent segments have well-developed hooks with six teeth above the main fang and stout tendons below. The pygidium has a funnel-shaped structure, about 20 subequal anal cirri, and one longer ventral cirrus, with no ventral valve. The nuchal grooves are long. The cephalic plate has a high rim laterally, separated by a notch or step from the lower posterior portion, which is smooth with a median posterior notch. The body segmentation includes the body, pygidial ring, and funnel. Glandular rings are present on setigers 2-7, with a median ventral glandular streak from setiger 9 onwards; dorsal glandular streaks are absent. Geographically, this species is found in South Africa (Cape, Natal) and Mozambique.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Euclymene glandularis
Expected_answer: Euclymene glandularis Day, 1955 is characterized by a brown body that reaches up to 138 mm in length and approximately 3.5 mm in width. It has 19 setigers, including two long achaetous preanals, with the first preanal twice as long as the second; together, these preanals are about equal to the length of the 19th setiger. The prostomium is rounded and bears numerous eye-spots. Notosetae are stout, winged capillaries, along with fine, spinulose capillaries. Neurosetae in segments 13 are one to three stout, smooth, acicular setae with curved tips; later segments feature numerous hooks with a vertical series of 56 teeth above the main fang and a prominent tendon beneath. The pygidium has a funnel shape, with 2530 subequal anal cirri, an inset anus, and no ventral valve. The nuchal grooves are straight and about three-quarters the length of the cephalic plate, which has a posterior crenulated rim with 810 lobes. Segmentation shows setigers 17 increasing in length, setiger 8 is short, setiger 9 is twice as long, and subsequent setigers decrease in length. Glandular patterns include glandular rings on setigers 28, a broad dorsal glandular streak on setigers 914, and a faint mid-ventral glandular streak beginning at setiger 9. Its distribution includes South Africa (Cape; Natal).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Euclymene annandalei
Expected_answer: Euclymene annandalei Southern, 1921 features a body up to 80 mm long, pale in alcohol, with 21 setigers, including two achaetous preanals, followed by a pygidial ring and funnel. The anterior segments are short, with setigers 38 only slightly longer than they are broad, while the later segments lengthen posteriorly. The prostomium is bluntly triangular with numerous ocelli. Notosetae are narrow-winged capillaries at the front and feathered capillaries further back. Neurosetae in the first three setigers include a single smooth, bent-tipped acicular spine; subsequent segments have many hooks with a vertical series of 56 teeth above the main fang and well-developed tendons underneath. The pygidium has a funnel with 14 short, equal anal cirri and one longer ventral cirrus; the anus is sunken, and there is no ventral valve.
