The branchiae are present as non-retractile, digitiform structures located between segments 16 and 22, on the parapodia towards the rear. The chaetae are simple capillaries in the notopodia and compound spinigers in the neuropodia. The specific locality isnt documented, but this species is found across the Bay of Bengal, Gulf of Aden, Suez Canal, along the west and east coasts of Africa, and around Indias Andaman & Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera americana?
Expected_answer: Glycera americana Leidy, 1855 is characterized by mid-body segments that are biannulate, with the anterior annulus about as long as or slightly longer than the posterior. The prostomium is conical and bears 10-12 rings. The proboscidal papillae consist of two types: numerous conical papillae with two U-shaped ridges, and isolated, broader, oval to globular papillae without ridges. The aileron has a triangular base. The parapodia are initially uniramous, becoming biramous in subsequent segments. The prechaetal lobes are two slender, triangular or digitiform lobes, slightly tapering in the posterior parapodia; in the last parapodia, the notopodial lobe is shorter than the neuropodial one. The postchaetal lobes are two shorter lobes; anteriorly, both are rounded, while in later segments, both are elongated and slender, triangular; in the last parapodia, both lobes are generally shorter and rounded. The dorsal cirrus begins from the 3rd parapodium, conical to oval, and is positioned slightly above the parapodial base on the body wall. The ventral cirrus is slender, triangular to digitiform, slightly shorter than the postchaetal lobes in the posterior segments, and becomes slender and elongated; in the last segments, it is about the same length as the neuropodial prechaetal lobe. The branchiae are retractile, bush-like when fully developed and everted. Their starting position is from about the 7th to the 22nd parapodium, extending near the posterior end. The chaetae are simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The type locality is Point Judith, Atlantic City, Atlantic Ocean. Its distribution includes the Arabian Sea, Atlantic coasts of North and South America, Brazil, Bangladesh, the Caribbean Sea, Japan, British Columbia, Gulf of Mexico, Gulf of Saint Lawrence, Pacific coasts of South America, New Zealand, North Atlantic Ocean, Red Sea, and Indian Ocean region (Arabian Sea).

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera benguellana?
Expected_answer: Glycera benguellana Augener, 1931, is characterized by numerous indistinct body rings and a long prostomium also with many faint rings. The proboscidal papillae consist of two types: a few broadly conical papillae and numerous digitiform ones with 10-16 rings. The aileron is blade-like, with the shorter limb being a simple expansion at the base of the other. The first two parapodia are uniramous, followed by biramous parapodia. The prechaetal lobes are two triangular structures, with the superior one slightly shorter. The postchaetal lobe is low and rounded. The dorsal cirrus is relatively large, arising at the junction of the parapodium with the body, while the ventral cirrus is absent. No branchiae are present. The chaetae include simple capillaries in the notopodia and compound spinigers in the neuropodia. The type locality is the Norwegian EEZ, and its geographic distribution includes areas in Africa, the Indian Ocean, the Arabian Sea, and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera brevicirris?
Expected_answer: Glycera brevicirris (Grube, 1870) is characterized by body rings: anterior segments are bi-annulated, while mid-body segments are more or less tri-annulated. The prostomium is an elongated, conical shape, longer than wide, with 10-12 rings. Its proboscidal papillae include two types: 1) digitiform papillae with 8-17 transverse ridges, and 2) oval-shaped papillae with longitudinal ridges. The aileron features a deeply incised base. Parapodia are uniramous in the first two segments and become biramous in subsequent segments. The prechaetal lobes are triangular and broad-based in the anterior and mid-body, shifting to digitiform in posterior segments. The postchaetal lobes are short and rounded throughout. The ventral cirrus is broadly triangular in the front and middle segments but becomes digitiform towards the rear. Branchiae are absent, with no described position. Chaetae consist of simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The dorsal cirrus is conical to oval, appearing from the third segment, located slightly away from the parapodial basis. The type locality is the Indian Ocean, and its distribution includes the West and East Atlantic, Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean Sea, Red Sea, Indian Ocean, Andaman Sea, Indo-Pacific, Central Pacific Basin, East Pacific coast, as well as Indian Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera cinnamomea?
Expected_answer: Glycera cinnamomea GRUBE 1874 features body rings described as biannulate in mid-body segments. The prostomium is conical with 9-12 rings. The proboscidian papillae include three types: (1) numerous papillae with terminal fingernail-like tips on long stalks and some longitudinal ridges, (2) fewer digitiform papillae with a straight, median longitudinal ridge, and (3) isolated, broader oval to globular papillae without ridges. The aileron has a pointed triangular base. Parapodia initially are uniramous, then become biramous. The prechaetal lobes are two slender, triangular or digitiform lobes, roughly equal in length. The postchaetal lobes are two shorter, slender, triangular lobes of similar size. The dorsal cirrus, starting from the 3rd parapodium, is conical to oval, inserted on the body wall slightly above the parapodial base. The ventral cirrus is slender, triangular or digitiform, slightly shorter than the postchaetal lobes. The branchia, non-retractile with 1-5 digitiform rami, is located from about parapodium 21-32 to near the posterior end, dorsally on parapodial bases, most developed in the mid-body region, about as long as the prechaetal lobes. Chaetae are simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The type locality is the Sri Lankan EEZ. Its distribution includes the Indian Ocean, Red Sea, Persian Gulf, South China Sea, Indo-Pacific, and Indian states such as Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Goa, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Odisha, West Bengal, Tamil Nadu, and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera fallax QUATREFAGES?
Expected_answer: Glycera fallax Quatrefages, 1850, is characterized by mid-body segments that are biannulate, with the anterior annulus approximately as long as or slightly longer than the posterior one. The prostomium is conical and has 14-17 rings. The proboscidean papillae include two types: numerous conical papillae with three U-shaped ridges, and isolated, broader, oval to globular papillae without ridges. The aileron is triangular. The first two parapodia are uniramous, while subsequent parapodia are biramous. The prechaetal lobes are two slender, triangular to digitiform lobes of similar length; these become slightly slimmer in the posterior parapodia, with the noto podial lobe being shorter than the neuropodial lobe in the last parapodia. The postchaetal lobes are two shorter lobes. Dorsal cirri are conical to oval, present from the third segment onward, positioned slightly above the parapodial base on the body wall. Branchiae are retractile and blister-like, starting from about the 17th to 25th parapodia and extending near the posterior end, situated medially on the anterior side of the parapodia. Chaetae consist of simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirri are slender, triangular to digitiform, about as long as the neuropodial postchaetal lobe, becoming slender and elongated in the posterior parapodia, and in the last parapodia, about as long as the neuropodial prechaetal lobe. They are located medio-ventrally on the parapodia. The type locality is the French EEZ, and the species is distributed in the North Sea, Mediterranean Sea, Andaman Sea, and along the Kerala Coast in India.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera lancadivae?
Expected_answer: Glycera lancadivae Schmarda, 1861 is described with body rings that are bi-annulated in the anterior regions and more or less tri-annulated in the mid-body segments. The prostomium is conical with 9-12 rings. It features two types of proboscidal papillae: numerous digitiform papillae with undulating ridges, and fewer shorter, broader, conical to oval papillae without ridges. The aileron has a slight dent on its pointed triangular base. Parapodia are uniramous in the first two segments, then biramous in following segments. The prechaetal lobes are two slender, triangular to digitiform lobes, and neuropodial lobes are twice as long as notopodial lobes. A single short, rounded postchaetal lobe is present. Dorsal cirri are oval to globular, present from the 3rd segment onwards, and are located on the body wall above the parapodial base. Branchiae are absent. Chaetae include simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirri are slender, triangular to digitiform, about as long as the postchaetal lobe, and become slender and elongated in posterior parapodia. The type locality is the Sri Lankan EEZ, and the species is distributed across Sri Lanka, Madagascar, the Persian Gulf, Australia, and in Indian waters such as the Bay of Bengal, South Arabian Sea, and Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera lapidum?
Expected_answer: Glycera lapidum Quaterefages, 1866, is characterized by body rings with anterior segments being bi-annulated and mid-body segments more or less tri-annulated. The prostomium is elongated and conical, longer than wide, with 10-12 indistinct rings. The proboscidal papillae consist of two types: mostly digitiform shapes of various sizes, and conical, oval-shaped papillae without ridges or undulating ridges. The aileron has a pointed triangular base with a slight dent. The parapodia start as uniramous in the first two segments, then become biramous. The prechaetal lobe is shorter than the prechaetal lobe of the neuropodia throughout the body; in the final segments, both are digitiform. The postchaetal lobe is short and rounded along the body. The dorsal cirrus is conical to oval, present from the third segment onwards, positioned far from the parapodial basis. No branchiae are present. The chaetae are simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirrus is broadly triangular in the front and middle regions and digitiform at the rear. The type locality is Berwick Bay, England. Its distribution includes mainly temperate waters and the tropical Indo-Pacific, particularly in India, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, and the Indian Ocean.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera longipinnis?
Expected_answer: Glycera longipinnis Grube, 1878 is characterized by mid-body segments that are bi-annulated. The prostomium is conical with 12 rings. The proboscidal papillae consist of two types: 1) long cylindrical papillae without rings, and 2) a few stout forms. The aileron features two long, slender rami, with one being twice as long as the other, narrowly united at the base. The first two parapodia are uniramous, while subsequent ones are biramous. The prechaetal lobes are elongate, pointed, and roughly equal in size. The postchaetal lobes are low, rounded, or faintly bilobed. The dorsal cirrus is ovoid. Branchiae are present as filaments on the dorsal edge of the parapodia, longer than the prechaetal lobes, starting from the 20th chaetiger. Chaetae include simple capillaries in the notopodia and compound spinigers in the neuropodia. The ventral cirrus is triangular, much shorter than the prechaetal lobes. The type locality is the Philippines EEZ. The species is distributed in the Red Sea, Sumatra, and regions including the Indian Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera natalensis?
Expected_answer: Glycera natalensis Day, 1957 is characterized by anterior segments that are biannulate, with mid-body segments appearing more or less distinctly triannulate, and the median dorsal region featuring up to 4 tubercles on each side. The prostomium is conical, comprising 16-21 rings. The proboscidal papillae consist of three types: (1) numerous papillae with terminal fingernail structures on long stalks, exhibiting multiple V-shaped ridges and some longitudinal ridges on the nail; (2) less numerous digitiform papillae with an indistinct, straight, median, longitudinal ridge; and (3) isolated, broader, oval to globular papillae lacking ridges. The aileron has a triangular base. Parapodia first appear as uniramous, followed by biramous structures in subsequent segments. The prechaetal lobes are two slender, triangular or digitiform lobes of equal length, slightly slimmer in posterior parapodia, with the last parapodias notopodial lobe being shorter than the neuropodial one. The postchaetal lobes are two shorter structures; the anterior lobes are rounded, while the following parapodia have an elongated, slender, triangular notopodial lobe. The dorsal cirrus, starting from the third parapodium, is conical to oval. Branchiae are non-retractile, simple, digitiform, and present from approximately the 32nd to the 54th parapodium, extending near the posterior end. The chaetae include simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirrus is slender, triangular to digitiform, and approximately as long as the neuropodial postchaetal lobe. The type locality is KwaZulu-Natal, and its distribution includes South Africa, Sri Lanka, and parts of India such as Kerala and the Andaman Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera nicobarica?
Expected_answer: Glycera nicobarica Grube, 1866 Body rings are described as bi-annulated in mid-body segments. The prostomium is elongated and conical, longer than wide, with 10-11 rings. The proboscidal papillae exist in two types: 1) conical papillae with three transverse ridges, which are most abundant, and 2) oval-shaped papillae without ridges. The aileron is noted as 'Aileron with a.' The parapodia are such that the first two are uniramous, while subsequent ones are biramous. The prechaetal lobes are triangular with a broad base in the anterior and mid-body, and become digitiform in the posterior segments. The postchaetal lobes are short. Notopodial lobes are triangular, while neuropodial lobes are rounded. The dorsal cirrus begins from the 2nd segment, conical to oval, situated near the parapodial base. Retractile digitiform branchiae are present from segments 19-26 to the posterior end, predominantly visible in mid-body. The chaetae include simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirrus is broad and triangular in the anterior and mid-body, transforming into a digitiform shape in the posterior. The type locality is the Nicobar Islands, and the species is distributed in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera oxycephala?
Expected_answer: Glycera oxycephala Ehlers, 1887 features a body with rings that vary along its length: anterior segments are bi-annulated, while mid-body segments are mostly tri-annulated. The elongated, conical prostomium, which is longer than wide, consists of 20-25 indistinct rings. The proboscidal papillae include two types: 1) abundant conical papillae with transverse ridges (11-18), and 2) oval-shaped papillae with transverse ridges (5-9). The aileron has a slightly arched base. Parapodia start as uniramous in the first two segments and become biramous afterward. The prechaetal lobes of notopodia and neuropodia are similar in length and transition from broad bases to digitiform shapes from anterior to posterior segments. The postchaetal lobes are short and rounded throughout. Dorsal cirri are conical to oval, beginning from the 3rd segment, located near the parapodial bases. Branchiae are absent. The chaetae consist of simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. Ventral cirri are broadly triangular in the front and middle, changing to digitiform toward the rear. The species was first found in Barbados and is distributed across the Atlantic, North Sea, Red Sea, Australia, Madagascar, East Pacific, and Indias Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera papillosa?
Expected_answer: Glycera papillosa Grube, 1857, has body rings with mid-body segments that are bi-annulated. The prostomium is conical with 8 rings. The proboscidal papillae consist of two types: a few ovoid forms and many long, slender forms without rings. The aileron is deeply forked and slender, with the shorter limb being half the length of the longer one and attached to it. The parapodia initially are uniramous, followed by biramous parapodia. The superior prechaetal lobe is small, while the inferior is large and pointed. A single, rounded postchaetal lobe is present. The small dorsal cirrus arises from the body wall above the parapodium. No branchiae are present or located. The chaetae include simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirrus has a length comparable to the postchaetal lobe. The type locality is in the Chilean part of the South Pacific Ocean. Its distribution spans the Western Atlantic from North Carolina to the Gulf of Mexico, Chile, Western Africa, and the Indian Ocean including the South Arabian Sea and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera posterobranchia?
Expected_answer: Glycera posterobranchia Hoagland, 1920 is characterized by body rings, with mid-body segments being bi-annulated. The prostomium is an elongated, conical structure longer than wide, comprising 10-11 rings. The proboscidal papillae include three types: 1) the most common are papillae with terminal fingernail-like tips and a medium stalk with longitudinal ridges; 2) shorter, conical papillae with longitudinal ridges; 3) oval-shaped papillae without ridges. The aileron features a pointed triangular base. Parapodia start as uniramous in the first two segments, then become biramous. The prechaetal lobes are triangular with broad bases in the anterior and mid-body, and digitiform in posterior segments. The postchaetal lobes are short; notopodial lobes are triangular, while neuropodial lobes are rounded. The dorsal cirrus begins from the third segment, shaped conically to oval, situated near the parapodial base. The branchiae are non-retractile, located between the 16th and 24th segments, dorsomedially on the parapodia towards the posterior. The chaetae consist of simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirrus is broad and triangular in the front and middle parts, changing to a digitiform shape at the rear. The type locality is the Philippines EEZ, with distribution including Philippine Islands, South China Sea, Vietnam, and the Indian Ocean, especially the Bay of Bengal and Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera subaenea?
Expected_answer: Glycera subaenea Grube, 1878 is characterized by body rings where anterior segments are bi-annulated, and mid-body segments are generally tri-annulated. The prostomium is conical, featuring 8-10 rings. The proboscidal papillae include two types: numerous bluntly conical papillae with 1-2 rings and subspherical papillae without rings. The aileron comprises one well-developed prong and another short prong, which is fully united with the first by an oblique shelf. The parapodia start as uniramous in the first two segments and become biramous thereafter. The prechaetal lobes are long, equally pointed, and there are two of them. The postchaetal lobes include a pointed superior lob and a shorter, blunt inferior lob. Branchiae are present, originating from chaetiger 12, positioned on the anterior end of the parapodium, with 2 to 5 branched digitiform lobes. The chaetae consist of simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The type locality is recorded as the Philippines EEZ. The species is distributed across the Philippines, Australia, South China Sea, Madagascar, Red Sea, South Africa, and in the Indian Ocean including South Arabian Sea and Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera sphyrabrancha?
Expected_answer: Glycera sphyrabrancha Schmarda, 1861 is characterized by body rings that are biannulate from chaetiger 10 onward, with the anterior rings being uniannulate. The prostomium is conical, featuring 10-12 rings. Proboscidal papillae are of two types: numerous digitiform papillae without ridges and several isolated, oval to globular papillae also without ridges. The aileron has a deeply incised base. Parapodia first appear uniramous, then become biramous in subsequent segments. The prechaetal lobes are two slender, triangular to digitiform structures on anterior parapodia; noto- and neuropodial prechaetal lobes are generally equal, with middle and posterior parapodia showing slightly longer neuropodial lobes. The postchaetal lobe is rounded. The dorsal cirrus is digitiform, slightly swollen dorsally at the base, longer on anterior and parapodial segments, decreasing in size towards the posterior. The ventral cirrus varies from triangular on anterior segments, digitiform in the middle, to slender on posterior segments. Branchiae are non-retractile, simple, slightly triangular anteriorly, becoming digitiform from the middle of the anterior region, most prominent in the middle body. They appear starting from chaetiger 15 near the upper chaetal lobe. The chaetae include simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The type locality is the Jamaican EEZ, and the species distribution includes the Arabian Gulf, Andaman Sea, Aruba, Belize, Caribbean Sea, Cuba, Curaçao, Honduras, Jamaica, Panama, Philippines, Red Sea, South Africa, South China Sea, Tobago, Trinidad, Venezuela, and regions in India such as Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Goa, Kerala, Lakshadweep Islands, Maharashtra, Odisha, and West Bengal.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera tesselata?
Expected_answer: Glycera tesselata Grube, 1863 is characterized by body rings that are bi-annulated in the anterior segments and more or less tri-annulated in the mid-body segments. The prostomium is conical with 8-9 rings. The proboscidal papillae include two types: mostly digitiform-shaped papillae, with the aileron featuring a deeply incised base. The parapodia initially uniramious, become biramous in the following segments. The prechaetal lobe, triangular with an broad anterior base in the front and mid-body, short and rounded in the posterior segments. The postchaetal lobe remains short and rounded across all segments. The dorsal cirrus, conical to oval, appears from the 3rd segment onward, positioned far from the parapodial basis. The branchiae are absent. The chaetae include simple capillaries in the notopodia and compound spinigers in the neuropodia. The ventral cirrus, broadly triangular at the front and middle, becomes digitiform towards the rear. The type locality is the Mediterranean Sea. Its distribution includes the Northwestern and Northeastern Atlantic, Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean Sea, Mediterranean Sea, Red Sea, southern coasts of Africa, Indo-Pacific, Northwestern Pacific, as well as India Bay of Bangla, Arabian Sea, North Indian Ocean, and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera tridactyla?
Expected_answer: Glycera tridactyla Schmarda, 1861: The body rings are described as bi-annulated in the mid-body segments. The prostomium is conical with 11-14 rings. The proboscidal papillae consist of three types: 1) terminal fingernail-shaped papillae with short stalks and longitudinal ridges, 2) digitiform papillae with longitudinal ridges, and 3) oval-shaped papillae without ridges. The aileron has a pointed triangular base. The parapodia first appear uniramous, then become biramous. The prechaetal lobes are triangular with a broad base in the anterior and mid-body regions and become digitiform in posterior segments. The postchaetal lobes are short; notopodial lobes are triangular and longer than the rounded neuropodial lobes. The dorsal cirrus is conical to oval-shaped, located close to the parapodial base from the 3rd segment onward. Non-retractile digitiform branchiae are present between segments 17 and 22, positioned terminodorsally on the parapodia extending to the posterior end. The chaetae are simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirrus is broadly triangular in the anterior and mid-body, transforming into digitiform shape towards the posterior. The type locality is the Atlantic Ocean. Its geographic distribution includes the Mediterranean Sea, Black Sea, South Africa, Red Sea, Japan coast, South China Sea, New Guinea, Australia, Andaman Sea, and various locations around India such as the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Andaman coast.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera unicornis?
Expected_answer: Glycera unicornis Lamarck, 1818, has body rings characterized by mid-body segments that are biannulate, with the anterior annulus roughly as long as or slightly longer than the posterior one. The prostomium is conical and bears 10-13 rings. Its proboscidal papillae consist of two types: numerous conical papillae with three U-shaped ridges, and isolated, broader oval to globular papillae without ridges. The aileron features a triangular base. Parapodia first appear uniramous for the initial two segments, then become biramous thereafter. The prechaetal lobe comprises two slender, triangular to digitiform lobes, while the postchaetal lobes are two in number, shorter, and rounded anteriorly; in subsequent segments, these lobes are elongated, slender, and roughly the same length. The dorsal cirrus, starting from the second parapodium, varies from conical to oval. Branchiae are retractile, with 1-2 digitiform branchial rami, and are positioned from about the 16th to the 30th parapodium near the posterior end. Chaetae include simple capillaries in the notopodia and compound spinigers in the neuropodia. The ventral cirrus is slender, triangular to digitiform, and approximately as long as the postchaetal lobes. The type locality is unknown. Its geographic distribution spans the Andaman Sea, Black Sea, North Sea, Mediterranean Sea, Madagascar, South China Sea, Java Sea, and regions in India such as Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Goa, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Odisha, West Bengal, Tamil Nadu, and the Andaman coast.
